hollowed: having a cavity within; as, canoe made of a hollowed log.
Halved: Appearing as if one side, or one half, were cut away; dimidiate.
Harmonica: A musical instrument, consisting of a series of hemispherical glasses which, by touching the edges with the dampened finger, give forth the tones; it is now called the glass harmonica, to distinguish it from the common harmonica, formerly called the harmonicon.
Hydrozoal: Of or pertaining to the Hydrozoa.
Harmonics: The doctrine or science of musical sounds.
homeschooling: The practise of providing formal education, especially primary or secondary education, at home rather than in a school.
Hosier: One who deals in hose or stocking, or in goods knit or woven like hose.
half-truth: a partially true statement, especially one intended to deceive or mislead.
Hornbill: Any bird of the family Bucerotidæ, of which about sixty species are known, belonging to numerous genera. They inhabit the tropical parts of Asia, Africa, and the East Indies, and are remarkable for having a more or less horn-like protuberance, which is usually large and hollow and is situated on the upper side of the beak. The size of the hornbill varies from that of a pigeon to that of a raven, or even larger. They feed chiefly upon fruit, but some species eat dead animals.
Homologation: Confirmation or ratification (as of something otherwise null and void), by a court or a grantor.
Hexone: A liquid hydrocarbon, C6H8, of the valylene series, obtained from distillation products of certain fats and gums.
Herderite: A rare fluophosphate of glucina, in small white crystals.
hardnose: A hard-nosed person; one who is realistic and pragmatic and is impatient with those who are not.
Hamulose: Bearing a small hook at the end.
Hemiholohedral: Presenting hemihedral forms, in which half the sectants have the full number of planes.
Host: To lodge at an inn; to take up entertainment.
Harefoot: A long, narrow foot, carried (that is, produced or extending) forward; -- said of dogs.
Hydragogue: Causing a discharge of water; expelling serum effused into any part of the body, as in dropsy.
Hermogenian: A disciple of Hermogenes, an heretical teacher who lived in Africa near the close of the second century. He held matter to be the fountain of all evil, and that souls and spirits are formed of corrupt matter.
Hautboy: A wind instrument, sounded through a reed, and similar in shape to the clarinet, but with a thinner tone. Now more commonly called oboe. See Illust. of Oboe.
Hooven: Affected with hoove; as, hooven, or hoven, cattle.
&Verbar;Heteroptera: A suborder of Hemiptera, in which the base of the anterior wings is thickened. See Hemiptera.
Hydrochloride: A compound of hydrochloric acid with a base; -- distinguished from a chloride, where only chlorine unites with the base.
hypertensive: A person who suffers from persistently high blood pressure.
Hospitalize: To render (a building) unfit for habitation, by long continued use as a hospital.
Hither: Being on the side next or toward the person speaking; nearer; -- correlate of thither and farther; as, on the hither side of a hill.
Hit: A striking against; the collision of one body against another; the stroke that touches anything.
&Verbar;Hypodactylum: The under side of the toes.
Hoarfrost: The white particles formed by the congelation of dew; white frost.
Haricot: A ragout or stew of meat with beans and other vegetables.
Henry: The unit of electric induction; the induction in a circuit when the electro-motive force induced in this circuit is one volt, while the inducing current varies at the rate of one ampère a second.
hibernating: in a state of suspended animation; -- of animals that sleep most of the winter.
Hunchback: A back with a hunch or hump; also, a hunchbacked person.
Harmonicon: A small, flat, wind instrument of music, in which the notes are produced by the vibration of free metallic reeds; it is now called the harmonica.
Housework: The work belonging to housekeeping; especially, kitchen work, sweeping, scrubbing, bed making, and the like.
Half-timbered: Constructed of a timber frame, having the spaces filled in with masonry; -- said of buildings.
Hittite: A member of an ancient people (or perhaps group of peoples) whose settlements extended from Armenia westward into Asia Minor and southward into Palestine. They are known to have been met along the Orontes as early as 1500 b. c., and were often at war with the Egyptians and Assyrians. Especially in the north they developed a considerable civilization, of which numerous monuments and inscriptions are extant. Authorities are not agreed as to their race. While several attempts have been made to decipher the Hittite characters, little progress has yet been made.
Hopper: One who, or that which, hops.
handout: money or an object given in or as in a charitable gesture; -- also used of government disbursements to individuals for welfare; as, government hand-outs to welfare clients.
hr: An abbreviation for hour, the period of time equal to 1/24th of a day.
Hygrostatics: The science or art of comparing or measuring degrees of moisture.
Halation: An appearance as of a halo of light, surrounding the edges of dark objects in a photographic picture.
Heaving: A lifting or rising; a swell; a panting or deep sighing.
Hulver: Holly, an evergreen shrub or tree.
Hepatize: To impregnate with sulphureted hydrogen gas, formerly called hepatic gas.
Hesp: A measure of two hanks of linen thread.
Hairbrush: A brush for cleansing and smoothing the hair.
Hydrotic: Causing a discharge of water or phlegm.
&Verbar;Hortus siccus: A collection of specimens of plants, dried and preserved, and arranged systematically; an herbarium.
Hayrack: A frame mounted on the running gear of a wagon, and used in hauling hay, straw, sheaves, etc.; -- called also hay rigging and hay rig.
Honorably: In an honorable manner; in a manner showing, or consistent with, honor.
Hydrostatician: One who is versed or skilled in hydrostatics.
Himyaric: Pertaining to Himyar, an ancient king of Yemen, in Arabia, or to his successors or people; as, the Himjaritic characters, language, etc.; applied esp. to certain ancient inscriptions showing the primitive type of the oldest form of the Arabic, still spoken in Southern Arabia.
&Verbar;Hatti-sherif: A irrevocable Turkish decree countersigned by the sultan.
Hevea: A small genus of South American trees yielding latex.  It includes the rubber tree, Hevea brasiliensis, originally found in South America, but now used for production of rubber world-wide.
Honorable: Worthy of honor; fit to be esteemed or regarded; estimable; illustrious.
Hay-cutter: A machine in which hay is chopped short, as fodder for cattle.
hot-wire: to start (a car) by using a wire instead of a key, as when stealing the car; the wire is connected to points in the ignition circuit that bypass the key.
Hygroscopic: Of or pertaining to, or indicated by, the hygroscope; not readily manifest to the senses, but capable of detection by the hygroscope; as, glass is often covered with a film of hygroscopic moisture.
Hundreder: An inhabitant or freeholder of a hundred.
Heliometric: Of or pertaining to the heliometer, or to heliometry.
Horseless: Being without a horse; specif., not requiring a horse; -- said of certain vehicles in which horse power has been replaced by electricity, steam, etc.; as, a horseless carriage or truck.  It was used primarily in the term “horseless carriage”, to refer to automobiles.  By the 1930's when automobiles had become more common than horses for transportation, the term had lost its currency.
Howdah: A seat or pavilion, generally covered, fastened on the back of an elephant, for the rider or riders.
&Verbar;Homoptera: A suborder of Hemiptera, in which both pairs of wings are similar in texture, and do not overlap when folded, as in the cicada. See Hemiptera.
Hydrometallurgy: The art or process of assaying or reducing ores by means of liquid reagents.
Highboy: One who lives high; also, in politics, a highflyer.
Hydrocarbon: A compound containing only hydrogen and carbon, as methane, benzene, etc.; also, by extension, any of their derivatives.
Holiness: The state or quality of being holy; perfect moral integrity or purity; freedom from sin; sanctity; innocence.
Hudibrastic: Similar to, or in the style of, the poem “Hudibras,” by Samuel Butler; in the style of doggerel verse.
hairlike: shaped like a hair; long and slender.
&Verbar;Hexandria: A Linnæan class of plants having six stamens.
Hibernicism: An idiom or mode of speech peculiar to the Irish.
Headrope: That part of a boltrope which is sewed to the upper edge or head of a sail.
Hyetology: The science which treats of the precipitation of rain, snow, etc.
Horse Guards: A body of cavalry so called; esp., a British regiment, called the Royal Horse Guards, which furnishes guards of state for the sovereign.
Homelike: Like a home; comfortable; cheerful; cozy; friendly; as, a homelike atmosphere.
hoofmark: a visible impression on a surface made by the hoof of an animal.
Hypnotism: A form of sleep or trance, in some respects resembling somnambulism, but brought on by artificial means, in which there is an unusual suspension of some powers, and an unusual activity of others, especially a heightened susceptibility to suggestion. It is induced by an action upon the nerves, through the medium of the senses, by causing the subject to gaze steadily at a very bright object held before the eyes, or on an oscillating object, or by pressure upon certain points of the surface of the body, usually accompanied by the speaking of the hypnotist in quiet soothing tones.  Called also hypnosis.
Homotropal: Turned in the same direction with something else.
Hangmanship: The office or character of a hangman.
Hellenize: To give a Greek form or character to; to Grecize; as, to Hellenize a word.
Hain: To inclose for mowing; to set aside for grass.
Hail: A wish of health; a salutation; a loud call.
Hexylic: Pertaining to, or derived from, hexyl or hexane; as, hexylic alcohol.
Hair: The collection or mass of filaments growing from the skin of an animal, and forming a covering for a part of the head or for any part or the whole of the body.
Husk: To strip off the external covering or envelope of; as, to husk Indian corn.
Hoarstone: A stone designating the bounds of an estate; a landmark.
High-principled: Possessed of noble or honorable principles.
Halocarpus: A genus of dioecious trees or shrubs of New Zealand; similar in habit to Dacrydium.
Huso: A large European sturgeon (Huso huso or Acipenser huso), inhabiting the region of the Black and Caspian Seas. It sometimes attains a length of more than twelve feet, and a weight of two thousand pounds. Called also hausen and beluga.  It is the source of the finest and most esteemed caviar.
Hexoctahedron: A solid having forty-eight equal triangular faces.
Hominoidea: A superfamily of mammals including anthropoid apes and human beings.
Hydrogen: A gaseous element, colorless, tasteless, and odorless, the lightest known substance, being fourteen and a half times lighter than air (hence its use in filling balloons), and over eleven thousand times lighter than water. It is very abundant, being an ingredient of water and of many other substances, especially those of animal or vegetable origin. It may by produced in many ways, but is chiefly obtained by the action of acids (as sulphuric) on metals, as zinc, iron, etc. It is very inflammable, and is an ingredient of coal gas and water gas. It is standard of chemical equivalents or combining weights, and also of valence, being the typical monad. Symbol H. Atomic weight 1.
&Verbar;Halesia: A genus of American shrubs containing several species, called snowdrop trees, or silver-bell trees. They have showy, white flowers, drooping on slender pedicels.
Hydrophanous: Made transparent by immersion in water.
Helioscope: A telescope or instrument for viewing the sun without injury to the eyes, as through colored glasses, or with mirrors which reflect but a small portion of light.
&Verbar;Hypogeum: The subterraneous portion of a building, as in amphitheaters, for the service of the games; also, subterranean galleries, as the catacombs.
hand-hole: A small hole in a boiler for the insertion of the hand in cleaning, etc.
Health: The state of being hale, sound, or whole, in body, mind, or soul; especially, the state of being free from physical disease or pain.
hindsight: understanding the nature of an event after it has happened; as, hindsight is always clearer than foresight.
Hothouse: A house kept warm to shelter tender plants and shrubs from the cold air; a place in which the plants of warmer climates may be reared, and fruits ripened.
handlebar: The curved bar connected by a shaft to the front wheel of a bicycle or motorcycle, positioned nearly horizontally in front of the rider's seat, designed to be gripped by the rider while riding, and used to steer the vehicle.  Usually used in the plural; as, don't let go of the handlbars.
head-on: characterized by direct opposition; as, a head-on confrontation.
Half-sister: A sister by one parent only.
Hexose: Any member of a group of sugars containing six carbon atoms in the molecule. Some are widely distributed in nature, esp. in ripe fruits.
Horizontality: The state or quality of being horizontal.
handrail: a rail{1} at the side of staircase or balcony to prevent people from falling; -- shaped so as to be conveniently gripped with the hand; as, please hold onto the handrail when crossing the walkway.
Hypodermic syringe: a small syringe designed for use together with a hypodermic needle{1} for injection of liquids directly under the skin, or into other parts of the body of an animal.
Hydrophobic: Of or pertaining to hydrophobia; producing or caused by rabies; as, hydrophobic symptoms; the hydrophobic poison.
Humility: The state or quality of being humble; freedom from pride and arrogance; lowliness of mind; a modest estimate of one's own worth; a sense of one's own unworthiness through imperfection and sinfulness; self-abasement; humbleness.
heralded: widely publicized; as, the royal couple's much heralded world tour.
Hypostatic: Relating to hypostasis, or substance; hence, constitutive, or elementary.
&Verbar;Hematosis: Sanguification; the conversion of chyle into blood.
Hornbeam: A tree of the genus Carpinus (Carpinus Americana), having a smooth gray bark and a ridged trunk, the wood being white and very hard.  It is common along the banks of streams in the United States, and is also called ironwood.  The English hornbeam is Carpinus Betulus.  The American is called also blue beech and water beech.
Hyemal: Belonging to winter; done in winter.
handcar: a small railroad car propelled by hand or by a small motor.
Handily: In a handy manner; skillfully; conveniently.
Hebridean: Of or pertaining to the islands called Hebrides, west of Scotland.
Hagbut: A harquebus, of which the but was bent down or hooked for convenience in taking aim.
Humanitarian: One who denies the divinity of Christ, and believes him to have been merely human.
Halma: A game played on a board having 256 squares, by two persons with 19 men each, or by four with 13 men each, starting from different corners and striving to place each his own set of men in a corresponding position in the opposite corner by moving them or by jumping them over those met in progress.
&Verbar;Heliopora: An East Indian stony coral now known to belong to the Alcyonaria; -- called also blue coral.
Humbler: One who, or that which, humbles some one.
Hydrotellurate: A salt formed by the union of hydrotelluric acid and the base.
hitchhike: To travel by getting free rides from passing vehicles; as, to hitchhike across the country.
Hamitic: Pertaining to Ham or his descendants.
Hypochlorite: A salt of hypochlorous acid; as, a calcium hypochloride.
Hemisect: To divide along the mesial plane.
Hollow: To urge or call by shouting.
Header: One who, or that which, heads nails, rivets, etc., esp. a machine for heading.
Hearten: To encourage; to animate; to incite or stimulate the courage of; to embolden.
Hypoglossal: Under the tongue; -- applied esp., in the higher vertebrates, to the twelfth or last pair of cranial nerves, which are distributed to the base of the tongue.
&Verbar;Hematoma: A localised leakage of blood from the blood vessels into nearby tissues, usually confined within a tissue or organ; especially, a local swelling produced by an effusion of blood beneath the skin, which may clot and discolor the affected area.
Hydrastine: An alkaloid, found in the rootstock of the golden seal (Hydrastis Canadensis), and extracted as a bitter, white, crystalline substance. It is used as a tonic and febrifuge.
Hearted: Having a heart; having (such) a heart (regarded as the seat of the affections, disposition, or character).
homey: having a feeling of home; cozy and comfortable; as, the homey everyday atmosphere; a restaurant with a homey atmosphere.
Haploid: having half the number of chromosomes normally present in somatic cells; having only one chromosome of each type, and therefore having only one complete set of genes; Contrasted with diploid and polyploid.  See also diploid.
Heteropelmous: Having each of the two flexor tendons of the toes bifid, the branches of one going to the first and second toes; those of the other, to the third and fourth toes. See Illust. in Append.
Horometry: The art, practice, or method of measuring time by hours and subordinate divisions.
Hibbertia: A genus of evergreen heathlike or scandent shrubs of Madagascar, Australasia, and Polynesia.
Hurricane: A violent storm, characterized by extreme fury and sudden changes of the wind, and generally accompanied by rain, thunder, and lightning; -- especially prevalent in the East and West Indies. Also used figuratively.
Helianthoid: Of or pertaining to the Helianthoidea.
Haycock: A conical pile or heap of hay in the field.
Holding: The act or state of sustaining, grasping, or retaining.
Histozyme: A soluble enzyme occurring in the animal body, to the presence of which many normal decompositions and synthetical processes are supposed to be due.
Hyperchromatism: The condition of having an unusual intensity of color.
Heathy: Full of heath; abounding with heath; as, heathy land; heathy hills.
Hookes joint: A universal joint. See under Universal.
Homiletics: The art of preaching; that branch of theology which treats of homilies or sermons, and the best method of preparing and delivering them.
Helodermatidae: A natural family of lizards, including the only known venomous lizards.
&Verbar;Hautgo\u00fbt: High relish or flavor; high seasoning.
Hemihedron: A solid hemihedrally derived. The tetrahedron is a hemihedron.
Homely: Plainly; rudely; coarsely; as, homely dressed.
&Verbar;Houstonia: A genus of small rubiaceous herbs, having tetramerous salveform blue or white flower. There are about twenty species, natives of North America. Also, a plant of this genus.
Humorism: The theory founded on the influence which the humors were supposed to have in the production of disease; Galenism.
Hartford: The Hartford grape, a variety of grape first raised at Hartford, Connecticut, from the Northern fox grape. Its large dark-colored berries ripen earlier than those of most other kinds.
hitchhiker: a person who travels by getting free rides from passing vehicles; one who hitchhikes.
Hobbler: One who by his tenure was to maintain a horse for military service; a kind of light horseman in the Middle Ages who was mounted on a hobby.
honey eater: One of numerous species of small passerine birds of the family Meliphagidæ having tongue and bill adapted for extracting nectar, abundant in Australia and Oceania; -- called also honeysucker.
Heleodytes: A genus comprising the cactus wrens; one of several alternative classifications.
Hobit: A small mortar on a gun carriage, in use before the howitzer.
&Verbar;Hydrarthrosis: An effusion of watery liquid into the cavity of a joint.
Hairiness: The state of abounding, or being covered, with hair.
Hummum: A sweating bath or place for sweating.
hallucinogen: A substance capable of producing hallucinations when ingested; a hallucinogenic substance; as, LSD is a powerful hallucinogen.
Hydramine: One of a series of artificial, organic bases, usually produced as thick viscous liquids by the action of ammonia on ethylene oxide. They have the properties both of alcohol and amines.
Hyomental: Between the hyoid bone and the lower jaw, pertaining to them; suprahyoid; submaxillary; as, the hyomental region of the front of the neck.
Hemimellitic: Having half as many (three) carboxyl radicals as mellitic acid; -- said of an organic acid.
Homologize: To determine the homologies or structural relations of.
&Verbar;Hyperbaton: A figurative construction, changing or inverting the natural order of words or clauses; as, “echoed the hills” for “the hills echoed.”
Humoristic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a humorist.
Hollow-horned: Having permanent horns with a bony core, as cattle.
Holocene: The geological period comprising approximately the last 10,000 years.
Hardenbergia: A small genus of Australian woody vines with small violet flowers; closely related to genus Kennedia.
Hotcockles: A childish play, in which one covers his eyes, and guesses who strikes him or his hand placed behind him.
Hypodermic: Of or pertaining to the parts under the skin.
Hydroxylamine: A nitrogenous, organic base, NH2.OH, resembling ammonia, and produced by a modified reduction of nitric acid. It is usually obtained as a volatile, unstable solution in water. It acts as a strong reducing agent.
Hydride: A compound of the binary type, in which hydrogen is united with some other element.
Hyrcanian: Of or pertaining to Hyrcania, an ancient country or province of Asia, southeast of the Caspian (which was also called the Hyrcanian) Sea.
Hessite: A lead-gray sectile mineral. It is a telluride of silver.
heuristically: In a heuristic manner; by using a heuristic method; by serving as a heuristic method; as, a heuristically guided search technique; a heuristically valuable theory.
Hireling: Serving for hire or wages; venal; mercenary.
Heliciform: Having the form of a helix; spiral.
Helmet: A defensive covering for the head. See Casque, Headpiece, Morion, Sallet, and Illust. of Beaver.
Hypocraterimorphous: Salver-shaped; having a slender tube, expanding suddenly above into a bowl-shaped or spreading border, as in the blossom of the phlox and the lilac.
hairnet: a small net that some women wear over their hair to keep it in place.
hotelier: an owner or manager of a hotel or hotels.
Hazy: Thick with haze; somewhat obscured with haze; not clear or transparent.
Hilly: Abounding with hills; uneven in surface; as, a hilly country.
H\u00e6madromograph: An instrument for registering the velocity of the blood.
Haze: To harass by exacting unnecessary, disagreeable, or difficult work.
Harborer: One who, or that which, harbors.
Herniotomy: A surgical procedure for the cure or relief of hernia; celotomy.
Halogenous: Of the nature of a halogen.
Hematinon: A red consisting of silica, borax, and soda, fused with oxide of copper and iron, and used in enamels, mosaics, etc.
His: Belonging or pertaining to him; -- used as a pronominal adjective or adjective pronoun; as, tell John his papers are ready; formerly used also for its, but this use is now obsolete.
Hero: An illustrious man, supposed to be exalted, after death, to a place among the gods; a demigod, as Hercules.
heartleaf: wild ginger (Asarum shuttleworthii) having persistent heart-shaped pungent leaves, growing from Western Virginia to Alabama.
Hydrogenation: The act of combining with hydrogen, or the state of being so combined.
Herb: A plant whose stem does not become woody and permanent, but dies, at least down to the ground, after flowering.
&Verbar;Holometabola: Those insects which have a complete metamorphosis; metabola.
Hypercriticise: To criticise with unjust severity; to criticise captiously.
Here: In this place; in the place where the speaker is; -- opposed to there.
Herd: To form or put into a herd.
Hery: To worship; to glorify; to praise.
Hid: imp. & p. p. of Hide. See Hidden.
Hers: See the Note under Her, pron.
Holder-forth: One who speaks in public; an haranguer; a preacher.  See hold forth (b) under hold.
Hard-mouthed: Not sensible to the bit; not easily governed; as, a hard-mouthed horse.
Homily: A discourse or sermon read or pronounced to an audience; a serious discourse.
hopsacking: a loosely woven coarse fabric of cotton or linen, used in clothing.
Hickory: An American tree of the genus Carya, of which there are several species.  The shagbark is the Carya alba, and has a very rough bark; it affords the hickory nut of the markets.  The pignut, or brown hickory, is the Carya glabra.  The swamp hickory is Carya amara, having a nut whose shell is very thin and the kernel bitter.
Hunky: All right; in a good condition; also, even; square.
&Verbar;Hemiptera: An order of hexapod insects having a jointed proboscis, including four sharp stylets (mandibles and maxillæ), for piercing. In many of the species (Heteroptera) the front wings are partially coriaceous, and different from the others.
Haliography: Description of the sea; the science that treats of the sea.
hipbone: Either of two large flaring bones, each forming one half of the pelvis; made up of the ilium and ischium and pubis.
Heptateuch: The first seven books of the Testament.
Heterogeneous: Differing in kind; having unlike qualities; possessed of different characteristics; dissimilar; -- opposed to homogeneous, and said of two or more connected objects, or of a conglomerate mass, considered in respect to the parts of which it is made up.
Hemitrope: That which is hemitropal in construction; (Crystallog.) a twin crystal having a hemitropal structure.
Hirtellous: Pubescent with minute and somewhat rigid hairs.
Habitat: The natural abode, locality or region of an animal or plant.
Hygroplasm: The fluid portion of the cell protoplasm, in opposition to stereoplasm, the solid or insoluble portion. The latter is supposed to be partly nutritive and partly composed of idioplasm.
Harmattan: A dry, hot wind, prevailing on the Atlantic coast of Africa, in December, January, and February, blowing from the interior or Sahara. It is usually accompanied by a haze which obscures the sun.
hod carrier: A construction worker whose main function is to carry construction materials in a hod{1}.
Hackney: To devote to common or frequent use, as a horse or carriage; to wear out in common service; to make trite or commonplace; as, a hackneyed metaphor or quotation.
hardback: A book with cardboard or cloth or leather covers; a hardcover book.  Compare paperback.
hard-won: Acquired with difficulty; as, to squander one's hard-won fortune.
Hermodactyl: A heart-shaped bulbous root, about the size of a finger, brought from Turkey, formerly used as a cathartic.
Here-at: At, or by reason of, this; as, he was offended hereat.
Hoppet: A hand basket; also, a dish used by miners for measuring ore.
hypersphere: A mathematical object existing in more than three dimensions, analogous to the sphere in that all points on the surface are equidistant from the central point; a generalization of a sphere in more than three dimensions.
Horse-leechery: The business of a farrier; especially, the art of curing the diseases of horses.
Horizontally: In a horizontal direction or position; on a level; as, moving horizontally.
Horde: A wandering troop or gang; especially, a clan or tribe of a nomadic people migrating from place to place for the sake of pasturage, plunder, etc.; a predatory multitude.
&Verbar;Hematotherma: The warm-blooded vertebrates, comprising the mammals and birds; -- the antithesis to hematocrya.
henyard: an enclosed yard for keeping poultry.
hallway: an interior passage or corridor in a building, onto which rooms open.
Hydantoic: Pertaining to, or derived from, hydantoin. See Glycoluric.
Hostry: A hostelry; an inn or lodging house.
Hydrodynamometer: An instrument to measure the velocity of a liquid current by the force of its impact.
Hibernal: Belonging or relating to winter; wintry; winterish.
&Verbar;Hyperplasia: An increase in, or excessive growth of, the normal elements of any part.
Hatch: To close with a hatch or hatches.
hootenanny: An informal social gathering or concert featuring mostly folk songs, sometimes dancing, and where the audience often participates in the singing.
hit-or-miss: performed without care or close attention; slipshod; careless; -- of the manner of performing a task.  Opposite of careful, conscientious or methodical.
Hebdomadally: In periods of seven days; weekly.
Hyponitrous: Containing or derived from nitrogen having a lower valence than in nitrous compounds.
Hyacinth: A bulbous plant of the genus Hyacinthus, bearing beautiful spikes of fragrant flowers. Hyacinthus orientalis is a common variety.
Hagborn: Born of a hag or witch.
Hurr: To make a rolling or burring sound.
Holt: A piece of woodland; especially, a woody hill.
Holm: A common evergreen oak, of Europe (Quercus Ilex); -- called also ilex, and holly.
Hercules: A hero, fabled to have been the son of Jupiter and Alcmena, and celebrated for great strength, esp. for the accomplishment of his twelve great tasks or “labors.”
Hibernate: To winter; to pass the season of winter in close quarters, in a torpid or lethargic state, as certain mammals, reptiles, and insects.
Hurl: The act of hurling or throwing with violence; a cast; a fling.
Hyetographic: Of or pertaining to to hyetography.
Hole: To go or get into a hole.
Hierogram: A form of sacred or hieratic writing.
Hexdecylic: Pertaining to, or derived from, hexdecyl or hecdecane; as, hexdecylic alcohol.
hogan: An earth-covered Navajo lodge; it is traditionally built with the entrance facing east.
Half-life: the time it takes for one-half of a substance decaying in a first-order reaction to be destroyed.  For radioactive substances, it is the time required for one-half of the initial amount of the radioactive isotope to decay.  The half-lifeis a measure of the rate of the reaction being observed.  For processes that are true first-order processes, such as radioactive decay, the half-life is independent of the quantity of material present, and it is thus a constant.  The time it takes for one-half the remaining quantity of a radioactive isotope to decay will be the same regardless of how far the decay process has advanced.  Some chemical reactions are also first order, and may be characterized as having a half-life.  However, for chemical reactions the half-life will depend upon temperature and in some cases other environmental conditions, whereas for radioactive isotopes the rate of decay is largely independent of the environment.
Hemoptysis: The expectoration of blood, due usually to hemorrhage from the mucous membrane of the lungs.
&Verbar;Honorarium: A fee offered to professional men for their services; as, an honorarium of one thousand dollars.
&Verbar;Hyporhachis: The stem of an aftershaft or hypoptilum.
hoodooism: Voodoo, a form of religion practiced chiefly in Caribbean countries (esp. Haiti); it involves witchcraft and animistic deities.
Hand-tight: As tight as can be made by the hand; as, to tighten the nut hand-tight.
&Verbar;Hormogonium: A chain of small cells in certain algæ, by which the plant is propagated.
Heterotaxy: Variation in arrangement from that existing in a normal form; heterogenous arrangement or structure, as, in botany, the deviation in position of the organs of a plant, from the ordinary or typical arrangement.
Hair worm: A nematoid worm of the genus Gordius, resembling a hair.  See Gordius.
Habiliment: A garment; an article of clothing.
Hydrogenous: Of or pertaining to hydrogen; containing hydrogen.
Heterotropal: Having the embryo or ovule oblique or transverse to the funiculus; amphitropous.
Harmonium: A musical instrument, resembling a small organ and especially designed for church music, in which the tones are produced by forcing air by means of a bellows so as to cause the vibration of free metallic reeds. It is now made with one or two keyboards, and has pedals and stops.
Hyphenated: United by hyphens; hyphened; as, a hyphenated or hyphened word.
&Verbar;H\u00e6matoxylon: A genus of leguminous plants containing but a single species, the Haematoxylon Campechianum or logwood tree, native in Yucatan.
Hypodicrotic: Exhibiting retarded dicrotism; as, a hypodicrotic pulse curve.
H\u00e6mapodous: Having the limbs on, or directed toward, the ventral or hemal side, as in vertebrates; -- opposed to neuropodous.
Heretification: The act of hereticating or pronouncing heretical.
&Verbar;Hyperapophysis: A lateral and backward-projecting process on the dorsal side of a vertebra.
Helpless: Destitute of help or strength; unable to help or defend one's self; needing help; feeble; weak; as, a helpless infant.
Helium: An inert, monoatomic, gaseous element occurring in the atmosphere of the sun and stars, and in small quantities in the earth's atmosphere, in several minerals and in certain mineral waters. It is obtained from natural gas in industrial quantities.  Symbol, He; atomic number 2; at. wt., 4.0026 (C=12.011). Helium was first detected spectroscopically in the sun by Lockyer in 1868; it was first prepared by Ramsay in 1895. Helium has a density of 1.98 compared with hydrogen, and is more difficult to liquefy than the latter. Chemically, it is an inert noble gas, belonging to the argon group, and cannot be made to form compounds. The helium nucleus is the charged particle which constitutes alpha rays, and helium is therefore formed as a decomposition product of certain radioactive substances such as radium.  The normal helium nucleus has two protons and two neutrons, but an isotope with only one neutron is also observed in atmospheric helium at an abundance of 0.013 %.  Liquid helium has a boiling point of -268.9° C at atmospheric pressure, and is used for maintaining very low temperatures, both in laboratory experimentation and in commercial applications to maintain superconductivity in low-temperature superconducting devices.  Gaseous helium at normal temperatures is used for buoyancy in blimps, dirigibles, and high-altitude balloons, and also for amusement in party balloons.
Heathenry: The state, quality, or character of the heathen.
Homicide: The killing of one human being by another.
&Verbar;Hyphomycetes: One of the great division of fungi, containing those species which have naked spores borne on free or only fasciculate threads.
Hinderling: A worthless, base, degenerate person or animal.
Heelpiece: A piece of armor to protect the heels.
&Verbar;Hydroidea: An extensive order of Hydrozoa or Acalephæ.
holography: The process of producing holograms, usually requiring a source of coherent light, as from a laser.
Hookah: A pipe with a long, flexible stem, so arranged that the smoke is cooled by being made to pass through water.  Also called narghile and water pipe.  The hubble-bubble is a simple form of this device.
Humstrum: An instrument out of tune or rudely constructed; music badly played.
Hoard: To lay up a store or hoard, as of money.
Homolographic: Preserving the mutual relations of parts, especially as to size and form; maintaining relative proportion.
&Verbar;Hyalonema: A genus of hexactinelline sponges, having a long stem composed of very long, slender, transparent, siliceous fibres twisted together like the strands of a color.  The stem of the Japanese species (Hyalonema Sieboldii), called glass-rope, has long been in use as an ornament. See Glass-rope.
Hippocrepian: One of an order of fresh-water Bryozoa, in which the tentacles are on a lophophore, shaped like a horseshoe. See Phylactolæma.
&Verbar;Hapuku: A large and valuable food fish (Polyprion prognathus) of New Zealand. It sometimes weighs one hundred pounds or more.
&Verbar;Hydropiper: A species (Polygonum Hydropiper) of knotweed with acrid foliage; water pepper; smartweed.
heights: a high place; the high part of a district; as, he doesn't like heights.
Harts-tongue: A common British fern (Scolopendrium vulgare), rare in America.
Hornbug: A large nocturnal beetle of the genus Lucanus (as Lucanus capreolus, and Lucanus dama), having long, curved upper jaws, resembling a sickle.  The grubs are found in the trunks of old trees.
Heathery: Heathy; abounding in heather; of the nature of heath.
Headborough: The chief of a frankpledge, tithing, or decennary, consisting of ten families; -- called also borsholder, boroughhead, boroughholder, and sometimes tithingman. See Borsholder.
Haiti: a country on the island of Hispaniola.
Huckster: To deal in small articles, or in petty bargains.
Hagiolatry: The invocation or worship of saints.
High-reaching: Reaching high or upward; hence, ambitious; aspiring.
Hiatus: An opening; an aperture; a gap; a chasm; esp., a defect in a manuscript, where some part is lost or effaced; a space where something is wanting; a break.
Herpesvirus: any of several dozen DNA-containing virus of the family Herpetoviridae, including among them such human-disease-causing agents as Herpes simplex virus causing oral and genital herpes, varicella-zoster virus (Herpes zoster virus) causing shingles and chickenpox (varicella), Epstein-Barr virus (EB virus) causing infectious mononucleosis, and Cytomegalovirus.
Headmost: Most advanced; most forward; as, the headmost ship in a fleet.
Hegemony: Leadership; preponderant influence or authority; -- usually applied to the relation of a government or state to its neighbors or confederates.
Heterocercy: Unequal development of the tail lobes of fishes; the possession of a heterocercal tail.
Hin: A Hebrew measure of liquids, containing three quarts, one pint, one gill, English measure.
homogenized: formed by blending unlike elements, especially by reducing one element to particles and dispersing them throughout another substance.
Hematite: An important ore of iron, the sesquioxide, so called because of the red color of the powder. It occurs in splendent rhombohedral crystals, and in massive and earthy forms; -- the last called red ocher. Called also specular iron, oligist iron, rhombohedral iron ore, and bloodstone. See Brown hematite, under Brown.
Homespun: Cloth made at home; as, he was dressed in homespun.
Hydropathy: The water cure; a mode of treating diseases by the copious and frequent use of pure water, both internally and externally.
Hyson: A fragrant kind of green tea.
Haggler: One who haggles or is difficult in bargaining.
hard-nosed: facing reality squarely; guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory; tough and pragmatic; as, a hard-nosed businessman.
Hillside: The side or declivity of a hill.
Hyalite: A pellucid variety of opal in globules looking like colorless gum or resin; -- called also Müller's glass.
Hogger-pipe: The upper terminal pipe of a mining pump.
Hyksos: A dynasty of Egyptian kings, often called the Shepherd kings, of foreign origin, who, according to the narrative of Manetho, ruled for about 500 years, forming the XVth and XVIth dynasties. It is now considered that the XVIth is merely a double of the XVth dynasty, and that the total period of the six Hyksos kings was little more than 100 years. It is supposed that they were Asiatic Semites.
Hoggerel: A sheep of the second year. [Written also hogrel.] Ash.
Half-blooded: Proceeding from a male and female of different breeds or races; having only one parent of good stock; as, a half-blooded sheep.
hologram: A photographic image giving the observer a seemingly three-dimensional view of the represented object.  The three-dimensional effect is produced by exposing a photographic recording medium to an interference pattern generated by a coherent beam of light (as from a laser) reflected from the subject, interacting with a beam directly from the source.  The full three-dimensional effect requires illumination of the image with coherent light, but less perfect three-dimensional visual effects may also be observed when the hologram is illuminated with white light.
Hockey: A game in which two parties of players, armed with sticks curved or hooked at the end, attempt to drive any small object (as a ball or a bit of wood) toward opposite goals.
Hexatomic: Having six atoms in the molecule.
Hydroferricyanic: Pertaining to, or containing, or obtained from, hydrogen, ferric iron, and cyanogen; as, hydroferricyanic acid. See Ferricyanic.
humidification: The act or process of increasing the moisture content; -- usually used of gases, especially air.
Hopperings: Gravel retaining in the hopper of a cradle.
Hollo: To call out or exclaim; to halloo.
&Verbar;Hyper\u00e6mia: A superabundance or congestion of blood in an organ or part of the body.
Hyalescence: The process of becoming, or the state of being, transparent like glass.
Hypercatalectic: Having a syllable or two beyond measure; as, a hypercatalectic verse.
&Verbar;Heptagynia: A Linnæan order of plants having seven pistils.
Hermeneutic: Unfolding the signification; of or pertaining to interpretation; exegetical; explanatory; as, hermeneutic theology, or the art of expounding the Scriptures; a hermeneutic phrase.
handfastly: In a handfast or publicly pledged manner.
Heliochromic: Pertaining to, or produced by, heliochromy.
Heteropodous: Of or pertaining to the Heteropoda.
Hyperborean: One of the people who lived beyond the North wind, in a land of perpetual sunshine.
hyperventilation: The act or process of hyperventilating; breathing rapidly and deeply.
Herrnhuter: One of the Moravians; -- so called from the settlement of Herrnhut (the Lord's watch) made, about 1722, by the Moravians at the invitation of Nicholas Lewis, count of Zinzendorf, upon his estate in the circle of Bautzen.
-hood: A termination denoting state, condition, quality, character, totality, as in manhood, childhood, knighthood, brotherhood. Sometimes it is written, chiefly in obsolete words, in the form -head.
Hellanodic: A judge or umpire in games or combats.
Heighten: To make high; to raise higher; to elevate.
Hemlock: The name of several poisonous umbelliferous herbs having finely cut leaves and small white flowers, as the Cicuta maculata, Cicuta bulbifera, and Cicuta virosa, and the Conium maculatum. See Conium.
H\u00e6mochromometer: An apparatus for measuring the amount of hemoglobin in a fluid, by comparing it with a solution of known strength and of normal color.
higher-up: A superior officer or official; a person having greater rank or station or quality than others; -- used chiefly in pl.
Hydrolase: an enzyme which causes the splitting of a chemical bond with the addition of the elements of water; a hydrolytic enzyme.  Formerly called a hydrolytic ferment.
Humidity: Moisture; dampness; a moderate degree of wetness, which is perceptible to the eye or touch; -- used especially of the atmosphere, or of anything which has absorbed moisture from the atmosphere, as clothing.
Hebraistic: Pertaining to, or resembling, the Hebrew language or idiom.
hide-and-seek: A game played by children, in which one child (who is “it”) covers his eyes for a short time while the other players hide, and then the one who is “it” tries to find the others.
Heddling: The act of drawing the warp threads through the heddle-eyes of a weaver's harness; the harness itself.
Hotly: In a hot or fiery manner; ardently; vehemently; violently; hastily; as, a hotly pursued.
-handled: having a usually specified type of handle; as, a pearl-handled revolver; a long-handled shovel.
Harelip: A lip, commonly the upper one, having a fissure of perpendicular division like that of a hare.
Hydrargyrate: Of or pertaining to mercury; containing, or impregnated with, mercury.
Hemicarp: One portion of a fruit that spontaneously divides into halves.
Heaper: One who heaps, piles, or amasses.
Hereinbefore: In the preceding part of this (writing, document, book, etc.).
Hexokinase: an enzyme catalyzing the transfer of a phosphate residue from ATP to a hexose, as in the formation of glucose-6-phosphate from glucose.
Halyard: A rope or tackle for hoisting or lowering yards, sails, flags, etc.
hamming: poor acting by a ham actor; see ham.
Hecdecane: A white, semisolid, spermaceti-like hydrocarbon, C16H34, of the paraffin series, found dissolved as an important ingredient of kerosene, and so called because each molecule has sixteen atoms of carbon; -- called also hexadecane.
Haurient: In pale, with the head in chief; -- said of the figure of a fish, as if rising for air.
Hogchain: A chain or tie rod, in a boat or barge, to prevent the vessel from hogging.
Harts clover: Melilot or sweet clover. See Melilot.
Hornwrack: A bryozoan of the genus Flustra.
Helipterum: genus of South African and Australian herbs or shrubs grown as everlastings; the various Helipterum species are currently in process of being assigned to other genera, especially Pteropogon and Hyalosperma.
Hypnologist: One who is versed in hypnology.
Hindustani: a native or inhabitant of Hindustan or India.
Hold up: To rob, usually at gunpoint or knifepoint.
Hypnocyst: A cyst in which some unicellular organisms temporarily inclose themselves, from which they emerge unchanged, after a period of drought or deficiency of food. In some instances, a process of spore formation seems to occur within such cysts.
hypercube: A mathematical object existing in more than three dimensions, analogous to the cube in that each two-dimensional facet of the surface is a square; a generalization of a cube in more than three dimensions.
Hipshot: Having the hip dislocated; hence, having one hip lower than the other.
Heliograph: To telegraph, or signal, with a heliograph.
headline: To mention in a headline.
Hotchpot: A mingled mass; a confused mixture; a stew of various ingredients; a hodgepodge.
Haliographer: One who writes about or describes the sea.
&Verbar;Hypopharynx: An appendage or fold on the lower side of the pharynx, in certain insects.
Hommock: A small eminence of a conical form, of land or of ice; a knoll; a hillock. See Hummock.
Houseline: A small line of three strands used for seizing; -- called also housing.
Hypohyal: Pertaining to one or more small elements in the hyoidean arch of fishes, between the caratohyal and urohyal.
Hypoxanthin: A crystalline, nitrogenous substance, closely related to xanthin and uric acid, widely distributed through the animal body, but especially in muscle tissue; -- called also sarcin, sarkin.
&Verbar;Helminthiasis: A disease in which worms are present in some part of the body.
Hastings: Early fruit or vegetables; especially, early pease.
Haitian: Same as Haytian; -- now the preferred spelling.
&Verbar;Heft: A number of sheets of paper fastened together, as for a notebook; also, a part of a serial publication.
Homicidal: Pertaining to homicide; tending to homicide; murderous; as, a homicidal maniac.
highchair: a chair designed for feeding a very young child, having four long legs and a footrest and a detachable tray, which rests in front of the child, holds the food, and also serves as a restraint, to keep the child from falling out of the chair.
Havana: Of or pertaining to Havana, the capital of the island of Cuba; as, an Havana cigar
Handicapper: One who determines the conditions of a handicap.
Hopeful: Full of hope, or agreeable expectation; inclined to hope; expectant.
High-palmed: Having high antlers; bearing full-grown antlers aloft.
Handicapped: suffering from a handicap (in senses 4 or 5); disabled; at a disadvantage.
Heck: hell; -- a euphemism.  Used commonly in the phrase “What the heck”.
Helenin: A neutral organic substance found in the root of the elecampane (Inula helenium), and extracted as a white crystalline or oily material, with a slightly bitter taste.
Hesperetin: A white, crystalline substance having a sweetish taste, obtained by the decomposition of hesperidin, and regarded as a complex derivative of caffeic acid.
Hooper: The European whistling, or wild, swan (Olor cygnus); -- called also hooper swan, whooping swan, and elk.
Holstein: One of a breed of cattle, originally from Schleswig-Holstein, valued for the large amount of milk produced by the cows. The color is usually black and white in irregular patches.
Heraldically: In an heraldic manner; according to the rules of heraldry.
Hemmer: One who, or that which, hems with a needle.
Heliotroper: The person at a geodetic station who has charge of the heliotrope.
Hydro-a\u00ebroplane: An aëroplane with a boatlike or other understructure that enables it to travel on, or to rise from the surface of, a body of water by its own motive power; -- now usually referred to as a seaplane.
Heliotropic: Manifesting heliotropism; turning toward the sun.
halfpennyworth: the amount that can be bought for a halfpenny.
Hippodrome: To arrange contests with predetermined winners.
holloware: serving dishes of silver having some depth in the bowl; contrasted with flatware.
Holohemihedral: Presenting hemihedral forms, in which all the sectants have halt the whole number of planes.
Holosiderite: Meteoric iron; a meteorite consisting of metallic iron without stony matter.
Hereinafter: In the following part of this (writing, document, speech, and the like).
Highlander: a soldier in a Scottish Highland regiment.
Hitlerian: of or pertaining to Adolf Hitler; resembling the policies of Hitler.
Henware: A coarse, blackish seaweed. See Badderlocks.
hoactzin: A crested ill-smelling South American bird (Opisthocomus hoazin) whose young have claws on the first and second digits of the wings.
hand-crafted: made by hand or by a hand process.  Contrasted to machine-made.
Hastily: In haste; with speed or quickness; speedily; nimbly.
Handy-dandy: A child's play, one child guessing in which closed hand the other holds some small object, winning the object if right and forfeiting an equivalent if wrong; hence, forfeit.
Hydrogalvanic: Pertaining to, produced by, or consisting of, electricity evolved by the action or use of fluids; as, hydrogalvanic currents.
Ha\u00fcynite: A blue isometric mineral, characteristic of some volcanic rocks.  It is a silicate of alumina, lime, and soda, with sulphate of lime.
Hobby: A strong, active horse, of a middle size, said to have been originally from Ireland; an ambling nag.
Homophonic: Originally, sounding alike; of the same pitch; unisonous; monodic.
Hepatogenic: Arising from the liver; due to a condition of the liver; as, hepatogenic jaundice.
Hyades: A cluster of five stars in the face of the constellation Taurus, supposed by the ancients to indicate the coming of rainy weather when they rose with the sun.
&Verbar;Hypinosis: A diminution in the normal amount of fibrin present in the blood.
Horror: A bristling up; a rising into roughness; tumultuous movement.
Heathendom: That part of the world where heathenism prevails; the heathen nations, considered collectively.
&Verbar;Hydr\u00e6mia: An abnormally watery state of the blood; anæmia.
Hiberno-Celtic: The native language of the Irish; that branch of the Celtic languages spoken by the natives of Ireland. Also adj.
High-handed: Overbearing; oppressive; arbitrary; violent; as, a high-handed act.
Hares-foot fern: A species of fern (Davallia Canariensis) with a soft, gray, hairy rootstock; -- whence the name.
Hollandaise sauce: A sauce consisting essentially of a seasoned emulsion of butter and yolk of eggs with a little lemon juice or vinegar.
Harshly: In a harsh manner; gratingly; roughly; rudely.
Hexad: An atom whose valence is six, and which can be theoretically combined with, substituted for, or replaced by, six monad atoms or radicals; as, sulphur is a hexad in sulphuric acid. Also used as an adjective.
&Verbar;Halones: Alternating transparent and opaque white rings which are seen outside the blastoderm, on the surface of the developing egg of the hen and other birds.
&Verbar;Heteromyaria: A division of bivalve shells, including the marine mussels, in which the two adductor muscles are very unequal. See Dreissena, and Illust. under Byssus.
handful: As much as the hand will grasp or contain.
haj: A pilgrimage to Mecca; every Muslim must make this journey at least once.
homelessness: the state or condition of having no home, especially of living in the streets.
Hindrance: The act of hindering, or the state of being hindered.
Hospitality: The act or practice of one who is hospitable; reception and entertainment of strangers or guests without reward, or with kind and generous liberality.
Hyaenidae: A natural family of canids comprising the hyenas.
Homobasidiomycetes: A category used in some classification systems for various basidiomycetous fungi including e.g. mushrooms and puffballs which are usually placed in the classes Gasteromycetes and Hymenomycetes.
Howel: To smooth; to plane; as, to howel a cask.
Harmonist: One of a religious sect, founded in Würtemburg in the last century, composed of followers of George Rapp, a weaver. They had all their property in common. In 1803, a portion of this sect settled in Pennsylvania and called the village thus established, Harmony.
Hallowmas: The feast of All Saints, or Allhallows.
Heavily: In a heavy manner; with great weight; as, to bear heavily on a thing; to be heavily loaded.
Hook-nosed: Having a hooked or aquiline nose.
Hairpin: A pin, usually forked, or of bent wire, for fastening the hair in place, -- used by women.
Hyperoxide: A compound having a relatively large percentage of oxygen; a peroxide.
Half-ray: A straight line considered as drawn from a center to an indefinite distance in one direction, the complete ray being the whole line drawn to an indefinite distance in both directions.
Hectoliter: A measure of liquids, containing a hundred liters; equal to a tenth of a cubic meter, nearly 261/2 gallons of wine measure, or 22.0097 imperial gallons. As a dry measure, it contains ten decaliters, or about 25/6 Winchester bushels.
Holoblast: an ovum composed entirely of germinal matter. See Meroblast.
Heptahedron: A solid figure with seven sides.
Hydrocephalic: Relating to, or connected with, hydrocephalus, or dropsy of the brain.
Heteronym: That which is heteronymous; a thing having a different name or designation from some other thing; -- opposed to homonym.
Honeydew melon: A type of winter melon (Cucumis melo inodorus) related to the muskmelon (Cucumis melo reticulatus), but having a smooth pale yellowish-green rind and sweet, juicy, light green flesh.  It is slightly ovoid in shape, commonly about 8 to 10 inches long on the long axis.
Homoousian: Of or pertaining to the Homoousians, or to the doctrines they held.
Hayrick: A heap or pile of hay, usually covered with thatch for preservation in the open air.
hardworking: habitually working diligently and for long hours.
horsebox: a conveyance (railroad car or trailer) for transporting racehorses.
&Verbar;Hordeolum: A small tumor upon the eyelid, resembling a grain of barley; a sty.
&Verbar;Hypapophysis: A process, or other element, of a vertebra developed from the ventral side of the centrum, as hæmal spines, and chevron bones.
homeothermal: having constant and relatively high body temperature; warm-blooded; same as homoiothermal; -- of birds and mammals.  Contrasted to poikilothermal.
Haughtiness: The quality of being haughty; disdain; arrogance.
Halter: To tie by the neck with a rope, strap, or halter; to put a halter on; to subject to a hangman's halter.
Hurtful: Tending to impair or damage; injurious; mischievous; occasioning loss or injury; as, hurtful words or conduct.
&Verbar;Hypotricha: A division of ciliated Infusoria in which the cilia cover only the under side of the body.
Hydrophid: Any sea snake of the genus Hydrophys and allied genera. These snakes are venomous, live upon fishes, and have a flattened tail for swimming.
Hazard: To try the chance; to encounter risk or danger.
honker: The nose; -- an informal terms used in the U. S.
Hybridize: To produce hybrid offspring; to interbreed; to cross.
Hydrostatics: The branch of science which relates to the pressure and equilibrium of nonelastic fluids, as water, mercury, etc.; the principles of statics applied to water and other liquids.
Heroship: The character or personality of a hero.
Huia bird: A New Zealand starling (Heteralocha acutirostris), remarkable for the great difference in the form and length of the bill in the two sexes, that of the male being sharp and straight, that of the female much longer and strongly curved.
Hellhound: A dog of hell; an agent of hell.
Hesitancy: The act of hesitating, or pausing to consider; slowness in deciding; vacillation; also, the manner of one who hesitates.
Hygeist: One skilled in hygiena; a hygienist.
Headstall: That part of a bridle or halter which encompasses the head.
Husbandable: Capable of being husbanded, or managed with economy.
halfway house: an inn or place of call midway on a journey.
Hamamelis: A genus of plants which includes the witch-hazel (Hamamelis Virginica), a preparation of which is used medicinally.
Home-bred: Bred at home; domestic; not foreign.
Helpmate: A helper; a companion; specifically, a wife.
Heartquake: Trembling of the heart; trepidation; fear.
Hexameter: Having six metrical feet, especially dactyls and spondees.
Hieroscopy: Divination by inspection of entrails of victims offered in sacrifice.
Hydroscope: An instrument designed to mark the presence of water, especially in air.
&Verbar;Heteropoda: An order of pelagic Gastropoda, having the foot developed into a median fin. Some of the species are naked; others, as Carinaria and Atlanta, have thin glassy shells.
Holmes: Sherlock Holmes, a fictitious detective in novels by A. Conan Doyle.
Hydroplane: Of a boat, to move through water while supported by hydroplanes{3} (see hydroplane{3}, above).
Hexoic: Pertaining to, or derived from, hexane; as, hexoic acid.
Hoop: A shout; a whoop, as in whooping cough.
Healthiness: The state of being healthy or healthful; freedom from disease.
homebound: Kept at home, usually due to illness; same as housebound.
Hook: To bend; to curve as a hook.
Hallucinate: To wander; to go astray; to err; to blunder; -- used of mental processes.
Hyalophane: A species of the feldspar group containing barium. See Feldspar.
Heliocentric: pertaining to the sun's center, or appearing to be seen from it; having, or relating to, the sun as a center; -- opposed to geocentrical.
Huswife: To manage with frugality; -- said of a woman.
&Verbar;Hydrozoa: The Acalephæ; one of the classes of cœlenterates, including the Hydroidea, Discophora, and Siphonophora.
hard-fought: Vigorously contested by both opponents; -- of contests; as, a hard-fought battle; a hard-fought primary election.
Headfirst: With the head foremost; -- of motion.
Heterodox: An opinion opposed to some accepted standard.
Hasheesh: A slightly acrid gum resin produced by the common hemp (Cannabis sativa), of the variety Indica, when cultivated in a warm climate; also, the tops of the plant, from which the resinous product is obtained.  It is narcotic, and has long been used in the East for its intoxicating effect.  The active psychoactive principle has been identified as tetrahydrocannabinol.   See Bhang, and Ganja.
Heaviness: The state or quality of being heavy in its various senses; weight; sadness; sluggishness; oppression; thickness.
Hoarding: A screen of boards inclosing a house and materials while builders are at work.
Headlight: A light, with a powerful reflector, placed at the front of a vehicle such as an automobile, truck, locomotive etc., to throw light on the road or track ahead of the vehicle at night, or in going through a dark tunnel; a headlamp.
Hot-short: Brittle when heated, esp. beyond a red heat; as, hot-short iron.
Hudsonia: A genus of small evergreen subshrubs of North America.
&Verbar;Heterocera: A division of Lepidoptera, including the moths, and hawk moths, which have the antennæ variable in form.
haptic: relating to or based on the sense of touch.
Historically: In the manner of, or in accordance with, history.
Hurdy-gurdy: A stringled instrument, lutelike in shape, in which the sound is produced by the friction of a wheel turned by a crank at the end, instead of by a bow, two of the strings being tuned as drones, while two or more, tuned in unison, are modulated by keys.
Housebote: Wood allowed to a tenant for repairing the house and for fuel. This latter is often called firebote. See Bote.
Hodgepodge: A mixed mass; a medley. See Hotchpot.
highly-developed: very complex or intricate; -- used especially of technology.
Half-deck: A shell of the genus Crepidula; a boat shell. See Boat shell.
haphazard: Determined by chance, whimsy, or guesswork; unplanned; aimless; random; -- used mostly of human actions.
helianthus: any plant of the genus Helianthus having large flower heads with dark disk florets and showy yellow rays.
Hypostyle: Resting upon columns; constructed by means of columns; -- especially applied to the great hall at Karnak.
Hagiographer: One of the writers of the hagiographa; a writer of lives of the saints.
Housekeeper: One who occupies a house with his family; a householder; the master or mistress of a family.
Hebraist: One versed in the Hebrew language and learning.
hyperthyroidism: An abnormality of the thyroid gland characterized by the pathologically excessive production of thyroid hormones; -- also, the resulting condition characterized by increased metabolism, weight loss, rapid heart rate, high blood pressure, an enlarged thyroid gland and sometimes exophthalmos.  It leads to, and may be confirmed by, high plasma levels of triiodothyronine or thyroxin.
Huge: Very large; enormous; immense; excessive; -- used esp. of material bulk, but often of qualities, extent, etc.; as, a huge ox; a huge space; a huge difference.
Hamated: Hooked, or set with hooks; hamate.
Hybl\u00e6an: Pertaining to Hybla, an ancient town of Sicily, famous for its bees.
Haply: By hap, chance, luck, or accident; perhaps; it may be.
&Verbar;Heterosis: A figure of speech by which one form of a noun, verb, or pronoun, and the like, is used for another, as in the sentence: “What is life to such as me?”
Hydroid: Related to, or resembling, the hydra; of or pertaining to the Hydroidea.
Hebraic: Of or pertaining to the Hebrews, or to the language of the Hebrews.
Home: To one's home or country; as in the phrases, go home, come home, carry home.
Homodynamy: The homology of metameres. See Metamere.
Homeopathy: The art of curing, founded on resemblances; the theory and its practice that disease is cured (tuto, cito, et jucunde) by remedies which produce on a healthy person effects similar to the symptoms of the complaint under which the patient suffers, the remedies being usually administered in minute doses. This system was founded by Dr. Samuel Hahnemann, and is opposed to allopathy, or heteropathy.
Hylobate: Any species of the genus Hylobates; a gibbon, or long-armed ape. See Gibbon.
Heptyl: A compound radical, C7H15, regarded as the essential radical of heptane and a related series of compounds.
Haliotidae: A natural family of mollusks including the abalone (Haliotis).
Hydromantic: Of or pertaining to divination by water.
Harderian: A term applied to a lachrymal gland on the inner side of the orbit of many animals which have a third eyelid, or nictitating membrane. See Nictitating membrane, under Nictitate.
Hydrocarbostyril: A white, crystalline, nitrogenous hydrocarbon, C9H9NO, obtained from certain derivatives of cinnamic acid and closely related to quinoline and carbostyril.
Haulage: Act of hauling; as, the haulage of cars by an engine; charge for hauling.
Hausen: A large sturgeon (Acipenser huso syn. Huso huso) from the region of the Black Sea; also called Beluga.  It is sometimes twelve feet long, and provides the highest quality caviar.
Hookedness: The state of being bent like a hook; incurvation.
Helio-: A combining form from Gr. "h`lios the sun.
homburg: A felt hat with a crown that is creased lengthwise, and a brim that is slightly curled upward at the edge.
Hypnotist: A person who hypnotizes another, especially one who is professionally trained in the technique.
honky-tonk: Pertaining to or resembling a honky-tonk.
Hamper: A shackle; a fetter; anything which impedes.
halfhearted: Wanting in heart or spirit; ungenerous; unkind.
Hebraistically: In a Hebraistic sense or form.
Hedger: One who makes or mends hedges; also, one who hedges, as, in betting.
Helicine: Curled; spiral; helicoid; -- applied esp. to certain arteries of the penis.
Herpestes: A genus of carnivores including the mongooses.
Hendecane: A hydrocarbon, C11H24, of the paraffin series; -- so called because it has eleven atoms of carbon in each molecule. Called also endecane, undecane.
Heavenly: In a manner resembling that of heaven.
Heterogony: The condition of having two or more kinds of flowers, different as to the length of their stamens and pistils.
hemostat: a surgical instrument that stops bleeding by clamping the blood vessel.
Hygroscope: An instrument which shows whether there is more or less moisture in the atmosphere, without indicating its amount.
Happy: Favored by hap, luck, or fortune; lucky; fortunate; successful; prosperous; satisfying desire; as, a happy expedient; a happy effort; a happy venture; a happy omen.
Headnote: A note at the head of a page or chapter; in law reports, an abstract of a case, showing the principles involved and the opinion of the court.
Hardship: That which is hard to bear, as toil, privation, injury, injustice, etc.
Hatiora: A small genus of South American epiphytic or lithophytic cacti.
Harmaline: An alkaloid found in the plant Peganum harmala. It forms bitter, yellow salts.
Harlequinade: A play or part of a play in which the harlequin is conspicuous; the part of a harlequin.
Hanker: To long (for) with a keen appetite and uneasiness; to have a vehement desire; -- usually with for or after; as, to hanker after fruit; to hanker after the diversions of the town.
Hirundine: Like or pertaining to the swallows.
Hyposkeletal: Beneath the endoskeleton; hypaxial; as, the hyposkeletal muscles; -- opposed to episkeletal.
Hyoscine: An alkaloid found with hyoscyamine (with which it is also isomeric) in henbane, and extracted as a white, amorphous, semisolid substance.
High-pressure: Having or involving a pressure greatly exceeding that of the atmosphere; -- said of steam, air, water, etc., and of steam, air, or hydraulic engines, water wheels, etc.
Housekeeping: Domestic; used in a family; as, housekeeping commodities.
Hierarchism: The principles or authority of a hierarchy.
Hopeite: A hydrous phosphate of zinc in transparent prismatic crystals.
&Verbar;Haphtarah: One of the lessons from the Nebiim (or Prophets) read in the Jewish synagogue on Sabbaths, feast days, fasts, and the ninth of Ab, at the end of the service, after the parashoth, or lessons from the Law. Such a practice is evidenced in Luke iv.17 and Acts xiii.15.
Hamular: Hooked; hooklike; hamate; as, the hamular process of the sphenoid bone.
Hollander: A native or one of the people of Holland; a Dutchman.
Homomallous: Uniformly bending or curving to one side; -- said of leaves which grow on several sides of a stem.
Handsaw: A saw used with one hand.
Hippurite: A fossil bivalve mollusk of the genus Hippurites, of many species, having a conical, cup-shaped under valve, with a flattish upper valve or lid. Hippurites are found only in the Cretaceous rocks.
Heartsick: Sick at heart; extremely depressed in spirits; very despondent.
Heart: To form a compact center or heart; as, a hearting cabbage.
Homonym: A word having the same sound as another, but differing from it in meaning; as the noun bear and the verb bear.
Hydroxide: A hydrate; a substance containing hydrogen and oxygen, made by combining water with an oxide, and yielding water by elimination. The hydroxides are regarded as compounds of hydroxyl, united usually with basic element or radical; as, calcium hydroxide ethyl hydroxide.
Henotheism: Primitive religion in which each of several divinities is regarded as independent, and is worshiped without reference to the rest.
Hydrographer: One skilled in the hydrography; one who surveys, or draws maps or charts of, the sea, lakes, or other waters, with the adjacent shores; one who describes the sea or other waters.
Hypoarian: Of or pertaining to a hypoarion.
hypernymy: the relation of being superordinate or belonging to a higher (more abstract) rank or class.  Inverse of hyponymy.
Hornblende: The common black, or dark green or brown, variety of amphibole. (See Amphibole.) It belongs to the aluminous division of the species, and is also characterized by its containing considerable iron. Also used as a general term to include the whole species.
Hearts-ease: Ease of heart; peace or tranquillity of mind or feeling.
Hylophagous: Eating green shoots, as certain insects do.
hard-hitting: characterized by or full of force and vigor; forceful; as, a hard-hitting expose.
Hippophagous: Feeding on horseflesh; -- said of certain nomadic tribes, as the Tartars.
Hodiern: Of this day; belonging to the present day.
hyperventilate: to breathe rapidly and deeply; to breathe excessively; as, The mountain climber started to hyperventilate.
Highflier: One who is extravagant in pretensions, opinions, or manners; one who is highfaluting.
honoree: a recipient of honors in recognition of noteworthy accomplishments.  Correlative of honorer or conferrer.
Heretofore: Up to this time; hitherto; before; in time past.
Hypothecator: One who hypothecates or pledges anything as security for the repayment of money borrowed.
HQ: Headquarters, the place from which a commander performs the functions of command.
&Verbar;Humiri: A fragrant balsam obtained from Brazilian trees of the genus Humirium.
&Verbar;H\u00e6mocytotrypsis: A breaking up of the blood corpuscles, as by pressure, in distinction from solution of the corpuscles, or hæmocytolysis.
hassle: to repeatedly annoy; as, He is known to hassle his staff when he is overworked.
headlinese: The abbreviated writing style of headline writers.
Heritor: A proprietor or landholder in a parish.
heaume: a large medieval helmet supported on the shoulders; called also helm.
Hippocampus: A fabulous monster, with the head and fore quarters of a horse joined to the tail of a dolphin or other fish (Hippocampus brevirostris), -- seen in Pompeian paintings, attached to the chariot of Neptune.
Hiddenite: An emerald-green variety of spodumene found in North Carolina; lithia emerald, -- used as a gem.
Hamamelidaceae: A natural family of plants comprising the genera Hamamelis; Corylopsis; Fothergilla; Liquidambar; Parrotia; and other small genera.
Half-pike: A short pike, sometimes carried by officers of infantry, sometimes used in boarding ships; a spontoon.
Huntress: A woman who hunts or follows the chase; as, the huntress Diana.
hydroxymethyl: a methyl radical with a hydroxyl group replacing one of the hydrogen atoms.
Headman: A head or leading man, especially of a village community.
Ho: Halloo! attend! -- a call to excite attention, or to give notice of approach.
Hatching: A mode of execution in engraving, drawing, and miniature painting, in which shading is produced by lines crossing each other at angles more or less acute; -- called also crosshatching.
Hierolatry: The worship of saints or sacred things.
Ha: An exclamation denoting surprise, joy, or grief. Both as uttered and as written, it expresses a great variety of emotions, determined by the tone or the context. When repeated, ha, ha, it is an expression of laughter, satisfaction, or triumph, sometimes of derisive laughter; or sometimes it is equivalent to  “Well, it is so.”
Harrow: To pillage; to harry; to oppress.
Hardness: The quality or state of being hard, literally or figuratively.
Hederose: Pertaining to, or of, ivy; full of ivy.
Head-hunter: A member of any tribe or race of savages who have the custom of decapitating human beings and preserving their heads as trophies.  The Dyaks of Borneo are the most noted head-hunters.
Howitzer: A gun so short that the projectile, which was hollow, could be put in its place by hand; a kind of mortar.
hydroxyproline: A crystalline amino acid (C5H9NO3), a hydroxylated proline, obtained by hydrolysis of gelatin or collagen.  Chemically it is 4-hydroxy-L-proline.  It is classified as nonessential for growth in rats.
Helleborein: A poisonous glucoside accompanying helleborin in several species of hellebore, and extracted as a white crystalline substance with a bittersweet taste. It has a strong action on the heart, resembling digitalin.
Humped: Having a hump, as the back.
Hygrometer: An instrument for measuring the degree of moisture of the atmosphere.
Hydrodynamic: Pertaining to, or derived from, the dynamical action of water of a liquid; of or pertaining to water power.
Hatchway: A square or oblong opening in a deck or floor, affording passage from one deck or story to another; the entrance to a cellar.
Horsiness: The condition or quality of being a horse; that which pertains to a horse.
Hackamore: A halter consisting of a long leather or rope strap and headstall, -- used for leading or tieing a pack animal.
hot cross bun: A bun or cake marked with a cross of icing, and intended to be eaten on Good Friday; called also cross bun.
Hearsay: Report; rumor; fame; common talk; something heard from another.
&Verbar;Halysites: A genus of Silurian fossil corals; the chain corals. See Chain coral, under Chain.
Hyposulphuric: Pertaining to, or containing, sulphur in a lower state of oxidation than in the sulphuric compounds; as, hyposulphuric acid.
hostilities: a legal state created by a declaration of war and ended by official declaration, during which the international rules of war apply.
Hearing: The act or power of perceiving sound; perception of sound; the faculty or sense by which sound is perceived; as, my hearing is good.
Hig-taper: A plant of the genus Verbascum (Verbascum Thapsus); the common mullein. [Also high-taper and hag-taper.]
Haberdasher: A dealer in small wares, as tapes, pins, needles, and thread.
Hypog\u00e6ic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the peanut, or earthnut (Arachis hypogæa).
Hone: To sharpen on, or with, a hone; to rub on a hone in order to sharpen; as, to hone a razor.
Hetairism: A supposed primitive state of society, in which all the women of a tribe were held in common.
Hormonal: of, pertaining to, or affected by, hormones.
Horizon: The line which bounds that part of the earth's surface visible to a spectator from a given point; the apparent junction of the earth and sky.
Hybrid: Produced from the mixture of two genetically distinct strains; as, plants of hybrid nature.
Honk: To make a sound like the honk of a goose.
high road: The most ethical and honest method; -- used mostly in the phrase to take the high road (as in an election campaign).  Contrasted with low road.
Hosteler: The keeper of a hostel or inn.
Heteroousian: One of those Arians who held that the Son was of a different substance from the Father.
Hyperphysical: Above or transcending physical laws; supernatural.
hallucinogenic: capable of producing hallucinations; as, LSD is a powerful hallucinogenic drug.
Homoplastic: Of or pertaining to homoplasty; as, homoplasticorgans; homoplastic forms.
Halenia: A genus of herbs of Eurasia and the Americas: spurred gentians.
Hank: To fasten with a rope, as a gate.
Haunter: One who, or that which, haunts.
Hang: The manner in which one part or thing hangs upon, or is connected with, another; as, the hang of a scythe.
Hypo-: A prefix signifying a less quantity, or a low state or degree, of that denoted by the word with which it is joined, or position under or beneath.
Hydric: Pertaining to, or containing, hydrogen; as, hydric oxide.
Harridan: A worn-out strumpet; a vixenish woman; a hag.
Haunted: Inhabited by, or subject to the visits of, apparitions; frequented by a ghost.
Homeling: A person or thing belonging to a home or to a particular country; a native; as, a word which is a homeling.
Hardihood: Boldness, united with firmness and constancy of mind; bravery; intrepidity; also, audaciousness; impudence.
Handspike: A bar or lever, generally of wood, used in a windlass or capstan, for heaving anchor, and, in modified forms, for various purposes.
Hypermetrical: Having a redundant syllable; exceeding the common measure.
Hydrocyanide: A compound of hydrocyanic acid with a base; -- distinguished from a cyanide, in which only the cyanogen so combines.
Hellier: One who heles or covers; hence, a tiler, slater, or thatcher.
Hugueninia: A genus having only one species, the tansy-leaved rocket.
Holosteric: Wholly solid; -- said of a barometer constructed of solid materials to show the variations of atmospheric pressure without the use of liquids, as the aneroid.
&Verbar;Hyperpyrexia: A condition of excessive fever; an elevation of temperature in a disease, in excess of the limit usually observed in that disease.
Holostomatous: Having an entire aperture; -- said of many univalve shells.
Hanger-on: One who hangs on, or sticks to, a person, place, or service; a dependent; one who adheres to others' society longer than he is wanted.
Hedgehog: A small European insectivore (Erinaceus Europæus), and other allied species of Asia and Africa, having the hair on the upper part of its body mixed with prickles or spines. It is able to roll itself into a ball so as to present the spines outwardly in every direction. It is nocturnal in its habits, feeding chiefly upon insects.
Heeltool: A tool used by turners in metal, having a bend forming a heel near the cutting end.
Humoralism: The state or quality of being humoral.
heartwarming: causing gladness and pleasure; -- used mostly of the actions of people, and sometimes of animals; as, Is there a sight more heart-warming than a family reunion?.
Household: Belonging to the house and family; domestic; as, household furniture; household affairs.
Huffish: Disposed to be blustering or arrogant; petulant.
Heterodoxy: An opinion or doctrine, or a system of doctrines, contrary to some established standard of faith, as the Scriptures, the creed or standards of a church, etc.; heresy.
Hair-salt: A variety of native Epsom salt occurring in silky fibers.
Hindustan: northern region of India where Hinduism predominates.
Holophote: A lamp with lenses or reflectors to collect the rays of light and throw them in a given direction; -- used in lighthouses.
Hurdle: To hedge, cover, make, or inclose with hurdles.
Hinny: A term of endearment; darling; -- corrupted from honey.
HN: a colorless explosive liquid that is volatile, poisonous, and foul-smelling.
Heptone: A liquid hydrocarbon, C7H10, of the valylene series.
Historiography: The art of employment of an historiographer.
Heterogynous: Having females very unlike the males in form and structure; -- as certain insects, the males of which are winged, and the females wingless.
Hylicist: A philosopher who treats chiefly of matter; one who adopts or teaches hylism.
Hard-visaged: Of a harsh or stern countenance; hard-featured.
Hectocotylized: Changed into a hectocotylus; having a hectocotylis.
Havoc: A cry in war as the signal for indiscriminate slaughter.
Hankey-pankey: Professional cant; the chatter of conjurers to divert attention from their tricks; hence, jugglery.
Hector: To play the bully; to bluster; to be turbulent or insolent.
Huswifely: Like a huswife; capable; economical; prudent.
Herdbook: A book containing the list and pedigrees of one or more herds of choice breeds of cattle; -- also called herd record, or herd register.
Heartily: From the heart; with all the heart; with sincerity.
Harpings: The fore parts of the wales, which encompass the bow of a vessel, and are fastened to the stem.
