handbell: a bell that is held in the hand.
he-huckleberry: A deciduous much-branched shrub (Lyonia ligustrina) with dense downy panicles of small bell-shaped white flowers.
Hairy: Bearing or covered with hair; made of or resembling hair; rough with hair; hirsute.
High: To rise; as, the sun higheth.
Hood molding: A projecting molding over the head of an arch, forming the outermost member of the archivolt; -- called also hood mold.
Handle: That part of vessels, instruments, etc., which is held in the hand when used or moved, as the haft of a sword, the knob of a door, the bail of a kettle, etc.
Hairdresser: One who dresses or cuts hair; a barber.
Hypostatize: To make into, or regarded as, a separate and distinct substance.
Hoodwink: To blind by covering the eyes.
Hot-headed: quickly and easily aroused to anger; fiery; violent; rash; hasty; impetuous; vehement; as, a hot-headed commander.
Hippocrene: A fountain on Mount Helicon in Bœotia, fabled to have burst forth when the ground was struck by the hoof of Pegasus. Also, its waters, which were supposed to impart poetic inspiration.
Hastiness: The quality or state of being hasty; haste; precipitation; rashness; quickness of temper.
hander: One who hands over or transmits; a conveyer in succession.
A prefix used in the names of British warships, meaning His Majesty's Ship or Her Majesty's Ship; as, H. M. S. Pinafore.
Hapless: Without hap or luck; luckless; unfortunate; unlucky; unhappy; as, hapless youth; hapless maid.
holier-than-thou: being excessively or hypocritically pious while condemning others as being less virtuous than oneself.
Hygiology: A treatise on, or the science of, the preservation of health.
Humble: To bring low; to reduce the power, independence, or exaltation of; to lower; to abase; to humilate.
&Verbar;Hymenomycetes: One of the great divisions of fungi, containing those species in which the hymenium is completely exposed.
handicap: An allowance of a certain amount of time or distance in starting, granted in a race to the competitor possessing inferior advantages; or an additional weight or other hindrance imposed upon the one possessing superior advantages, in order to equalize, as much as possible, the chances of success; as, the handicap was five seconds, or ten pounds, and the like.
Hunt: The act or practice of chasing wild animals; chase; pursuit; search.
Hyponasty: Downward convexity, or convexity of the inferior surface.
Hamshackle: To fasten (an animal) by a rope binding the head to one of the fore legs; as, to hamshackle a horse or cow; hence, to bind or restrain; to curb.
Hyo-: A prexif used in anatomy, and generally denoting connection with the hyoid bone or arch; as, hyoglossal, hyomandibular, hyomental, etc.
Humifuse: Spread over the surface of the ground; procumbent.
&Verbar;Hypoderma: A layer of tissue beneath the epidermis in plants, and performing the physiological function of strengthening the epidermal tissue. In phanerogamous plants it is developed as collenchyma.
Homeopathically: According to the practice of homeopathy.
Hyssop: A plant (Hyssopus officinalis). The leaves have an aromatic smell, and a warm, pungent taste.
Hircine: Goatlike; of or pertaining to a goat or the goats.
&Verbar;Homunculus: A little man; a dwarf; a manikin.
hemophilic: of, pertaining to, characteristic of, or afflicted with hemophilia; hemophiliac.
Hellbroth: A composition for infernal purposes; a magical preparation.
Heriotable: Subject to the payment of a heriot.
&Verbar;Hautpas: A raised part of the floor of a large room; a platform for a raised table or throne. See Dais.
Half-tone: Having, consisting of, or pertaining to, half tones;
hoofer: a professional dancer, especially a tap dancer.
Harness: To dress in armor; to equip with armor for war, as a horseman; to array.
High-hoe: The European green woodpecker or yaffle.
housefather: a man in charge of children in an institution.
Hominidae: The natural family of primates including modern man and the extinct immediate ancestors of man.
hitless: Having no hits scored; -- of a baseball game (or the pitching) in which a pitcher allows the opponent no hits; as, a hitless game.
Hydrosulphurous: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by the reduction of sulphurous acid. See Hyposulphurous acid, under Hyposulphurous.
hardheaded: Having sound judgment; sagacious; shrewd; practical and pragmatic.
Hydrotropic: Turning or bending towards moisture, as roots.
Hicksite: A member or follower of the “liberal” party, headed by Elias Hicks, which, because of a change of views respecting the divinity of Christ and the Atonement, seceded from the conservative portion of the Society of Friends in the United States, in 1827.
Hyperion: The god of the sun; in the later mythology identified with Apollo, and distinguished for his beauty.
Hoven: Affected with the disease called hoove; as, hoven cattle.
Haugh: A low-lying meadow by the side of a river.
Hallier: A kind of net for catching birds.
Hackbolt: The greater shearwater or hagdon. See Hagdon.
Huckleberry: The edible black or dark blue fruit of several species of the American genus Gaylussacia, shrubs nearly related to the blueberries (Vaccinium), and formerly confused with them.  The commonest huckelberry comes from Gaylussacia resinosa.
Hypothecation: The act or contract by which property is hypothecated; a right which a creditor has in or to the property of his debtor, in virtue of which he may cause it to be sold and the price appropriated in payment of his debt. This is a right in the thing, or jus in re.
Hospitate: To receive with hospitality; to lodge as a guest.
halfpence: an English coin worth half a penny; -- no longer minted.
Husband: To direct and manage with frugality; to use or employ to good purpose and the best advantage; to spend, apply, or use, with economy.
Hippa: A genus of marine decapod crustaceans, which burrow rapidly in the sand by pushing themselves backward; -- called also bait bug. See Illust. under Anomura.
Hydrometry: The art of determining the specific gravity of liquids, and thence the strength of spirituous liquors, saline solutions, etc.
house-raising: A gathering for the construction of a house by a group of neighbors, usually in a rural community, and sometimes accomplished in a single day; similar to a barn-raising.
Hadji: A Mohammedan who has made a pilgrimage to Mecca; -- used among Orientals as a respectful salutation or a title of honor.
Hedge: To shelter one's self from danger, risk, duty, responsibility, etc., as if by hiding in or behind a hedge; to skulk; to slink; to shirk obligations.
Halfer: One who possesses or gives half only; one who shares.
Homage: To pay reverence to by external action.
high-water: Pertaining to water at its highest achieved level; of or pertaining to high water; as, the high-water marks on the walls after a flood.
hospitalisation insurance: A form of medical insurance that pays for all or part of the fees for a person's residence and treatment in a hospital.
Heddle: To draw (the warp thread) through the heddle-eyes, in weaving.
Hopeless: Destitute of hope; having no expectation of good; despairing.
Hippopathology: The science of veterinary medicine; the pathology of the horse.
Hair-brown: Of a clear tint of brown, resembling brown human hair. It is composed of equal proportions of red and green.
hashmark: an insignia worn on the uniform to indicate years of service.
H\u00e6moscope: An instrument devised by Hermann, for regulating and measuring the thickness of a layer of blood for spectroscopic examination.
homebody: a person who seldom goes anywhere; one not given to wandering or travel.
harpullia: any of various tree of the genus Harpullia.
homeostatic: Of or pertaining to homeostasis; exhibiting homeostasis.
Handcuff: To apply handcuffs to; to manacle.
Hoolock: A small black gibbon (Hylobates hoolock), found in the mountains of Assam.
Hard-fisted: Having hard or strong hands; as, a hard-fisted laborer.
Hereford: One of a breed of cattle originating in Herefordshire, England. The Herefords are good working animals, and their beef-producing quality is excellent.
Hsien: An administrative subdivision of a fu, or department, or of an independent chow; also, the seat of government of such a district.
Helmsman: The man at the helm; a steersman.
&Verbar;Holostraca: A division of phyllopod Crustacea, including those that are entirely covered by a bivalve shell.
Hierophant: The presiding priest who initiated candidates at the Eleusinian mysteries;
hatpin: a long sturdy pin used by women to secure a hat to their hair.
Hardener: One who, or that which, hardens; specif., one who tempers tools.
handlock: a metal loop that can be locked around the wrist, usually used in pairs; a handcuff.
Heritage: That which is inherited, or passes from heir to heir; inheritance.
Hydrogenium: Hydrogen; -- called also in view of its supposed metallic nature.
Hardened: Made hard, or harder, or compact; made unfeeling or callous; made obstinate or obdurate; confirmed in error or vice.
Height: The condition of being high; elevated position.
heinie: The buttocks; -- a word used with children.
Hobnailed: See with hobnails, as a shoe.
Head: To originate; to spring; to have its source, as a river.
Hydriodic: Pertaining to, or derived from, hydrogen and iodine; -- said of an acid (HI) produced by the combination of these elements.
Heam: The afterbirth or secundines of a beast.
Heat: Heated; as, the iron though heat red-hot.
Heterophyllous: Having leaves of more than one shape on the same plant.
Hear: To have the sense or faculty of perceiving sound.
Herpetotomy: The anatomy or dissection of reptiles.
Heap: To collect in great quantity; to amass; to lay up; to accumulate; -- usually with up; as, to heap up treasures.
Homogenesis: That method of reproduction in which the successive generations are alike, the offspring, either animal or plant, running through the same cycle of existence as the parent; gamogenesis; -- opposed to heterogenesis.
high-stepping: having or moving with a high step; as, a high-stepping horse.
housebroken: trained to urinate and defecate outside or in a special place, such as a litter box; as, housebroken pets; -- of pet animals.
Hubble-bubble: A tobacco pipe, so arranged that the smoke passes through water, making a bubbling noise, whence its name. In India, the bulb containing the water is often a cocoanut shell.  It is a simple type of hookah.
Hornblendic: Composed largely of hornblende; resembling or relating to hornblende.
Hortatory: Giving exhortation or advise; encouraging; exhortatory; inciting; as, a hortatory speech.
Helvine: A mineral of a yellowish color, consisting chiefly of silica, glucina, manganese, and iron, with a little sulphur.
Histogenesis: The formation and development of organic tissues; histogeny; -- the opposite of histolysis.
Hamster: A small European rodent (Cricetus frumentarius).  It is remarkable for having a pouch on each side of the jaw, under the skin, and for its migrations.  Hamsters are commonly kept as a pets.
Hyacinthine: Belonging to the hyacinth; resembling the hyacinth; in color like the hyacinth.
Handyfight: A fight with the hands; boxing.
Holometabolic: Having a complete metamorphosis; -- said of certain insects, as the butterflies and bees.
&Verbar;Hauteur: Haughty manner or spirit; haughtiness; pride; arrogance.
Home-driven: Driven to the end, as a nail; driven close.
Horsewoman: A woman who rides on horseback.
Heckerism: The teaching of Isaac Thomas Hecker (1819-88), which interprets Catholicism as promoting human aspirations after liberty and truth, and as the religion best suited to the character and institutions of the American people.
Hydrophytology: The branch of botany which treats of water plants.
Horsetail: A leafless plant, with hollow and rushlike stems. It is of the genus Equisetum, and is allied to the ferns. See Illust. of Equisetum.
Hibernation: The act or state of hibernating.
hominian: Any animal of the family Hominidae, including modern man as well as extinct species of the genera Homo and Australopithecus.
Hague Tribunal: The permanent court of arbitration created by the “International Convention for the Pacific Settle of International Disputes.”, adopted by the International Peace Conference of 1899. It is composed of persons of known competency in questions of international law, nominated by the signatory powers. From these persons an arbitration tribunal is chosen by the parties to a difference submitted to the court. On the failure of the parties to agree directly on the arbitrators, each chooses two arbitrators, an umpire is selected by them, by a third power, or by two powers selected by the parties.
Hallucal: Of or pertaining to the hallux.
Hippophagy: The act or practice of feeding on horseflesh.
Hexyl: A univalent organic radical, C6H13-, regarded as the essential residue of hexane, and a related series of compounds.
H\u00e6mal: Pertaining to the blood or blood vessels; also, ventral. See Hemal.
Hauerite: Native sulphide of manganese, a reddish brown or brownish black mineral.
Haymaker: One who cuts and cures hay.
&Verbar;Hydrina: The group of hydroids to which the fresh-water hydras belong.
houseman: an advanced student or graduate in medicine gaining supervised practical experience in a hospital or other medical institution.
Humoral: Pertaining to, or proceeding from, the humors; as, a humoral fever.
Hyaline: A poetic term for the sea or the atmosphere.
Half-mast: A point some distance below the top of a mast or staff; as, a flag a half-mast (a token of mourning, etc.).
&Verbar;Hemimetabola: Those insects which have an incomplete metamorphosis.
Heliotropism: The phenomenon of turning toward the light, seen in many leaves and flowers.
Hammerkop: A bird of the Heron family; the umber.
Housebreaking: The act of breaking open and entering, with a felonious purpose, the dwelling house of another, whether done by day or night. See Burglary, and To break a house, under Break.
Hittorf rays: Rays (chiefly cathode rays) developed by the electric discharge in Hittorf tubes.
Hill: To surround with earth; to heap or draw earth around or upon; as, to hill corn.
Hemiglyph: The half channel or groove in the edge of the triglyph in the Doric order.
Hydro-extractor: An apparatus for drying anything, as yarn, cloth, sugar, etc., by centrifugal force; a centrifugal.
Haranguer: One who harangues, or is fond of haranguing; a declaimer.
handled: fitted with or having having a handle; as, a handled magnifying glass is easier to use.  Opposite of handleless.
Hungarian: Of or pertaining to Hungary or to the people of Hungary.
Heterochromous: Having the central florets of a flower head of a different color from those of the circumference.
Hostage: A person given as a pledge or security for the performance of the conditions of a treaty or stipulations of any kind, on the performance of which the person is to be released.
Haslet: The edible viscera, as the heart, liver, etc., of a beast, esp. of a hog.
Heroicomic: Combining the heroic and the ludicrous; denoting high burlesque; as, a heroicomic poem.
Humpbacked salmon: A small salmon (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha) which ascends the rivers of the Pacific coast from California to Alaska, and also on the Asiatic side. In the breeding season the male has a large dorsal hump and distorted jaws.
Halieutics: A treatise upon fish or the art of fishing; ichthyology.
Heart-whole: Having the heart or affections free; not in love.
handler: one who trains or exhibits animals.
Hatch-boat: A vessel whose deck consists almost wholly of movable hatches; -- used mostly in the fisheries.
Habitude: Habitual attitude; usual or accustomed state with reference to something else; established or usual relations.
&Verbar;Hyalea: A pteropod of the genus Cavolina. See Pteropoda, and Illustration in Appendix.
&Verbar;Huarache: A kind of low-heeled sandal with the upper consisting of interwoven leather strips; -- usually used in pl.
Highroad: A highway; a much traveled or main road.
Handcart: A cart drawn or pushed by hand.
&Verbar;Hyoganoidei: A division of ganoid fishes, including the gar pikes and bowfins.
&Verbar;Hyperpn\u0153a: Abnormal breathing, due to slightly deficient arterialization of the blood; -- in distinction from eupnœa. See Eupnœa, and Dispnœa.
Horny-handed: Having the hands horny and callous from labor.
Heterophemy: The unconscious saying, in speech or in writing, of that which one does not intend to say; -- frequently the very reverse of the thought which is present to consciousness.
Hepatic: Of or pertaining to the liver; as, hepatic artery; hepatic diseases.
Hypothec: A landlord's right, independently of stipulation, over the stocking (cattle, implements, etc.), and crops of his tenant, as security for payment of rent.
&Verbar;Herodiones: A division of wading birds, including the herons, storks, and allied forms. Called also Herodii.
Horning: Appearance of the moon when increasing, or in the form of a crescent.
Half-port: One half of a shutter made in two parts for closing a porthole.
henpeck: To bother persistently with trivial complaints; to subject to petty authority; -- said of a woman who thus treats her male companion, especially of wives who thus dominate their husbands. Commonly used in the past participle (often adjectively); as, henpecked for years, he finally left her.
Half-heard: Imperfectly or partly heard; not heard to the end.
Hyperodontidae: A natural family of cetaceans comprising the beaked whales; in some, especially former, classifications it included in the family Physeteridae.
Hunger-starve: To starve with hunger; to famish.
Hindbrain: The posterior of the three principal divisions of the brain, including the epencephalon and metencephalon. Sometimes restricted to the epencephalon only.
Homogamous: Having all the flowers alike; -- said of such composite plants as Eupatorium, and the thistels.
Hilling: The act or process of heaping or drawing earth around plants.
Hyperbolic: Belonging to the hyperbola; having the nature of the hyperbola.
Headline: The line at the head or top of a page.
Hump: To form into a hump; to make hump-shaped; to hunch; -- often with up.
Heelpath: The bank of a canal opposite, and corresponding to, that of the towpath; berm.
Hunt-counter: A worthless dog that runs back on the scent; a blunderer.
Holocentridae: A natural family of fish including the squirrelfishes and soldierfishes.
hard-to-please: Requiring great patience and effort and skill; demanding; -- of persons.  Opposite of undemanding.
hand-me-down: An outgrown garment given to one person after use by another; -- usually transferred between members of a family or close friends; as, because she was the youngest of four girls, the clothes she wore were always hand-me-downs.
Hoodoo: A natural rock pile or pinnacle of fantastic shape.
Humph: An exclamation denoting surprise, or contempt, doubt, etc.
Hussar: Originally, one of the national cavalry of Hungary and Croatia; now, one of the light cavalry of European armies.
Herborize: To form the figures of plants in; -- said in reference to minerals. See Arborized.
Hyetography: The branch of physical science which treats of the geographical distribution of rain.
Heavenize: To render like heaven or fit for heaven.
Horrisonous: Sounding dreadfully; uttering a terrible sound.
High-energy physics: the branch of particle physics which studies collisions of particles accelerated to such high energy that new fundamental particles are generated in the process.  The creation of new particles of very high energy is required to permit the study of the most fundamental relations between forms of matter, so as to understand the fundamental nature of matter.  The high energies also reproduce the high-temperature conditions at the earliest phase of the big bang, allowing generation of some data relevant to understanding the nature and evolution of the universe.
Holethnos: A parent stock or race of people, not yet divided into separate branches or tribes.
Horal: Of or pertaining to an hour, or to hours.
H\u00e6matoblast: One of the very minute, disk-shaped bodies found in blood with the ordinary red corpuscles and white corpuscles; a third kind of blood corpuscle, supposed by some to be an early stage in the development of the red corpuscles; -- called also blood plaque, and blood plate.
Hoddy: See Dun crow, under Dun, a.
Horsemint: A coarse American plant of the Mint family (Monarda punctata).
Hoit: To leap; to caper; to romp noisily.
homebuilder: someone who builds houses as a business.
hombre: an informal term for a youth or man.
Hubby: Full of hubs or protuberances; as, a road that has been frozen while muddy is hubby.
Heteronomy: Subordination or subjection to the law of another; political subjection of a community or state; -- opposed to autonomy.
HS2: Herpes simplex 2, a herpes virus that can cause genital herpes; also called type II Herpes.
Hypoblastic: Relating to, or connected with, the hypoblast; as, the hypoic sac.
Hogger: A stocking without a foot, worn by coal miners at work.
hoya: Any plant of the genus Hoya having fleshy leaves and usually nectariferous flowers.
Hungerer: One who hungers; one who longs.
Heterogenous: Of or pertaining to heterogenesis; heterogenetic.
Hogged: Broken or strained so as to have an upward curve between the ends. See Hog, v. i.
Headland: A cape; a promontory; a point of land projecting into the sea or other expanse of water.
Hottentot: One of a degraded and savage race of South Africa, with yellowish brown complexion, high cheek bones, and wooly hair growing in tufts.
Hame: One of the two curved pieces of wood or metal, in the harness of a draught horse, to which the traces are fastened. They are fitted upon the collar, or have pads fitting the horse's neck attached to them.
Hymn: To sing in praise or adoration.
Hidebound: Having the skin adhering so closely to the ribs and back as not to be easily loosened or raised; -- said of an animal.
Hierogrammatic: Written in, or pertaining to, hierograms; expressive of sacred writing.
Hematinometric: Relating to the measurement of the amount of hematin or hemoglobin contained in blood, or other fluids.
Hunting: The pursuit of game or of wild animals.
&Verbar;Helicotrema: The opening by which the two scalæ communicate at the top of the cochlea of the ear.
Heterotactous: Relating to, or characterized by, heterotaxy.
&Verbar;Hirundo: A genus of birds including the swallows and martins.
Histophyly: The tribal history of cells, a division of morphophyly.
Hogscore: A distance line drawn across the rink or course between the middle line and the tee.
Headstrong: Not easily restrained; ungovernable; obstinate; stubborn.
Hinder: To interpose obstacles or impediments; to be a hindrance.
Hyalotype: A photographic picture copied from the negative on glass; a photographic transparency.
Hover: To hang fluttering in the air, or on the wing; to remain in flight or floating about or over a place or object; to be suspended in the air above something.
Hornotine: A yearling; a bird of the year.
harassed: troubled persistently, especially with petty annoyances; as, harassed working mothers.
Heliochromy: The art of producing photographs in color.
Hindoostanee: Of or pertaining to the Hindoos or their language.
&Verbar;Hexapla: A collection of the Holy Scriptures in six languages or six versions in parallel columns; particularly, the edition of the Old Testament published by Origen, in the 3d century.
Hovel: To put in a hovel; to shelter.
Headboard: A board or boarding which marks or forms the head of anything; as, the headboard of a bed; the headboard of a grave.
H\u00e6mochromogen: A body obtained from hemoglobin, by the action of reducing agents in the absence of oxygen.
Hoopoe: A European bird of the genus Upupa (Upupa epops), having a beautiful crest, which it can erect or depress at pleasure, and a slender down-curving bill. Called also hoop, whoop. The name is also applied to several other species of the same genus and allied genera.
Hypnotic: Any agent that produces, or tends to produce, sleep; an opiate; a soporific; a narcotic.
harakiri: A ritual form of suicide, by slashing the abdomen, formerly practiced in Japan, and commanded by the government in the cases of disgraced officials; disembowelment; -- also written, but incorrectly, hari-kari.
Heliometry: The apart or practice of measuring the diameters of heavenly bodies, their relative distances, etc. See Heliometer.
Herpes zoster: same as shingles; -- a form of herpes caused by the varicella-zoster virus.
Homodromal: Running in the same direction; -- said of stems twining round a support, or of the spiral succession of leaves on stems and their branches.
Hallucination: The act of hallucinating; a wandering of the mind; error; mistake; a blunder.
Haustellate: Provided with a haustellum, or sucking proboscis.
Hydrate: To form into a hydrate; to combine with water.
Hemisection: A division along the mesial plane; also, one of the parts so divided.
Haruspicy: The art or practices of haruspices. See Aruspicy.
Hyalography: Art of writing or engraving on glass.
heavenliness: The state or quality of being heavenly.
Houseroom: Room or place in a house; as, to give any one houseroom.
Houndfish: Any small shark of the genus Galeus or Mustelus, of which there are several species, as the smooth houndfish (Galeus canis), of Europe and America; -- called also houndshark, and dogfish.
Heirship: The state, character, or privileges of an heir; right of inheriting.
Heroine: A woman of an heroic spirit.
Hydroferrocyanic: Pertaining to, or containing, or obtained from, hydrogen, ferrous iron, and cyanogen; as, hydroferrocyanic acid. See Ferrocyanic.
Horseweed: A composite plant (Erigeron Canadensis), which is a common weed.
Haruspice: A diviner of ancient Rome.  Same as Aruspice.
Horse-leech: A large blood-sucking leech (Hæmopsis vorax), of Europe and Northern Africa. It attacks the lips and mouths of horses.
hyalin: a glassy translucent material that occurs in hyaline cartilage or in certain skin conditions.
Hippocras: A cordial made of spiced wine, etc.
ham-fisted: not skillful in physical movement especially with the hands; clumsy; bungling; -- also used metaphorically of actions; as, ham-handed governmental interference.
Heteroplasm: An abnormal formation foreign to the economy, and composed of elements different from those are found in it in its normal condition.
Hypertrophic: Of or pertaining to hypertrophy; affected with, or tending to, hypertrophy.
hawkbill: A sea turtle (Eretmochelys imbricata), which yields the best quality of tortoise shell; -- called also caret.
Hurter: A butting piece; a strengthening piece, esp.: (Mil.) A piece of wood at the lower end of a platform, designed to prevent the wheels of gun carriages from injuring the parapet.
hard-wired: Contained within the circuitry of a computer or computer peripheral device, and not changeable by programming; -- of functions; as, error correction is hard-wired into the circuit of the disk drive, so it proceeds very rapidly.
Hippocratic: Of or pertaining to Hippocrates, or to his teachings.
Heptane: Any one of several isometric hydrocarbons, C7H16, of the paraffin series (nine are possible, four are known); -- so called because the molecule has seven carbon atoms. Specifically, a colorless liquid, found as a constituent of petroleum, in the tar oil of cannel coal, etc.
hacker: One who, or that which, hacks.
&Verbar;Hydronephrosis: An accumulation of urine in the pelvis of the kidney, occasioned by obstruction in the urinary passages.
Hybridizable: Capable of forming a hybrid, or of being subjected to a hybridizing process; capable of producing a hybrid by union with another species or stock.
Hydractinian: Any species or marine hydroids, of the genus Hydractinia and allied genera. These hydroids form, by their rootstalks, a firm, chitinous coating on shells and stones, and esp. on spiral shells occupied by hermit crabs. See Illust. of Athecata.
Hagdon: One of several species of sea birds of the genus Puffinus; esp., Puffinus major, the greater shearwarter, and Puffinus Stricklandi, the black hagdon or sooty shearwater; -- called also hagdown, haglin, and hag. See Shearwater.
Hermeneutics: The science of interpretation and explanation; exegesis; esp., that branch of theology which defines the laws whereby the meaning of the Scriptures is to be ascertained.
&Verbar;Hierapicra: A warming cathartic medicine, made of aloes and canella bark.
Hygrometric: Of or pertaining to hygrometry; made with, or according to, the hygrometer; as, hygrometric observations.
hemophiliac: of, pertaining to, characteristic of, or afflicted with hemophilia; hemophilic.
Harlech group: A minor subdivision at the base of the Cambrian system in Wales.
Homoiothermal: Maintaining a uniform body temperature, usually  above the ambient temperature; hæmatothermal; homothermic; warm-blooded; -- applied to warm-bodied animals such as birds and mammals, because they maintain a nearly uniform temperature in spite of the great variations in the surrounding air; in distinct from the cold-blooded (poikilothermal) animals, whose body temperature follows the variations in temperature of the surrounding medium.
hallucinate: To experience (something nonexistent) as an hallucination{2}.
Halfbeak: Any slender, marine fish of the genus Hemirhamphus, or of the family Hemiramphidae, having an elongated protruding lower jaw; -- called also balahoo.
Hendecagon: A plane figure of eleven sides and eleven angles.
Homodermic: Relating to homodermy; originating from the same germ layer.
Herpetic: Pertaining to, or resembling, the herpes; partaking of the nature of herpes; as, herpetic eruptions.
Hustle: To push or crows; to force one's way; to move hustily and with confusion; a hurry.
Hydrotrope: A device for raising water by the direct action of steam; a pulsometer.
Heliogram: A message transmitted by a heliograph.
Hydrobilirubin: A body formed from bilirubin, identical with urobilin.
Hemautography: The obtaining of a curve similar to a pulse curve or sphygmogram by allowing the blood from a divided artery to strike against a piece of paper.
Hamfatter: A low-grade actor or performer; a ham.
Holometer: An instrument for making all kinds of angular measurements.
Hydrolysis: A chemical process causing the splitting of a chemical bond by the addition of the elements of water.  Where the bond which is split is not part of a ring structure, this process causes formation of two compounds from one compound plus water, as in the hydrolysis of the ester bonds of fats during saponification.
Hold: The act of holding, as in or with the hands or arms; the manner of holding, whether firm or loose; seizure; grasp; clasp; grip; possession; -- often used with the verbs take and lay.
Hierographic: Of or pertaining to sacred writing.
Hagiologist: One who treats of the sacred writings; a writer of the lives of the saints; a hagiographer.
Heirloom: Any furniture, movable, or personal chattel, which by law or special custom descends to the heir along with the inheritance; any piece of personal property that has been in a family for several generations.
Hatable: Capable of being, or deserving to be, hated; odious; detestable.
Hemadynamics: The principles of dynamics in their application to the blood; that part of science which treats of the motion of the blood.
Hazardable: Liable to hazard or chance; uncertain; risky.
Hades: The nether world (according to classical mythology, the abode of the shades, ruled over by Hades or Pluto); the invisible world; the grave.
Heterophony: An abnormal state of the voice.
Hydantoin: A derivative of urea, C3H4N2O2, obtained from allantion, as a white, crystalline substance, with a sweetish taste; -- called also glycolyl urea.
Hospice: A convent or monastery which is also a place of refuge or entertainment for travelers on some difficult road or pass, as in the Alps; as, the Hospice of the Great St. Bernard.
Hungary: A country in Central Europe, formerly a part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire.
hooch: an illicitly distilled (and usually inferior) alcoholic liquor.
Hyoglossal: Pertaining to or connecting the tongue and hyodean arch; as, the hyoglossal membrane.
Hymnology: The hymns or sacred lyrics composed by authors of a particular country or period; as, the hymnology of the eighteenth century; also, the collective body of hymns used by any particular church or religious body; as, the Anglican hymnology.
home-schooled: Receiving or having received formal education, especially primary or secondary education, at home rather than in a school.  The instruction at home may be accomplished by parents or by professionals who come to the home; as, home-schooled students often get higher test scores than those educated in schools.
Helotism: The condition of the Helots or slaves in Sparta; slavery.
Historian: A writer of history; a chronicler; an annalist.
Herbivorous: Eating plants; of or pertaining to the Herbivora.
Hertz: a unit of frequency equal to one cycle per second; it is abbreviated Hz.  It is commonly used to specify the frequency of radio waves, and also the clock frequencies in digital computers.  For these applications, kilohertz and megahertz are the most commonly used units, derived from hertz.
Hypochlorous: Pertaining to, or derived from, chlorine having a valence lower than in chlorous compounds.
Helix: A nonplane curve whose tangents are all equally inclined to a given plane. The common helix is the curve formed by the thread of the ordinary screw. It is distinguished from the spiral, all the convolutions of which are in the plane.
Hylism: A theory which regards matter as the original principle of evil.
Hypsiprymnodon: A genus of marsupials comprising the musk kangaroos.
Hexylene: A colorless, liquid hydrocarbon, C6H12, of the ethylene series, produced artificially, and found as a natural product of distillation of certain coals; also, any one several isomers of hexylene proper. Called also hexene.
Harmost: A city governor or prefect appointed by the Spartans in the cities subjugated by them.
hediondilla: A desert shrub (Larrea tridentata) of the Southwestern U.S. and Northern Mexico having persistent resinous aromatic foliage and small yellow flowers.
haoma: A leafless East Indian vine (Sarcostemma acidum); its sour milky juice was formerly used to make an intoxicating drink.
&Verbar;Hospodar: A title borne by the princes or governors of Moldavia and Wallachia before those countries were united as Rumania.
Harlock: Probably a corruption either of charlock or hardock.
&Verbar;Hydrus: A constellation of the southern hemisphere, near the south pole.
&Verbar;Hydrocorallia: A division of Hydroidea, including those genera that secrete a stony coral, as Millepora and Stylaster. Two forms of zooids in life project from small pores in the coral and resemble those of other hydroids. See Millepora.
&Verbar;Hemicerebrum: A lateral half of the cerebrum.
Harmonometer: An instrument for measuring the harmonic relations of sounds. It is often a monochord furnished with movable bridges.
Hypermetamorphosis: A kind of metamorphosis, in certain insects, in which the larva itself undergoes remarkable changes of form and structure during its growth.
Hogcote: A shed for swine; a sty.
Hydromica: A variety of potash mica containing water. It is less elastic than ordinary muscovite.
Havelock: A light cloth covering for the head and neck, used by soldiers as a protection from sunstroke.
Hot-head: A violent, passionate person; a hasty or impetuous person; as, the rant of a hot-head.
Hallucinator: One whose judgment and acts are affected by hallucinations; one who errs on account of his hallucinations.
Humanitarianism: The distinctive tenet of the humanitarians in denying the divinity of Christ; also, the whole system of doctrine based upon this view of Christ.
Housecarl: A household servant; also, one of the bodyguard of King Canute.
Hispanic: Of or pertaining to Spain or its language; as, Hispanic words.
Harping: Pertaining to the harp; as, harping symphonies.
Honeycombed: Formed or perforated like a honeycomb.
Hard grass: A name given to several different grasses, especially to the Roltböllia incurvata, and to the species of Ægilops, from one of which it is contended that wheat has been derived.
Humanly: In a human manner; after the manner of men; according to the knowledge or wisdom of men; as, the present prospects, humanly speaking, promise a happy issue.
&Verbar;Haustellata: An artificial division of insects, including all those with a sucking proboscis.
heavyhearted: feeling or affected by sorrow or unhappiness.
&Verbar;Hypoptilum: An accessory plume arising from the posterior side of the stem of the contour feathers of many birds; -- called also aftershaft. See Illust. of Feather.
Hymnologist: A composer or compiler of hymns; one versed in hymnology.
Hawfinch: The common European grosbeak (Coccothraustes vulgaris); -- called also cherry finch, and coble.
Hoveling: A method of securing a good draught in chimneys by covering the top, leaving openings in the sides, or by carrying up two of the sides higher than the other two.
&Verbar;Homarus: A genus of decapod Crustacea, including the common lobsters.
Homodemic: A morphological term signifying development, in the case of multicellular organisms, from the same unit deme or unit of the inferior orders of individuality.
Hennotannic: Pertaining to, or designating, a brown resinous substance resembling tannin, and extracted from the henna plant; as, hennotannic acid.
Hant: A contraction of have not, or has not, used in illiterate speech. In the United States the commoner spelling is hain't.
Halleluiah: Praise ye Jehovah; praise ye the Lord; -- an exclamation used chiefly in songs of praise or thanksgiving to God, and as an expression of gratitude or adoration.
Handmaid: A maid that waits at hand; a female servant or attendant.
Homology: The quality of being homologous; correspondence; relation; as, the homologyof similar polygons.
honeycreeper: Any of a number of small to medium-sized finches of the Hawaiian islands belonging to the subfamily Drepanidae.
Hurtless: Doing no injury; harmless; also, unhurt; without injury or harm.
Hyperoodon: The mammalian genus comprised of the bottle-nosed whales.
Hoazin: A remarkable South American bird (Opisthocomus cristatus); the crested touraco. By some zoölogists it is made the type of a distinct order (Opisthocomi).
Hypocycloid: A curve traced by a point in the circumference of a circle which rolls on the concave side in the fixed circle.  Cf. Epicycloid, and Trochoid.
&Verbar;Habeas corpus: A writ having for its object to bring a party before a court or judge; especially, one to inquire into the cause of a person's imprisonment or detention by another, with the view to protect the right to personal liberty; also, one to bring a prisoner into court to testify in a pending trial.
&Verbar;Hyporadius: One of the barbs of the hypoptilum, or aftershaft of a feather. See Feather.
Horologe: A servant who called out the hours.
Hellene: A native of either ancient or modern Greece; a Greek.
hippeastrum: An amaryllis of tropical America (Hippeastrum puniceum) often cultivated as a houseplant for its showy white to red flowers.
Hendecatoic: Undecylic; pertaining to, or derived from, hendecane; as, hendecatoic acid.
H\u00e6matosac: A vascular sac connected, beneath the brain, in many fishes, with the infundibulum.
Hale: To pull; to drag; to haul.
Hachure: A short line used in drawing and engraving, especially in shading and denoting different surfaces, as in map drawing. See Hatching.
Hogweed: A common weed (Ambrosia artemisiæge). See Ambrosia, 3.
Hairspring: The slender recoil spring which regulates the motion of the balance in a timepiece.
Herby: Having the nature of, pertaining to, or covered with, herbs or herbage.
Hall: A building or room of considerable size and stateliness, used for public purposes; as, Westminster Hall, in London.
Halo: To form, or surround with, a halo; to encircle with, or as with, a halo.
hoover: to clean with a vacuum cleaner.
Hydration: The act of becoming, or state of being, a hydrate.
Healthy: Being in a state of health; enjoying health; hale; sound; free from disease; as, a healthy child; a healthy plant.
Hatchet: A small ax with a short handle, to be used with one hand.
Hexactinellid: Having six-rayed spicules; belonging to the Hexactinellinæ.
Hatcher: One who hatches, or that which hatches; a hatching apparatus; an incubator.
Hole in the air: same as Air hole, above; an air pocket.
Hatchel: To draw through the teeth of a hatchel, as flax or hemp, so as to separate the coarse and refuse parts from the fine, fibrous parts.
Houseless: Destitute of the shelter of a house; shelterless; homeless; as, a houseless wanderer.
Homonomy: The homology of parts arranged on transverse axes.
Hypothetic: Characterized by, or of the nature of, an hypothesis; conditional; assumed without proof, for the purpose of reasoning and deducing proof, or of accounting for some fact or phenomenon.
Homologue: That which is homologous to something else; as, the corresponding sides, etc., of similar polygons are the homologues of each other; the members or terms of an homologous series in chemistry are the homologues of each other; one of the bones in the hand of man is the homologue of that in the paddle of a whale.
Hypophysial: Of or pertaining to the hypophysis; pituitary.
Heliostat: An instrument consisting of a mirror moved by clockwork, by which a sunbeam is made apparently stationary, by being steadily directed to one spot during the whole of its diurnal period; also, a geodetic heliotrope.
Headwater: The source and upper part of a stream; -- commonly used in the plural; as, the headwaters of the Missouri.
Hatting: The business of making hats; also, stuff for hats.
Hunnish: Of or pertaining to the Huns.
Hymnal: A collection of hymns; a hymn book.
Hotness: The quality or state of being hot.
highlight: The part of an image that has the most intense light.
Hoarsely: With a harsh, grating sound or voice.
Hyparterial: Situated below an artery; applied esp. to the branches of the bronchi given off below the point where the pulmonary artery crosses the bronchus.
&Verbar;Hyperopia: An abnormal condition of the eye in which, through shortness of the eyeball or fault of the refractive media, the rays of light come to a focus behind the retina, making vision for distant objects better than for near objects; farsightedness; -- called also hypermetropia.  Cf. Emmetropia.
Hyperboloid: Having some property that belongs to an hyperboloid or hyperbola.
Horticultural: Of or pertaining to horticulture, or the culture of gardens or orchards.
Herring: One of various species of fishes of the genus Clupea, and allied genera, esp. the common round or English herring (Clupea harengus) of the North Atlantic.  Herrings move in vast schools, coming in spring to the shores of Europe and America, where they are salted and smoked in great quantities.
Halfway: Equally distant from the extremes; situated at an intermediate point; midway; as, at the halfway mark.
Hippoboscidae: A natural family of winged or wingless dipterans: louse flies.
Hexahedron: A solid body of six sides or faces.
Hersillon: A beam with projecting spikes, used to make a breach impassable.
&Verbar;Hyoscyamus: A genus of poisonous plants of the Nightshade family; henbane.
Homilist: One who prepares homilies; one who preaches to a congregation.
housedog: a dog trained to guard a house.
Hectostere: A measure of solidity, containing one hundred cubic meters, and equivalent to 3531.66 English or 3531.05 United States cubic feet.
Hobnail: To tread down roughly, as with hobnailed shoes.
Hydrosphere: The aqueous vapor of the entire atmosphere.
handbuild: to make without a wheel; of pottery.
Hostility: State of being hostile; public or private enemy; unfriendliness; animosity.
Hulk: To take out the entrails of; to disembowel; as, to hulk a hare.
Heterodactylous: Having the first and second toes turned backward, as in the trogons.
Hybodont: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, an extinct genus of sharks (Hybodus), especially in the form of the teeth, which consist of a principal median cone with smaller lateral ones.
Hithe: A port or small haven; -- used in composition; as, Lambhithe, now Lambeth.
Hoppestere: An unexplained epithet used by Chaucer in reference to ships. By some it is defined as “dancing (on the wave)”; by others as “opposing,”  “warlike.”
Housing: A cover or cloth for a horse's saddle, as an ornamental or military appendage; a saddlecloth; a horse cloth; in plural, trappings.
Helicon: A mountain in Bœotia, in Greece, supposed by the Greeks to be the residence of Apollo and the Muses.
Heartstring: A nerve or tendon, supposed to brace and sustain the heart.
H: The seventh degree in the diatonic scale, being used by the Germans for B natural. See B.
Home-felt: Felt in one's own breast; inward; private.
Hydrobromic: Composed of hydrogen and bromine; as, hydrobromic acid.
&Verbar;Hieron: A consecrated place; esp., a temple.
Hatchery: A house for hatching fish, etc.
HS1: Herpes simplex 1, a herpes virus that causes oral herpes; also called type I Herpes.
honours: A university degree with honors; -- a term used in Great Britain.
homegrown: grown or produced at home or in a specific locality; -- of plants or animals.
&Verbar;Haminura: A large edible river fish (Erythrinus macrodon) of Guiana.
Hendecasyllabic: Pertaining to a line of eleven syllables.
Hydrometric: Of or pertaining to an hydrometer, or to the determination of the specific gravity of fluids.
Hellespont: A narrow strait between Europe and Asia, now called the Daradanelles. It connects the Ægean Sea and the sea of Marmora.
Habitation: The act of inhabiting; state of inhabiting or dwelling, or of being inhabited; occupancy.
Hangbird: The Baltimore oriole (Icterus galbula); -- so called because its nest is suspended from the limb of a tree. See Baltimore oriole.
Hound: To set on the chase; to incite to pursuit; as, to hounda dog at a hare; to hound on pursuers.
hushed-up: kept secret; -- used of reports; as, hushed-up stories sometimes leak out.
Hurds: The coarse part of flax or hemp; hards.
Hectorly: Resembling a hector; blustering; insolent; taunting.
Hackee: The chipmunk; also, the chickaree or red squirrel.
H\u00e6mad: Toward the hæmal side; on the hæmal side of; -- opposed to neurad.
Hubble Telescope: A large astromical optical telescope placed into orbit around the earth, from which, in the absence of absorption and distortion by the earth's atmosphere, clear high-resolution images of astronomical objects can be obtained in the visible, infrared, and ultraviolet wavelengths.  The telescope was launched into orbit on April 24, 1990.  Since then the telescope has taken thousands of images, many of them unique, recording never before seen astronomical phenomena.  Service missions were performed in 1993 and 1997, during which astronauts upgraded or replaced equipment on the telescope.  Link to Hubble Telescope Information.
Hydrosulphide: One of a series of compounds, derived from hydrogen sulphide by the replacement of half its hydrogen by a base or basic radical; as, potassium hydrosulphide, KSH. The hydrosulphides are analogous to the hydrates and include the mercaptans.
Hot-livered: Of an excitable or irritable temperament; irascible.
Hastings sands: The lower group of the Wealden formation; -- so called from its development around Hastings, in Sussex, England.
&Verbar;Hypanthium: A fruit consisting in large part of a receptacle, enlarged below the calyx, as in the Calycanthus, the rose hip, and the pear.
hemosiderosis: The accumulation of abnormal amounts of hemosiderin in the tisssues.  Several causes have been recognized.
Helve: To furnish with a helve, as an ax.
Heterography: That method of spelling in which the same letters represent different sounds in different words, as in the ordinary English orthography; e. g., g in get and in ginger.
hafnium: A metallic element of atomic number 72 present together with zirconium to the extent of 1% to 5% in zirconium minerals.  It is a poisonous, ductile metal with a brilliant silver luster, has an atomic weight of 178.49, and has a high melting point (2227° C).  It is used in nuclear reactors, and incandescent lamps as a scavenger of oxygen and nitrogen.  See also norium.
hand-picked: carefully selected; as, a hand-picked jury; the company's president groomed his hand-picked successor.
Houri: A nymph of paradise; -- so called by the Mohammedans.
&Verbar;Haustorium: One of the suckerlike rootlets of such plants as the dodder and ivy.
Hours: Goddess of the seasons, or of the hours of the day.
house-to-house: omitting no one; proceeding from the door of one house to that of the next; as, house-to-house canvassing.
Hyperoxygenated: Combined with a relatively large amount of oxygen; -- said of higher oxides.
honky: A white (caucasian) person; -- a term used by some African-Americans, intended to be disparaging and often taken as offensive.
hospitalise: To place (a person) in a hospital in order to receive medical treatment, for observation, or for rest.
Harlot: To play the harlot; to practice lewdness.
Hoveler: One who assists in saving life and property from a wreck; a coast boatman.
H\u00e6ma-: Combining forms indicating relation or resemblance to blood, association with blood; as, hæmapod, hæmatogenesis, hæmoscope.
Housewifery: The business of the mistress of a family; female management of domestic concerns.
Harbor: To lodge, or abide for a time; to take shelter, as in a harbor.
Haint: A contraction of have not or has not; as, I hain't, he hain't, we hain't.
High-stepper: A horse that moves with a high step or proud gait; hence, a person having a proud bearing.
Hydromechanics: That branch of physics which treats of the mechanics of liquids, or of their laws of equilibrium and of motion.
&Verbar;Holostomata: An artificial division of gastropods, including those that have an entire aperture.
Hexastyle: Having six columns in front; -- said of a portico or temple.
Hemin: A substance, in the form of reddish brown, microscopic, prismatic crystals, formed from dried blood by the action of strong acetic acid and common salt; -- called also Teichmann's crystals. Chemically, it is a hydrochloride of hematin.
Hern: A heron; esp., the common European heron.
Hypoplastron: The third lateral plate in the plastron of turtles; -- called also hyposternum.
Homotypal: Of the same type of structure; pertaining to a homotype; as, homotypal parts.
Hydranth: One of the nutritive zooids of a hydroid colony. Also applied to the proboscis or manubrium of a hydroid medusa. See Illust. of Hydroidea.
Halotrichite: An iron alum occurring in silky fibrous aggregates of a yellowish white color.
Helical: Of or pertaining to, or in the form of, a helix; spiral; as, a helical staircase; a helical spring.
Heteropathy: That mode of treating diseases, by which a morbid condition is removed by inducing an opposite morbid condition to supplant it; allopathy.
hipless: having hips which are not prominent; seeming to have no hips; as, slim and hipless; -- of people.  Opposite of broad-hipped
Huron-Iroquous: A linguistic group of warlike North American Indians, belonging to the same stock as the Algonquins, and including several tribes, among which were the Five Nations. They formerly occupied the region about Lakes Erie and Ontario, and the larger part of New York.
houseplant: any of a variety of plants grown indoors for decorative purposes.
Horsemanship: The act or art of riding, and of training and managing horses; manege.
Hyperbolically: In the form of an hyperbola.
harlequin snake: any of several venomous New World snakes brilliantly banded in red and black and either yellow or white, especially the eastern coral snake, a small poisonous snake (Micrurus fulvius or Elaps fulvius), ringed with red and black, found in the Southeastern United States.  They are widely distributed in Southern and Central America;
Howell: The upper stage of a porcelian furnace.
Himalayan: Of or pertaining to the Himalayas, the great mountain chain in Asia.
hunched: having the back and shoulders rounded; not erect; -- of people.
&Verbar;Hyperinosis: A condition of the blood, characterized by an abnormally large amount of fibrin, as in many inflammatory diseases.
hardwareman: One who makes, or deals in, hardware.
Hirudine: Of or pertaining to the leeches.
Hunkers: In the phrase on one's hunkers, in a squatting or crouching position; haunches.
Hobblebush: A low bush (Viburnum lantanoides) having long, straggling branches and handsome flowers. It is found in the Northern United States. Called also shinhopple.
Hurst: A wood or grove; -- a word used in the composition of many names, as in Hazlehurst.
Heptylene: A colorless liquid hydrocarbon, C7H14, of the ethylene series; also, any one of its isomers. Called also heptene.
Half-length: Of half the whole or ordinary length, as a picture.
&Verbar;Hymenium: The spore-bearing surface of certain fungi, as that on the gills of a mushroom.
Hyphenated American: An American who is referred to by a hyphenated term with the first word indicating an origin in a foreign country, and the second term being “American”, as Irish-American, Italian-American, African-American, Asian-American.
Homoiousian: Of or pertaining to Homoiousians, or their belief.
Homologate: To approve; to allow; to confirm; as, the court homologates a proceeding.
hook-and-ladder company: A company of firefighters who operate a hook-and-ladder truck; a fire company; called also ladder company.
Highway robbery: Robbery committed on the public roads.
Hypidiomorphic: Partly idiomorphic; -- said of rock a portion only of whose constituents have a distinct crystalline form.
Heinous: Hateful; hatefully bad; flagrant; odious; atrocious; giving great offense; -- applied to deeds or to character.
Hairsplitter: One who makes excessively fine or needless distinctions in reasoning; one who quibbles.
Hopbine: The climbing stem of the hop.
High-hearted: Full of courage or nobleness; high-souled.
Hurry: The act of hurrying in motion or business; pressure; urgency; bustle; confusion.
Hognosesnake: A harmless North American snake of the genus Heterodon, esp. Heterodon platyrhynos; -- called also puffing adder, blowing adder, and sand viper.
&Verbar;Hybodus: An extinct genus of sharks having conical, compressed teeth.
Hellenic: The dialect, formed with slight variations from the Attic, which prevailed among Greek writers after the time of Alexander.
Herakline: A picrate compound, used as an explosive in blasting.
Hunterian: Discovered or described by John Hunter, an English surgeon; as, the Hunterian chancre. See Chancre.
Hertzian: Of or pert. to the German physicist Heinrich Hertz.
&Verbar;Hyperdulia: Veneration or worship given to the Virgin Mary as the most exalted of mere creatures; higher veneration than dulia.
Horologer: A maker or vender of clocks and watches; one skilled in horology.
Hotpressed: Pressed while heat is applied. See Hotpress, v. t.
Huer: One who cries out or gives an alarm; specifically, a balker; a conder. See Balker.
Hypogastric: Of or pertaining to the hypogastrium or the hypogastric region.
Honshu: the main island of Japan.  Together with the islands of Hokkaido, Kyushu and Shikoku it forms the bulk of the land area of Japan.
higher-ranking: having a rank above that of another.
Hogframe: A trussed frame extending fore and aft, usually above deck, and intended to increase the longitudinal strength and stiffness. Used chiefly in American river and lake steamers. Called also hogging frame, and hogback.
Herpes: An eruption of the skin, taking various names, according to its form, or the part affected, caused by a herpesvirus infection; especially, an eruption of vesicles in small distinct clusters, accompanied with itching or tingling, including shingles, ringworm, and the like; -- so called from its tendency to creep or spread from one part of the skin to another.
Hypercriticism: Excessive criticism, or unjust severity or rigor of criticism; zoilism.
Helmeted: Wearing a helmet; furnished with or having a helmet or helmet-shaped part; galeate.
Hawser-laid: Made in the manner of a hawser.  Cf. Cable-laid, and see Illust. of Cordage.
High-bred: Bred in high life; of pure blood.
Hierarch: One who has high and controlling authority in sacred things; the chief of a sacred order; as, princely hierarchs.
Heptoic: Pertaining to, or derived from, heptane; as, heptoic acid.
Hydrometeor: A meteor or atmospheric phenomenon dependent upon the vapor of water; -- in the pl., a general term for the whole aqueous phenomena of the atmosphere, as rain, snow, hail, etc.
Hedgeborn: Born under a hedge; of low birth.
Heugh: A crag; a cliff; a glen with overhanging sides.
Heigh-ho: An exclamation of surprise, joy, dejection, uneasiness, weariness, etc.
Hall-mark: The official stamp of the Goldsmiths' Company and other assay offices, in the United Kingdom, on gold and silver articles, attesting their purity.
Hernani: A thin silk or woolen goods, for women's dresses, woven in various styles and colors.
Hypsometer: An instrument for measuring heights by observation of barometric pressure; esp., one for determining heights by ascertaining the boiling point of water. It consists of a vessel for water, with a lamp for heating it, and an inclosed thermometer for showing the temperature of ebullition.
Hidden: from Hide. Concealed; put out of view; secret; not known; mysterious.
Halituous: Produced by, or like, breath; vaporous.
&Verbar;Hemophilia: A condition characterized by a tendency to profuse and uncontrollable hemorrhage from the slightest wounds; it is caused by an absence or abnormality of a clotting factor in the blood, and is a recessive genetic disease linked to the X-chromosome, and therefore usually occurs only in males; there are several specific forms.  It may be treated by administering purified clotting factor.  It was formerly termed Hematophilia.
horsebean: The seed of the broad-bean plant.
Hussy: A case or bag. See Housewife, 2.
Hornyhead: Any North American river chub of the genus Hybopsis, esp. Hybopsis biguttatus.
handwash: to wash by hand, launder by hand; -- contrasted to machine-wash.
Hirundinidae: A natural family of birds including the swallows and martins.
Highway: A road or way open to the use of the public, especially a paved main road or thoroughfare between towns; in the latter sense it contrasts with local street; as, on the highways and byways.
Heartswelling: Rankling in, or swelling, the heart.
&Verbar;Hemeralopia: A disease of the eyes, in consequence of which a person can see clearly or without pain only by daylight or a strong artificial light; day sight.
hard-of-hearing: having a reduced ability to hear, but not fully deaf; partly deaf.
homophobia: A strong dislike or fear of homosexuals, especially to an unreasonable degree.
homophobic: Disliking or fearing homosexuals to an unreasonable degree.
Huffiness: The state of being huffish; petulance; bad temper.
Highmen: Loaded dice so contrived as to turn up high numbers.
hideaway: a hiding place; usually a remote place used by outlaws.
Hexacid: Having six atoms or radicals capable of being replaced by acids; hexatomic; hexavalent; -- said of bases; as, mannite is a hexacid base.
Hydrometeorology: That branch of meteorology which relates to, or treats of, water in the atmosphere, or its phenomena, as rain, clouds, snow, hail, storms, etc.
Humanist: One of the scholars who in the field of literature proper represented the movement of the Renaissance, and early in the 16th century adopted the name Humanist as their distinctive title.
Hoofbound: Having a dry and contracted hoof, which occasions pain and lameness.
Hypocarp: A fleshy enlargement of the receptacle, or for the stem, below the proper fruit, as in the cashew. See Illust. of Cashew.
Hoe: To use a hoe; to labor with a hoe.
Hyperbatic: Of or pertaining to an hyperbaton; transposed; inverted.
hummingbird: any bird of the family Trochilidæ, of which over one hundred genera are known, including about four hundred species. They are found only in America and are most abundant in the tropics. They are mostly of very small size with long slender bills adapted to sucking nectar from flowers, and are noted for the very brilliant iridescent colors of their plumage and their peculiar habit of hovering about flowers while vibrating their wings very rapidly with a humming noise; the wings are specialized for hovering flight, but they can also dart forward and fly quite rapidly. They feed both upon the nectar of flowers and upon small insects. The common humming bird or ruby-throat of the Eastern United States is Trochilus colubris. Several other species are found in the Western United States. See Calliope, and Ruby-throat.
Heptine: Any one of a series of unsaturated metameric hydrocarbons, C7H12, of the acetylene series.
Heulandite: A mineral of the Zeolite family, often occurring in amygdaloid, in foliated masses, and also in monoclinic crystals with pearly luster on the cleavage face. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime.
Hussite: A follower of John Huss, the Bohemian reformer, who was adjudged a heretic and burnt alive in 1415.
Helminthite: One of the sinuous tracks on the surfaces of many stones, and popularly considered as worm trails.
Holcad: A large ship of burden, in ancient Greece.
Hard steel: Steel hardened by the addition of other elements, as manganese, phosphorus, or (usually) carbon.
Heptastich: A composition consisting of seven lines or verses.
Hesperian: Of or pertaining to a family of butterflies called Hesperidæ, or skippers.
hipflask: A small portable flask, usually made of metal, used to hold liquor.
Hippopotamus: A large, amphibious, herbivorous mammal (Hippopotamus amphibius), common in the rivers of tropical Africa. It is allied to the hogs, and has a very thick, naked skin, a thick and square head, a very large muzzle, small eyes and ears, thick and heavy body, and short legs. It is supposed to be the behemoth of the Bible. Called also zeekoe, and river horse.  A smaller species (Hippopotamus Liberiencis) inhabits Western Africa.
heaps: a large quantity.  See heap, senses 2 and 3; as, he made heaps of money in the stock market.
Homotonous: Of the same tenor or tone; equable; without variation.
&Verbar;Hallux: The first, or preaxial, digit of the hind limb, corresponding to the pollux in the fore limb; the great toe; the hind toe of birds.
Headsail: Any sail set forward of the foremast.
half-holiday: a day on which half of the day is free from work or duty; a holiday of one half of a day.
Homodont: Having all the teeth similar in front, as in the porpoises; -- opposed to heterodont.
&Verbar;Hakim: A Mohammedan title for a ruler; a judge.
Hexactinelline: Belonging to the Hexactinellinæ, a group of sponges, having six-rayed siliceous spicules.
Hist: Hush; be silent; -- a signal for silence.
Houseleek: A succulent plant of the genus Sempervivum (Sempervivum tectorum), originally a native of subalpine Europe, but now found very generally on old walls and roofs.  It is very tenacious of life under drought and heat; -- called also ayegreen.
Hiss: A prolonged sound like that letter s, made by forcing out the breath between the tongue and teeth, esp. as a token of disapprobation or contempt.
Hazily: In a hazy manner; mistily; obscurely; confusedly.
&Verbar;Hesperus: Venus when she is the evening star; Hesper.
Humorist: One who attributes diseases of the state of the humors.
homeostasis: The ability and tendency of certain systems to maintain a relatively constant internal state in spite of changes in external conditions; this ability is achieved by the presence of feedback mechanisms which can adjust the state of the system to compensate for changes in the state caused by the external environment.  It is exemplified in homeothermal biological systems, such as animals which maintain relatively constant blood temperature and composition in spite of variations in external temperature or the composition of the food ingested.
Hose: Close-fitting trousers or breeches, as formerly worn, reaching to the knee.
Hereditable: Capable of being inherited. See Inheritable.
Henrietta cloth: A fine wide wooled fabric much used for women's dresses.
Humic: Pertaining to, or derived from, vegetable mold; as, humic acid. See Humin.
Hailstone: A single particle of ice falling from a cloud; a frozen raindrop; a pellet of hail.
Hyperorganic: Higher than, or beyond the sphere of, the organic.
Hemidactyl: Any species of Old World geckoes of the genus Hemidactylus. The hemidactyls have dilated toes, with two rows of plates beneath.
housetop: The roof of a house, especially the flat part of a roof; as, shout it from the housetops.
Hermetic: Of, pertaining to, or taught by, Hermes Trismegistus; as, hermetic philosophy. Hence: Alchemical; chemic.
Hemistichal: Pertaining to, or written in, hemistichs; also, by, or according to, hemistichs; as, a hemistichal division of a verse.
halftime: an intermission between the first and second half of a game, especially a football game.  Also used attributively, as the halftime entertainment
Hedge fund: a mutual fund or partnership of investors who pool large sums of money to speculate in securities, increasing the risk of such activity by using borrowed money to leverage the investments, or by selling short.
Harvest: To reap or gather, as any crop.
Honiton lace: A kind of pillow lace, remarkable for the beauty of its figures; -- so called because chiefly made in Honiton, England.
Hogchoker: An American sole (Achirus lineatus syn. Achirus achirus), related to the European sole, but of no market value.
Helmwind: A wind attending or presaged by the cloud called helm.
Hanukka: The Jewish Feast of the Dedication, instituted by Judas Maccabæus, his brothers, and the whole congregation of Israel, in 165 b. c., to commemorate the dedication of the new altar set up at the purification of the temple of Jerusalem to replace the altar which had been polluted by Antiochus Epiphanes of Syria (1 Maccabees i. 58, iv. 59). The feast, which is mentioned in John x. 22, is held for eight days (beginning with the 25th day of Kislev, corresponding to December), and is celebrated everywhere, chiefly as a festival of lights, by the Jews.
Hydrology: The science of water, its properties, phenomena, and distribution over the earth's surface.
Hypostasize: To make into a distinct substance; to conceive or treat as an existing being; to hypostatize.
Headquarters: The quarters or place of residence of any chief officer, as the general in command of an army, or the head of a police force; the place from which orders or instructions are issued; hence, the center of authority or order.
Heuchera: A genus of North American herbs with basal cordate or orbicular leaves and small panicled flowers.
Homogenetic: Homogenous; -- applied to that class of homologies which arise from similarity of structure, and which are taken as evidences of common ancestry.
Halimodendron: A genus of trees consisting of one species, the salt tree.
Heckle: To interrogate, or ply with questions, esp. with severity or antagonism, as a candidate for the ministry.
Hatred: Strong aversion; intense dislike; hate; an affection of the mind awakened by something regarded as evil.
Hostess-ship: The character, personality, or office of a hostess.
Hypnology: A treatise on sleep; the doctrine of sleep.
H\u00e6matachometry: The measurement of the velocity of the blood.
&Verbar;Habendum: That part of a deed which follows the part called the premises, and determines the extent of the interest or estate granted; -- so called because it begins with the word Habendum.
Handbill: A loose, printed sheet, to be distributed by hand.
Helmet-shaped: Shaped like a helmet; galeate. See Illust. of Galeate.
Heraldic: Of or pertaining to heralds or heraldry; as, heraldic blazoning; heraldic language.
Hygeian: Relating to Hygeia, the goddess of health; of or pertaining to health, or its preservation.
&Verbar;Hirudinea: An order of Annelida, including the leeches; -- called also Hirudinei.
Hilum: The eye of a bean or other seed; the mark or scar at the point of attachment of an ovule or seed to its base or support; -- called also hile.
Hydrometallurgical: Of or pertaining to hydrometallurgy; involving the use of liquid reagents in the treatment or reduction of ores.
Humanize: To become or be made more humane; to become civilized; to be ameliorated.
Heterochronism: In evolution, a deviation from the typical sequence in the formation of organs or parts.
Hack: To be exposed or offered to common use for hire; to turn prostitute.
Heterogangliate: Having the ganglia of the nervous system unsymmetrically arranged; -- said of certain invertebrate animals.
Heterocercal: Having the vertebral column evidently continued into the upper lobe of the tail, which is usually longer than the lower one, as in sharks.
Homophone: A letter or character which expresses a like sound with another.
Hagship: The state or title of a hag.
Honeyberry: The fruit of either of two trees having sweetish berries: (a) An Old World hackberry (Celtis australis). (b) In the West Indies, the genip (Melicocca bijuga).
Hegira: The flight of Mohammed from Mecca, September 13, a. d. 622 (subsequently established as the first year of the Moslem era); hence, any flight or exodus regarded as like that of Mohammed.
Headshake: A significant shake of the head, commonly as a signal of denial.
Hectogram: A measure of weight, containing a hundred grams, or about 3.527 ounces avoirdupois.
Hispanicism: A Spanish idiom or mode of speech.
Haystack: A stack or conical pile of hay in the open air.
High-priesthood: The office, dignity, or position of a high priest.
Hypnotization: The act or process of producing hypnotism.
Hardbake: A sweetmeat of boiled brown sugar or molasses made with almonds, and flavored with orange or lemon juice, etc.
hyperactivity: an unusually high level of activity; -- used especially with respect to children who move around frequently and do not sit still very long, most noticeably in school.  It is sometimes associated with attention deficit disorder.
Hudsonian: Of or pertaining to Hudson's Bay or to the Hudson River; as, the Hudsonian curlew.
Huascaran: a mountain in Peru, 22,205 feet high.
Hyposulphurous: Pertaining to, or containing, sulphur, all, or a part, in a low state of oxidation.
Hemerobiidae: A natural family of insects including the brown lacewings.
Hematology: The science which treats of the blood.
Hektare: Same as Hectare, Hectogram, Hectoliter, and Hectometer.
hipster: A person who is hip{2}, a..
Hagiographal: Pertaining to the hagiographa, or to sacred writings.
Horary: Of or pertaining to an hour; noting the hours.
highbrow: highly cultured or educated; pertaining to highly educated people; as, highbrow events such as the ballet or opera.
Hectometer: A measure of length, equal to a hundred meters. It is equivalent to 328.09 feet.
Hydrophane: A semitranslucent variety of opal that becomes translucent or transparent on immersion in water.
Hebetation: The act of making blunt, dull, or stupid.
Henceforward: From this time forward; from now into the indefinite future; henceforth.
Hydrosome: All the zooids of a hydroid colony collectively, including the nutritive and reproductive zooids, and often other kinds.
Hansard: A merchant of one of the Hanse towns. See the Note under 2d Hanse.
Hypogeous: Growing under ground; remaining under ground; ripening its fruit under ground.
Herbarium: A collection of dried specimens of plants, systematically arranged.
Hydrostat: A contrivance or apparatus to prevent the explosion of steam boilers.
hayseed: a rural, unsophisticated person; also used in an extended sense for one who is not very intelligent or uninterested in culture.
Hookes gearing: Spur gearing having teeth slanting across the face of the wheel, sometimes slanting in opposite directions from the middle.
Haggis: A Scotch pudding made of the heart, liver, lights, etc., of a sheep or lamb, minced with suet, onions, oatmeal, etc., highly seasoned, and boiled in the stomach of the same animal; minced head and pluck.
Halibut: A large, northern, marine flatfish (Hippoglossus vulgaris), of the family Pleuronectidæ.  It often grows very large, weighing more than three hundred pounds.  It is an important food fish.
Horner: One who works or deal in horn or horns.
Hummeler: One who, or a machine which, hummels.
hadron: any elementary particle that interacts strongly with other particles.
Hanger: One who hangs, or causes to be hanged; a hangman.
&Verbar;Heteronereis: A free-swimming, dimorphic, sexual form of certain species of Nereis.
Homonymous: Having the same name or designation; standing in the same relation; -- opposed to heteronymous.
Hypocrystalline: Partly crystalline; -- said of rock which consists of crystals imbedded in a glassy ground mass.
Hate: Strong aversion coupled with desire that evil should befall the person toward whom the feeling is directed; as exercised toward things, intense dislike; hatred; detestation; -- opposed to love.
Hardpan: The hard substratum. Same as Hard pan, under Hard, a.
&Verbar;Hemina: A measure of half a sextary.
hearable: perceptible by the ear.  Opposite of inaudible.
hindquarter: the back half of a side of meat, from about the twelfth rib back.
Hares-ear: An umbelliferous plant (Bupleurum rotundifolium); -- so named from the shape of its leaves.
Hunk: A large lump or piece; a hunch; as, a hunk of bread.
Hematoidin: A crystalline or amorphous pigment, free from iron, formed from hematin in old blood stains, and in old hemorrhages in the body. It resembles bilirubin. When present in the corpora lutea it is called hæmolutein.
Hydromel: A liquor consisting of honey diluted in water, and after fermentation called mead.
Henbane: A plant of the genus Hyoscyamus (Hyoscyamus niger). All parts of the plant are poisonous, and the leaves are used for the same purposes as belladonna. It is poisonous to domestic fowls; whence the name. Called also, stinking nightshade, from the fetid odor of the plant. See Hyoscyamus.
Horologiographer: A maker of clocks, watches, or dials.
Housemaid: A female servant employed to do housework, esp. to take care of the rooms.
Hisingerite: A soft black, iron ore, nearly earthy, a hydrous silicate of iron.
Heady: Willful; rash; precipitate; hurried on by will or passion; ungovernable.
Hawkweed: A plant of the genus Hieracium; -- so called from the ancient belief that birds of prey used its juice to strengthen their vision.
Hyalograph: An instrument for tracing designs on glass.
homeless: Those people who have no permanent residence, especially those who live outdoors due to poverty; usually used in the definite phrase the homeless.
heated: characterized by great warmth and intensity of feeling; as, a heated argument.  Opposite of dispassionate, passionless.
Hard-labored: Wrought with severe labor; elaborate; studied.
Hysteroepilepsy: A disease resembling hysteria in its nature, and characterized by the occurrence of epileptiform convulsions, which can often be controlled or excited by pressure on the ovaries, and upon other definite points in the body.
&Verbar;Heterotricha: A division of ciliated Infusoria, having fine cilia all over the body, and a circle of larger ones around the anterior end.
hep: A call used by drill instructors to count cadence during marching; used identically to hut and hup.
Helleborism: The practice or theory of using hellebore as a medicine.
Hotel: A house for entertaining strangers or travelers; an inn or public house, of the better class.
Halloysite: A claylike mineral, occurring in soft, smooth, amorphous masses, of a whitish color.
Himantopus: one of two genera of stilts; they are similar to avocets but with straight bills.
Hostaceae: One of many families or subfamilies into which some classification systems subdivide the Liliaceae but not widely accepted; includes genus Hosta.
Hogpen: A pen or sty for hogs.
Hexabasic: Having six hydrogen atoms or six radicals capable of being replaced or saturated by bases; -- said of acids; as, mellitic acid is hexabasic.
Hypertrophy: A condition of overgrowth or excessive development of an organ or part; -- the opposite of atrophy.
Hydrofluosilicic: Pertaining to, or denoting, a compound consisting of a double fluoride of hydrogen and silicon; silicofluoric. See Silicofluoric.
Hornbook: The first book for children, or that from which in former times they learned their letters and rudiments; -- so called because a sheet of horn covered the small, thin board of oak, or the slip of paper, on which the alphabet, digits, and often the Lord's Prayer, were written or printed; a primer.
Hedging bill: A hedge bill. See under Hedge.
Harry: To make a predatory incursion; to plunder or lay waste.
Heroner: A hawk used in hunting the heron.
Handwheel: Any wheel worked by hand; esp., one the rim of which serves as the handle by which a valve, car brake, or other part is adjusted.
&Verbar;Hipparion: An extinct genus of Tertiary mammals allied to the horse, but three-toed, having on each foot a small lateral hoof on each side of the main central one. It is believed to be one of the ancestral genera of the Horse family.
Headmold shot: An old name for the condition of the skull, in which the bones ride, or are shot, over each other at the sutures.
Horizontal: Pertaining to, or near, the horizon.
happening: something that happens; an occurrence; an event.
heathfowl: A large Northern European black grouse (Lyrurus tetrix formerly Tetrao tetrix) with a lyre-shaped tail; it is also called heath grouse, black game, black grouse, heath poult, heath fowl, and moor fowl.  See heath grouse under heath, above.
Horopteric: Of or pertaining to the horopter.
Hoody: The hooded crow; also, in Scotland, the hooded gull.
Hysteranthous: Having the leaves expand after the flowers have opened.
Hemadynamometer: An instrument by which the pressure of the blood in the arteries, or veins, is measured by the height to which it will raise a column of mercury; -- called also a hæmomanometer.
Hackberry: A genus of trees (Celtis) related to the elm, but bearing drupes with scanty, but often edible, pulp.  Celtis occidentalis is common in the Eastern United States.
Heave: An effort to raise something, as a weight, or one's self, or to move something heavy.
How: In what manner or way; by what means or process.
Hog: To become bent upward in the middle, like a hog's back; -- said of a ship broken or strained so as to have this form.
Hod: A kind of wooden tray with a handle, having  V-shaped trough, made of wood or metal, attached to a long handle and usually carried over the shoulder; it is a tool used by construction workers for carrying bricks or mortar.
Hadrosauridae: A natural family of extinct reptiles including the duck-billed dinosaurs.
Hawser: A large rope made of three strands each containing many yarns.
Hint: A remote allusion; slight mention; intimation; insinuation; a suggestion or reminder, without a full declaration or explanation; also, an occasion or motive.
Heartrending: Causing intense grief; overpowering with anguish; very distressing.
Helotium: The type genus of the Helotiaceae.
Hot: Having much sensible heat; exciting the feeling of warmth in a great degree; very warm; -- opposed to cold, and exceeding warm in degree; as, a hot stove; hot water or air.
Hutch: To hoard or lay up, in a chest.
&Verbar;Hexagynia: A Linnæan order of plants having six pistils.
Hylopathism: The doctrine that matter is sentient.
Hine: A servant; a farm laborer; a peasant; a hind.
