Hind: In the rear; -- opposed to front; of or pertaining to the part or end which follows or is behind, in opposition to the part which leads or is before; as, the hind legs or hind feet of a quadruped; the hind man in a procession.
Hospitalism: A vitiated condition of the body, due to long confinement in a hospital, or the morbid condition of the atmosphere of a hospital.
Humanity: The quality of being human; the peculiar nature of man, by which he is distinguished from other beings.
Hox: To hock; to hamstring. See Hock.
Herea-bout: About this place; in this vicinity.
Homopterous: Of or pertaining to the Homoptera.
Hereticate: To decide to be heresy or a heretic; to denounce as a heretic or heretical.
Hemipteral: Of or pertaining to the Hemiptera.
&Verbar;Heliconia: One of numerous species of Heliconius, a genus of tropical American butterflies.  The wings are usually black, marked with green, crimson, and white.
homeworker: A person who works at home for pay.
Hylozoism: The doctrine that matter possesses a species of life and sensation, or that matter and life are inseparable.
Homager: One who does homage, or holds land of another by homage; a vassal.
&Verbar;Humerus: The bone of the brachium, or upper part of the arm or fore limb.
Histogenetic: Tissue-producing; connected with the formation and development of the organic tissues.
High-churchman-ship: The state of being a high-churchman.
Hierophantic: Of or relating to hierophants or their teachings.
Hypophosphoric: Pertaining to, or derived from, or containing, phosphorus in a lower state of oxidation than in phosphoric compounds; as, hypophosphoric acid.
houseboat: a barge that is designed and equipped for use as a dwelling.
Highborn: Of noble or aristocratic birth.  Contrasted with lowborn and common.
Hypural: Under the tail; -- applied to the bones which support the caudal fin rays in most fishes.
Humoralist: One who favors the humoral pathology or believes in humoralism.
&Verbar;Hemicrania: A pain that affects only one side of the head.
Hum: Ahem; hem; an inarticulate sound uttered in a pause of speech implying doubt and deliberation.
hackie: The driver of a taxicab; a hackman.
&Verbar;Haplomi: An order of freshwater fishes, including the true pikes, cyprinodonts, and blindfishes.
Holdfast: Something used to secure and hold in place something else, as a long flat-headed nail, a catch a hook, a clinch, a clamp, etc.; hence, a support.
Hasten: To move with celerity; to be rapid in motion; to act speedily or quickly; to go quickly.
Haplostemonous: Having but one series of stamens, and that equal in number to the proper number of petals; isostemonous.
Hymenogastrales: An order of fungi sometimes placed in subclass Homobasidiomycetes.
Holy: Set apart to the service or worship of God; hallowed; sacred; reserved from profane or common use; holy vessels; a holy priesthood.
Histology: That branch of biological science, which treats of the minute (microscopic) structure of animal and vegetable tissues; -- called also histiology.
&Verbar;Hydromedusa: Any medusa or jellyfish which is produced by budding from a hydroid. They are called also Craspedota, and naked-eyed medusæ.
Hardware: Ware made of metal, as cutlery, kitchen utensils, and the like; ironmongery.
&Verbar;H\u00e6matolysis: Dissolution of the red blood corpuscles with diminished coagulability of the blood; hæmolysis.
Hebraically: After the manner of the Hebrews or of the Hebrew language.
Habilitate: To fit out; to equip; to qualify; to entitle.
Harassment: The act of harassing, or state of being harassed; worry; annoyance; anxiety.
Hent: To seize; to lay hold on; to catch; to get.
Hypothecate: To subject, as property, to liability for a debt or engagement without delivery of possession or transfer of title; to pledge without delivery of possession; to mortgage, as ships, or other personal property; to make a contract by bottomry. See Hypothecation, Bottomry.
&Verbar;Hammochrysos: A stone with spangles of gold color in it.
&Verbar;Havildar: In the British Indian armies, a noncommissioned officer of native soldiers, corresponding to a sergeant.
Hunker: Originally, a nickname for a member of the conservative section of the Democratic party in New York; hence, one opposed to progress in general; a fogy.
Half-boot: A boot with a short top covering only the ankle. See Cocker, and Congress boot, under Congress.
Heartbreak: Crushing sorrow or grief; a yielding to such grief.
Helminthology: The natural history, or study, of worms, esp. parasitic worms.
Honeywort: A European plant of the genus Cerinthe, whose flowers are very attractive to bees.
Henchman: An attendant; a servant; a follower. Now chiefly used as a political cant term.
Hurt: To cause physical pain to; to do bodily harm to; to wound or bruise painfully.
Hopple: A fetter for horses, or cattle, when turned out to graze; -- chiefly used in the plural.
Humanness: The quality or state of being human.
Hangnail: A small piece or sliver of skin which hangs loose, near the root of a finger nail.
Handicap: To encumber with a handicap in any contest; hence, in general, to place at disadvantage; as, the candidate was heavily handicapped.
Healthful: Full of health; free from illness or disease; well; whole; sound; healthy; as, a healthful body or mind; a healthful plant.
HMO: A health maintenance organization; a form of group health insurance that entitles members to services of participating hospitals and clinics and physicians.
Housebreaker: One who is guilty of the crime of housebreaking.
Hemostatic: A medicine or application to arrest hemorrhage.
Hydrognosy: A treatise upon, or a history and description of, the water of the earth.
Headband: A fillet; a band for the head.
High-strung: Strung to a high pitch; spirited; sensitive; as, a high-strung horse.
Hulking: Bulky; unwiedly; of great size and bulk; ponderous.
Hypocaust: A furnace, esp. one connected with a series of small chambers and flues of tiles or other masonry through which the heat of a fire was distributed to rooms above. This contrivance, first used in bath, was afterwards adopted in private houses.
Hallage: A fee or toll paid for goods sold in a hall.
Heartseed: A climbing plant of the genus Cardiospermum, having round seeds which are marked with a spot like a heart.
hee-haw: a loud laugh that sounds like a horse neighing.
Hibernian: Of or pertaining to Hibernia, now Ireland; Irish.
Haddock: A marine food fish (Melanogrammus æglefinus), allied to the cod, inhabiting the northern coasts of Europe and America. It has a dark lateral line and a black spot on each side of the body, just back of the gills. Galled also haddie, and dickie.
Hittorf tube: A highly exhausted glass tube with metallic electrodes nearly in contact so as to exhibit the insulating effects of a vacuum. It was used by the German physicist W. Hittorf (b. 1824).
hinterland: a remote and undeveloped area; originally, the land or region lying behind the coast district. The term is used esp. with reference to the so-called doctrine of the hinterland, sometimes advanced, that occupation of the coast supports a claim to an exclusive right to occupy, from time to time, the territory lying inland of the coast.
Honesty: Honor; honorableness; dignity; propriety; suitableness; decency.
Hun: One of a warlike nomadic people of Northern Asia who, in the 5th century, under Atilla, invaded and conquered a great part of Europe.
Hydra: A serpent or monster in the lake or marsh of Lerna, in the Peloponnesus, represented as having many heads, one of which, when cut off, was immediately succeeded by two others, unless the wound was cauterized. It was slain by Hercules. Hence, a terrible monster.
Hamilton period: A subdivision of the Devonian system of America; -- so named from Hamilton, Madison Co., New York. It includes the Marcellus, Hamilton, and Genesee epochs or groups. See the Chart of Geology.
Hydrargochloride: A compound of the bichloride of mercury with another chloride.
Hymenogeny: The production of artificial membranes by contact of two fluids, as albumin and fat, by which the globules of the latter are surrounded by a thin film of the former.
Headway: The progress made by a ship in motion; hence, progress or success of any kind.
Heeler: A cock that strikes well with his heels or spurs.
Hurries: A staith or framework from which coal is discharged from cars into vessels.
Hundredfold: A hundred times as much or as many.
Horsefly: Any dipterous fly of the family Tabanidæ, that stings horses, and sucks their blood.
Half-sword: Half the length of a sword; close fight.
&Verbar;Historiette: Historical narration on a small scale; a brief recital; a story.
High steel: Steel containing a high percentage of carbon; high-carbon steel.
Herpetologist: One versed in herpetology, or the natural history of reptiles.
horsecart: A heavycart drawn by a horse, used for farm work.
Hagiology: The history or description of the sacred writings or of sacred persons; a narrative of the lives of the saints; a catalogue of saints.
Hereditarily: By inheritance; in an hereditary manner.
Hatband: A band round the crown of a hat; sometimes, a band of black cloth, crape, etc., worn as a badge of mourning.
Hemerocallidaceae: one of many subfamilies into which some classification systems subdivide the Lily family Liliaceae, but not widely accepted; it includes the genus Hemerocallis.
Humor: To comply with the humor of; to adjust matters so as suit the peculiarities, caprices, or exigencies of; to adapt one's self to; to indulge by skillful adaptation; as, to humor the mind.
Hurling: The act of throwing with force.
&Verbar;Hadj: The pilgrimage to Mecca, performed by Mohammedans.  It is the duty of Moslems to make a journey to Mecca at least once ina lifetime, or if that is not possible, three journeys to one of the alternate sacred sites.
Hamamelidae: a group of chiefly woody plants considered among the most primitive of angiosperms; they have a perianth poorly developed or lacking, and flowers often unisexual and often in catkins and often wind pollinated.  The group contains 23 families including the Betulaceae and Fagaceae (includes the Amentiferae); sometimes it is classified as a superorder.
Hawthorn: A thorny shrub or tree (the Cratægus oxyacantha), having deeply lobed, shining leaves, small, roselike, fragrant flowers, and a fruit called haw.  It is much used in Europe for hedges, and for standards in gardens.  The American hawthorn is Cratægus cordata, which has the leaves but little lobed.
Hypophyllous: Being or growing on the under side of a leaf, as the fruit dots of ferns.
Hemiprotein: An insoluble, proteid substance, described by Schützenberger, formed when albumin is heated for some time with dilute sulphuric acid. It is apparently identical with antialbumid and dyspeptone.
Harmel: A kind of rue (Ruta sylvestris) growing in India. At Lahore the seeds are used medicinally and for fumigation.
Harmful: Full of harm; injurious; hurtful; mischievous.
Holocryptic: Wholly or completely concealing; incapable of being deciphered.
Hodr: A blind god; misled by Loki he kills Balder by throwing a bough of mistletoe.
Hammer-beam: A member of one description of roof truss, called hammer-beam truss, which is so framed as not to have a tiebeam at the top of the wall. Each principal has two hammer-beams, which occupy the situation, and to some extent serve the purpose, of a tiebeam.
Hire: The price, reward, or compensation paid, or contracted to be paid, for the temporary use of a thing or a place, for personal service, or for labor; wages; rent; pay.
Hypostome: The lower lip of trilobites, crustaceans, etc.
Horseshoe: A shoe for horses, consisting of a narrow plate of iron in form somewhat like the letter U, nailed to a horse's hoof.
headlock: A wrestling hold in which the opponent's head is locked between the crook of your elbow and the side of your body.
Herald: To introduce, or give tidings of, as by a herald; to proclaim; to announce; to foretell; to usher in.
Hypercritical: Over critical; unreasonably or unjustly critical; carping; captious.
Hydrosulphuric: Pertaining to, or derived from, hydrogen and sulphur; as, hydrosulphuric acid, a designation applied to the solution of hydrogen sulphide in water.
Hinge: To stand, depend, hang, or turn, as on a hinge; to depend chiefly for a result or decision or for force and validity; -- usually with on or upon; as, the argument hinges on this point.
hoagie: a large sandwich on a long crusty roll that is split lengthwise and filled with meats and cheese (and tomato and onion and lettuce and condiments); different names are used in different sections of the U. S., such as hero, grinder, and submarine.
Humid: Containing sensible moisture; damp; moist; as, a humidair or atmosphere; somewhat wet or watery; as, humid earth; consisting of water or vapor.
Heliometer: An instrument devised originally for measuring the diameter of the sun; now employed for delicate measurements of the distance and relative direction of two stars too far apart to be easily measured in the field of view of an ordinary telescope.
harpulla: A fast-growing tree of India and East Indies (Harpullia cupanioides) yielding a wood used especially for building.
Humin: A bitter, brownish yellow, amorphous substance, extracted from vegetable mold, and also produced by the action of acids on certain sugars and carbohydrates; -- called also humic acid, ulmin, gein, ulmic or geic acid, etc.
Hypsiloid: Resembling the Greek letter Υ in form; hyoid.
heroin: a morphine derivative, diacetyl morphine, used to relieve severe pain and as a sedative.  It is highly addictive, and its use is strictly controlled in the U.S. by federal law.  It is a popular strong narcotic drug of abuse, in part because it is more soluble than morphine.  It is sometimes included as one of the components of Brompton's mixture, used to control pain in terminallly ill patients.
Hom\u0153omorphism: A near similarity of crystalline forms between unlike chemical compounds. See Isomorphism.
holdover: Any person or thing remaining from a previous period of use, tenure, etc;
Hourglass: An instrument for measuring time, especially the interval of an hour. It consists of a glass vessel having two compartments, from the uppermost of which a quantity of sand, water, or mercury occupies an hour in running through a small aperture unto the lower.
Hurkaru: In India, a running footman; a messenger.
Half-and-half: A mixture of two malt liquors, esp. porter and ale, in about equal parts.
Homoplasmy: Resemblance between different plants or animals, in external shape, in general habit, or in organs, which is not due to descent from a common ancestor, but to similar surrounding circumstances.
Hexachord: A series of six notes, with a semitone between the third and fourth, the other intervals being whole tones.
handwoven: same as hand-loomed; as, a handwoven tablecloth.
Hounds-tongue: A biennial weed (Cynoglossum officinale), with soft tongue-shaped leaves, and an offensive odor. It bears nutlets covered with barbed or hooked prickles. Called also dog's-tongue.
Helcoplasty: The act or process of repairing lesions made by ulcers, especially by a plastic operation.
&Verbar;Herr: A title of respect given to gentlemen in Germany, equivalent to the English Mister.
Histoh\u00e6matin: One of a class of respiratory pigments, widely distributed in the animal kingdom, capable of ready oxidation and reduction.
Hereditary: Descended, or capable of descending, from an ancestor to an heir at law; received or passing by inheritance, or that must pass by inheritance; as, an hereditary estate or crown.
Homacanth: Having the dorsal fin spines symmetrical, and in the same line; -- said of certain fishes.
hard-and-fast: invariable; firmly established; as, hard-and-fast regulations.
hemolysis: The lysis of erythrocytes with the release of hemoglobin; the breaking apart of red blood cells in the blood.
Hemi-demi-semiquaver: A short note, equal to one fourth of a semiquaver, or the sixty-fourth part of a whole note.
Hawebake: Probably, the baked berry of the hawthorn tree, that is, coarse fare. See 1st Haw, 2.
&Verbar;Hyracoidea: An order of small hoofed mammals, comprising the single living genus Hyrax.
Herdman: The owner or keeper of a herd or of herds; one employed in tending a herd of cattle.
Haidingerite: A mineral consisting chiefly of the arseniate of lime; -- so named in honor of W. Haidinger, of Vienna.
Herschelian: Of or relating to Sir William Herschel; as, the Herschelian telescope.
Histologic: Pertaining to histology, or to the microscopic structure of the tissues of living organisms.
Haffle: To stammer; to speak unintelligibly; to prevaricate.
Herapathite: The sulphate of iodoquinine, a substance crystallizing in thin plates remarkable for their effects in polarizing light.
Hircic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, mutton suet; -- applied by Chevreul to an oily acid which was obtained from mutton suet, and to which he attributed the peculiar taste and smell of that substance. The substance has also been called hircin.
hypertonic: Having a higher osmotic pressure than a comparison solution; -- of an aqueous solution.  Increasing the concentration of dissolved solids increases the osmotic pressure, and thus the tonicity of a solution.  Opposite of hypotonic and contrasting with isotonic.
&Verbar;Hemionus: A wild ass found in Tibet; the kiang.
Heliolite: A fossil coral of the genus Heliolites, having twelve-rayed cells. It is found in the Silurian rocks.
homework: preparatory school work done outside school (especially at home).
hawks-beard: Any of various plants of the genus Crepis having loose heads of yellow flowers on top of a long branched leafy stem; found in the Northern hemisphere.
Hair grass: A grass with very slender leaves or branches; as the Agrostis scabra, and several species of Aira or Deschampsia.
Hydrosulphite: A saline compound of hydrosulphurous acid and a base.
Hygrophthalmic: Serving to moisten the eye; -- sometimes applied to the lachrymal ducts.
Ha-ha: A sunk fence; a fence, wall, or ditch, not visible till one is close upon it.
hemming-stitch: a stitch used in sewing hems on skirts and dresses.
Hop: To gather hops. [Perhaps only in the form Hopping, vb. n.]
&Verbar;Hydrophyllium: One of the flat, leaflike, protective zooids, covering other zooids of certain Siphonophora.
Hydrophore: An instrument used for the purpose of obtaining specimens of water from any desired depth, as in a river, a lake, or the ocean.
Hegel: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, a German writer (1770-1831).
Hydrosorbic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from sorbic acid when this takes up hydrogen; as, hydrosorbic acid.
Heddle-eye: The eye or loop formed in each heddle to receive a warp thread.
Hydro-: A combining form from Gr. &unr_;, &unr_;, water (see Hydra).
Husbandage: The commission or compensation allowed to a ship's husband.
Hemuse: The roebuck in its third year.
Hybridism: The state or quality of being hybrid.
Headsman: An executioner who cuts off heads.
Hypobranchial: Pertaining to the segment between the basibranchial and the ceratobranchial in a branchial arch.
Hamlet: A small village; a little cluster of houses in the country.
Humite: A mineral of a transparent vitreous brown color, found in the ejected masses of Vesuvius. It is a silicate of iron and magnesia, containing fluorine.
hideout: a hiding place; usually a remote place used by outlaws.
Hydrocele: A collection of serous fluid in the areolar texture of the scrotum or in the coverings, especially in the serous sac, investing the testicle or the spermatic cord; dropsy of the testicle.
Hydrothermal: Of or pertaining to hot water; -- used esp. with reference to the action of heated waters in dissolving, redepositing, and otherwise producing mineral changes within the crust of the globe.
head-in-the-clouds: unable to concentrate on matters at hand; flighty[2].
Hockle: To hamstring; to hock; to hough.
Haloid: Resembling salt; -- said of certain binary compounds consisting of a metal united to a negative element or radical, and now chiefly applied to the chlorides, bromides, iodides, and sometimes also to the fluorides and cyanides.
Hygrodeik: A form of hygrometer having wet and dry bulb thermometers, with an adjustable index showing directly the percentage of moisture in the air, etc.
Hessian: A native or inhabitant of Hesse.
hirudinean: Any of a number of carnivorous or bloodsucking aquatic or terrestrial worms typically having a sucker at each end.
Housemate: One who dwells in the same house with another.
Hoistway: An opening for the hoist, or elevator, in the floor of a wareroom.
Hencoop: A coop or cage for hens.
Hearse: To inclose in a hearse; to entomb.
&Verbar;Hesperidium: A large berry with a thick rind, as a lemon or an orange.
hyponym: a word that is more specific (less abstract) than a given word; a term designating a class which is a subtype of the given word; a subcategory; a subtype.  Inverse of hypernym; as, “dog” is a hyponym of “mammal”, and “mammal” is a hyponym of “vertebrate”.
Harmless: Free from harm; unhurt; as, to give bond to save another harmless.
Hammock: A swinging couch or bed, usually made of netting or canvas about six feet long and three feet wide, suspended by clews or cords at the ends.
Hardtack: A name given by soldiers and sailors to a kind of unleavened hard biscuit or sea bread.  Called also pilot biscuit, pilot bread, ship biscuit and ship bread
Hundred: Ten times ten; five score; as, a hundred dollars.
Horn: To furnish with horns; to give the shape of a horn to.
Holophotal: Causing no loss of light; -- applied to reflectors which throw back the rays of light without perceptible loss.
Holophrastic: Expressing a phrase or sentence in a single word, -- as is the case in the aboriginal languages of America.
Hayfield: A field where grass for hay has been cut; a meadow.
Holland: A kind of linen first manufactured in Holland; a linen fabric used for window shades, children's garments, etc.; as, brown or unbleached hollands.
Homestead: The home place; a home and the inclosure or ground immediately connected with it.
hickey: A device used to adapt a lighting fixture for mounting in an outlet box, or on a pipe.
Hygrine: An alkaloid associated with cocaine in coca leaves (Erythroxylon coca), and extracted as a thick, yellow oil, having a pungent taste and odor.
hypha: any of the threadlike filaments forming the mycelium of a fungus.  See hyphae.
humidify: to render (gases, especially air) humid or to increase the moisture content of; as, We have a machine that humidifies the air in the house.
Hypochondria: An excessive concern about one's own health, particularly a morbid worry about illnesses which a person imagines are affecting him, often focusing on specific symptoms; also called hypochondriasis.
Hemp: A plant of the genus Cannabis (Cannabis sativa), the fibrous skin or bark of which is used for making cloth and cordage.  The name is also applied to various other plants yielding fiber.
Headstone: The principal stone in a foundation; the chief or corner stone.
Half blood: The relation between persons born of the same father or of the same mother, but not of both; as, a brother or sister of the half blood. See Blood, n., 2 and 4.
Hanover: the English royal house that reigned from 1714 to 1901.
Halfcock: To set the cock of (a firearm) at the first notch.
&Verbar;Heptandria: A Linnæan class of plants having seven stamens.
hawsehole: a hole in the bow of a ship, through which the anchor rope or cable passes.
Halve: To divide into two equal parts; as, to halve an apple; to be or form half of.
Hottentotism: A term employed to describe one of the varieties of stammering.
&Verbar;Het\u00e6ra: A female paramour; a mistress, concubine, or harlot.
Heightener: One who, or that which, heightens.
Hydrocyanic: Pertaining to, or derived from the combination of, hydrogen and cyanogen.
&Verbar;Hieromnemon: The sacred secretary or recorder sent by each state belonging to the Amphictyonic Council, along with the deputy or minister.
Handbarrow: A frame or barrow, without a wheel, carried by hand.
Hemorrhage: Any discharge of blood from the blood vessels.
Hydrometeorological: Of or pertaining to hydrometeorology, or to rain, clouds, storms, etc.
&Verbar;Hypnum: The largest genus of true mosses; feather moss.
High-sounding: Pompous; noisy; ostentatious; as, high-sounding words or titles.
Hemoglobin: The normal coloring matter of the red blood corpuscles of vertebrate animals. It is composed of hematin and globulin, and is also called hæmatoglobulin. In arterial blood, it is always combined with oxygen, and is then called oxyhemoglobin. It crystallizes under different forms from different animals, and when crystallized, is called hæmatocrystallin. See Blood crystal, under Blood.
Hackle: To separate, as the coarse part of flax or hemp from the fine, by drawing it through the teeth of a hackle or hatchel.
Helxine: A genus of plants consisting of one species; a dwarf creeping mat-forming evergreen herb.
Heydeguy: A kind of country-dance or round.
&Verbar;Hyperoartia: An order of marsipobranchs including the lampreys. The suckerlike moth contains numerous teeth; the nasal opening is in the middle of the head above, but it does not connect with the mouth. See Cyclostoma, and Lamprey.
Haggada: A story, anecdote, or legend in the Talmud, to explain or illustrate the text of the Old Testament.
High-souled: Having a high or noble spirit; honorable.
Holster: A leather case for a pistol, carried by a horseman at the bow of his saddle, or worn on the person suspended from a belt or shoulder strap.
Hebrew: Of or pertaining to the Hebrews; as, the Hebrew language or rites.
Hasty pudding: A thick batter pudding made of Indian meal stirred into boiling water; mush.
Humiliate: To reduce to a lower position in one's own eyes, or in the eyes of others; to cause a loss of pride or dignity; to humble; to mortify.
high-voltage: having, operating on, or powered by high voltage; as, a high-voltage generator; a high-voltage line.
Heuristic: A heuristic method; a specific heuristic procedure.
Heptagon: A plane figure consisting of seven sides and having seven angles.
Horse-radish: A plant of the genus Nasturtium (Nasturtium Armoracia), allied to scurvy grass, having a root of a pungent taste, much used, when grated, as a condiment and in medicine.
headpin: The front pin in the triangular arrangement of ten pins.
Hobbledehoy: A youth between boy and man; an awkward, gawky young fellow .
Holohedral: Having all the planes required by complete symmetry, -- in opposition to hemihedral.
Habituate: Firmly established by custom; formed by habit; habitual.
Hydrokinetic: Of or pertaining to the motions of fluids, or the forces which produce or affect such motions; -- opposed to hydrostatic.
&Verbar;Hatteria: A New Zealand lizard, which, in anatomical character, differs widely from all other existing lizards.  It is the only living representative of the order Rhynchocephala, of which many Mesozoic fossil species are known; -- called also Sphenodon, tuatara, and Tuatera.
Horsy: Pertaining to, or suggestive of, a horse, or of horse racing; as, horsy manners; garments of fantastically horsy fashions.
Hemipode: Any bird of the genus Turnix. Various species inhabit Asia, Africa, and Australia.
Hydrocaulus: The hollow stem of a hydroid, either simple or branched. See Illust. of Gymnoblastea and Hydroidea.
Hurdlework: Work after manner of a hurdle.
Hash: To chop into small pieces; to mince and mix; as, to hash meat.
Heavy spar: Native barium sulphate or barite, -- so called because of its high specific gravity as compared with other non-metallic minerals.
Hask: A basket made of rushes or flags, as for carrying fish.
Halophyte: A plant found growing in salt marshes, or in the sea.
Hermeneutically: According to the principles of interpretation; as, a verse of Scripture was examined hermeneutically.
&Verbar;Helminthes: One of the grand divisions or branches of the animal kingdom. It is a large group including a vast number of species, most of which are parasitic. Called also Enthelminthes, Enthelmintha.
hairball: a compact mass of hair that forms in the stomach of animals as a result of licking fur; as, the cat coughed up a hairball right on the new rug.
Hateful: Manifesting hate or hatred; malignant; malevolent.
Hamburg: A commercial city of Germany, near the mouth of the Elbe.
Hast: 2d pers. sing. pres. of Have, contr. of havest.
Hasp: To shut or fasten with a hasp.
holding company: A company that controls other independently incorporated companies by ownership of most or all of their stock, but does not directly control the daily operations of those companies.
Hellespontine: Of or pertaining to the Hellespont.
Hostess: A female host; a woman who hospitably entertains guests at her house.
&Verbar;Heterodactyl\u00e6: A group of birds including the trogons.
Hazelly: Of the color of the hazelnut; of a light brown.
H\u00e6mony: A plant described by Milton as “of sovereign use against all enchantments.”
Horselaugh: A loud, boisterous laugh; a guffaw.
hazelwood: A reddish-brown wood and lumber from the heartwood of the sweet gum tree.
Huff: A swell of sudden anger or arrogance; a fit of disappointment and petulance or anger; a rage.
Hornblower: One who, or that which, blows a horn.
Holarctic: Of or pert. to the arctic regions collectively
Hallstatt: Of or pertaining to Hallstatt, Austria, or the Hallstatt civilization.
Hyperboliform: Having the form, or nearly the form, of an hyperbola.
Heteracanth: Having the spines of the dorsal fin unsymmetrical, or thickened alternately on the right and left sides.
Halloo: An exclamation to call attention or to encourage one.  Now mostly replaced by hello.
Horologiography: An account of instruments that show the hour.
Hematein: A reddish brown or violet crystalline substance, C16H12O6, got from hematoxylin by partial oxidation, and regarded as analogous to the phthaleins.
Hyetal: Of or pertaining to rain; descriptive of the distribution of rain, or of rainy regions.
Hydroxy-: A combining form, also used adjectively, indicating hydroxyl as an ingredient.
Horrent: Standing erect, as bristles; covered with bristling points; bristled; bristling.
Hyperbola: A curve formed by a section of a cone, when the cutting plane makes a greater angle with the base than the side of the cone makes. It is a plane curve such that the difference of the distances from any point of it to two fixed points, called foci, is equal to a given distance. See Focus. If the cutting plane be produced so as to cut the opposite cone, another curve will be formed, which is also an hyperbola. Both curves are regarded as branches of the same hyperbola. See Illust. of Conic section, and Focus.
Hardfern: A species of fern (Lomaria borealis), growing in Europe and Northwestern America.
Hallow: To make holy; to set apart for holy or religious use; to consecrate; to treat or keep as sacred; to reverence.
Hyperbole: A figure of speech in which the expression is an evident exaggeration of the meaning intended to be conveyed, or by which things are represented as much greater or less, better or worse, than they really are; a statement exaggerated fancifully, through excitement, or for effect.
Homogeneous: Of the same kind of nature; consisting of similar parts, or of elements of the like nature; -- opposed to heterogeneous; as, homogeneous particles, elements, or principles; homogeneous bodies.
Half tone: An intermediate or middle tone in a painting, engraving, photograph, etc.; a middle tint, neither very dark nor very light.
Hospitableness: The quality of being hospitable; hospitality.
Housewife: To manage with skill and economy, as a housewife or other female manager; to economize.
Horse-jockey: A professional rider and trainer of race horses.
Histrionize: To act; to represent on the stage, or theatrically.
Heterotopism: A deviation from the natural position; -- a term applied in the case of organs or growths which are abnormal in situation.
&Verbar;Hemiplegia: A palsy that affects one side only of the body.
Haytian: Of or pertaining to Haiti; now usually written Haitian.
Hogmanay: The old name, in Scotland, for the last day of the year, on which children go about singing, and receive a dole of bread or cakes; also, the entertainment given on that day to a visitor, or the gift given to an applicant.
Hypaxial: Beneath the axis of the skeleton; subvertebral; hyposkeletal.
Heteroclitic: Deviating from ordinary forms or rules; irregular; anomalous; abnormal.
Hurried: Urged on; hastened; going or working at speed; as, a hurried writer; a hurried life.
HDL: High density lipoprotein, a lipoprotein that transports cholesterol in the blood; high levels are thought to be associated with decreased risk of coronary heart disease and atherosclerosis; sometimes called good cholesterol.  Contrasted with LDL.
Huronian: Of or pertaining to certain non-fossiliferous rocks on the borders of Lake Huron, which are supposed to correspond in time to the latter part of the Archæan age.
Horned: Furnished with a horn or horns; furnished with a hornlike process or appendage; as, horned cattle; having some part shaped like a horn.
&Verbar;H\u00e6matocrya: The cold-blooded vertebrates. Same as Hematocrya.
Hitter: One who hits or strikes; as, a hard hitter.
Hypotenuse: The side of a right-angled triangle that is opposite to the right angle.
Heathenism: The religious system or rites of a heathen nation; idolatry; paganism.
Hydropathist: One who practices hydropathy; a water-cure doctor.
Hardbeam: A tree of the genus Carpinus, of compact, horny texture; hornbeam.
Heathenish: Of or pertaining to the heathen; resembling or characteristic of heathens.
Hominy: Maize hulled and broken, and prepared for food by being boiled in water.
Hoodlum: A young rowdy; a rough, lawless fellow; colloquially, called also hood.
&Verbar;Hadrosaurus: An American herbivorous dinosaur of great size, allied to the iguanodon. It is found in the Cretaceous formation.
Homogonous: Having all the flowers of a plant alike in respect to the stamens and pistils.
Hypnagogic: Leading to sleep; -- applied to the illusions of one who is half asleep.
Hymnography: The art or act of composing hymns.
Holoblastic: Undergoing complete segmentation; composed entirely of germinal matter, the whole of the yolk undergoing fission; -- opposed to meroblastic.
hard-pressed: facing or experiencing trouble or difficulty; as, financially hard-pressed Mexican hotels are lowering their prices; they were hard-pressed to find a substitute on short notice; -- see distressed{1}.
Hammer-harden: To harden, as a metal, by hammering it in the cold state.
Hour: The twenty-fourth part of a day; sixty minutes.
hostile takeover: the purchase of a controlling interest in a publicly-traded company against the wishes of the current management.
Harrisia: A genus of slender often treelike spiny cacti with solitary showy nocturnal white or pink flowers; Florida and Caribbean to South America.
huamachil: A common thorny tropical American tree (Pithecellobium dulce) having terminal racemes of yellow flowers followed by sickle-shaped or circinate edible pods and yielding good timber and a yellow dye and mucilaginous gum.
Half-fish: A salmon in its fifth year of growth.
Hurden: A coarse kind of linen; -- called also harden.
Hordock: An unidentified plant mentioned by Shakespeare, perhaps equivalent to burdock.
Heartbroken: Overcome by crushing sorrow; deeply grieved.
Hackly: Rough or broken, as if hacked.
Hire purchase: A contract (more fully called contract of hire with an option of purchase) in which a person hires goods for a specified period and at a fixed rent, with the added condition that if he shall retain the goods for the full period and pay all the installments of rent as they become due the contract shall determine and the title vest absolutely in him, and that if he chooses he may at any time during the term surrender the goods and be quit of any liability for future installments upon the contract. In the United States such a contract is generally treated as a conditional sale, and the term hire purchase is also sometimes applied to a contract in which the hirer is not free to avoid future liability by surrender of the goods. In England, however, if the hirer does not have this right the contract is a sale.
heinousness: the quality of being shockingly cruel and inhumane.
Helper: One who, or that which, helps, aids, assists, or relieves; as, a lay helper in a parish.
Haar: A fog; esp., a fog or mist with a chill wind.
Hexapodous: Having six feet; belonging to the Hexapoda.
Hotpress: To apply heat to, in conjunction with mechanical pressure, for the purpose of giving a smooth and glossy surface, or to express oil, etc.; as, to hotpress paper, linen, etc.
Hawkeye State: Iowa; -- a nickname of obscure origin.
Herbary: A garden of herbs; a cottage garden.
&Verbar;Hypoarion: An oval lobe beneath each of the optic lobes in many fishes; one of the inferior lobes.
heartbeat: the audible and palpable rhythmic contraction and expansion of the arteries with each beat of the heart; as, he listened to her heartbeat with a stethoscope.
H\u00e6maph\u00e6in: A brownish substance sometimes found in the blood, in cases of jaundice.
hollygrape: An ornamental evergreen shrub (Mahonia aquifolium) of the Pacific coast of North America having dark green pinnate leaves and racemes of yellow flowers followed by blue-black berries.
Haaf: The deep-sea fishing for cod, ling, and tusk, off the Shetland Isles.
Hidalgo: A title, denoting a Spanish nobleman of the lower class.
Homo-: A combining form from Gr. "omo`s, one and the same, common, joint.
Horticulture: The cultivation of a garden or orchard; the art of cultivating gardens or orchards.
Hobgoblin: A frightful goblin; an imp; a bugaboo; also, a name formerly given to the household spirit, Robin Goodfellow.
Hydrophlorone: A white, crystalline benzene derivative, C8H10O2, obtained by the reduction of phlorone.
Heemraad: In Holland, and, until the 19th century, also in Cape Colony, a council to assist a local magistrate in the government of rural districts; hence, also, a member of such a council.
Hydraulics: That branch of science, or of engineering, which treats of fluids in motion, especially of water, its action in rivers and canals, the works and machinery for conducting or raising it, its use as a prime mover, and the like.
Hygrometry: That branch of physics which relates to the determination of the humidity of bodies, particularly of the atmosphere, with the theory and use of the instruments constructed for this purpose.
Handed: With hands joined; hand in hand.
Honorary: Done as a sign or evidence of honor; as, honorary services.
Hoarseness: Harshness or roughness of voice or sound, due to mucus collected on the vocal cords, or to swelling or looseness of the cords.
humourous: same as humorous; causing amusement or laughter.
hipline: the line formed by measuring the hip at its greatest part.
Hyemation: The passing of a winter in a particular place; a wintering.
Himantoglossum: A small genus of terrestrial orchids of Europe and Mediterranean region.
Hatte: pres. & imp. sing. & pl. of Hote, to be called. See Hote.
Heyday: The time of triumph and exultation; hence, joy, high spirits, frolicsomeness; wildness.
&Verbar;Heliozoa: An order of fresh-water rhizopods having a more or less globular form, with slender radiating pseudopodia; the sun animalcule.
Housewarming: A feast or merry-making made by or for a family or business firm on taking possession of a new house or premises.
Hemadrometry: The act of measuring the velocity with which the blood circulates in the arteries; hæmotachometry.
Hawked: Curved like a hawk's bill; crooked.
Husbandry: Care of domestic affairs; economy; domestic management; thrift.
hallowed: belonging to or derived from or associated with a divine power; made holy.  Opposite of unholy.
Hercynian: Of or pertaining to an extensive forest in Germany, of which there are still portions in Swabia and the Hartz mountains.
Hopperdozer: An appliance for the destruction of insects, consisting of a shallow iron box, containing kerosene or coated with tar or other sticky substance, which may be mounted on wheels.
Hostilize: To make hostile; to cause to become an enemy.
Hot-blooded: Having hot blood; excitable; high-spirited; irritable; ardent; passionate.
&Verbar;Hypotarsus: A process on the posterior side of the tarsometatarsus of many birds; the calcaneal process.
Harbinger: To usher in; to be a harbinger of.
Helpful: Furnishing help; giving aid; assistant; useful; salutary.
Hoidenish: Like, or appropriate to, a hoiden.
Hydrometer: An instrument for determining the specific gravities of liquids, and thence the strength spirituous liquors, saline solutions, etc.
hardbound: same as hardback; -- used of books.
hardboard: a cheap hard material made from wood chips that are pressed together and bound with synthetic resin to form sheets, used in construction and various other purposes; -- called also particle board and chipboard.
Hagiarchy: A sacred government; government by holy orders of men.
Homostyled: Having only one form of pistils; -- said of the flowers of some plants.
Hygroscopicity: The property possessed by vegetable tissues of absorbing or discharging moisture according to circumstances.
Hansom: A light, low, two-wheeled covered carriage with the driver's seat elevated behind, the reins being passed over the top.
Horse-litter: A carriage hung on poles, and borne by and between two horses.
&Verbar;Hospitium: An inn; a lodging; a hospice.
Haberdashery: The goods and wares sold by a haberdasher; also (Fig.), trifles.
huastorium: a rootlike attachment in parasitic plants that penetrates and obtains food from the host.
Hemstitch: To ornament at the head of a broad hem by drawing out a few parallel threads, and fastening the cross threads in successive small clusters; as, to hemstitch a handkerchief.
Hereunto: Unto this; up to this time; hereto.
heavyweight: a wrestler who weighs more than 214 pounds.
hesitating: holding back because of doubt or lack of confidence.
hagiographic: of or pertaining to the Hagiographa, or to sacred writings; -- same as hagiographal.
Hyphantria: A genus of moths whose larvae are called fall webworms.
Horseshoeing: The act or employment of shoeing horses.
headword: a word that is qualified by a modifier.
Horse power: The power which a horse exerts.
Hypothenal: Of or pertaining to the prominent part of the palm of the hand above the base of the little finger, or a corresponding part in the forefoot of an animal; as, the hypothenar eminence.
Homesteader: One who has entered upon a portion of the public land with the purpose of acquiring ownership of it under provisions of the homestead law, so called; one who has acquired a homestead in this manner.
Halimas: The feast of All Saints; Hallowmas.
Humbleness: The quality of being humble; humility; meekness.
Hastate: Shaped like the head of a halberd; triangular, with the basal angles or lobes spreading; as, a hastate leaf.
Heracleonite: A follower of Heracleon of Alexandria, a Judaizing Gnostic, in the early history of the Christian church.
Hypozoic: Anterior in age to the lowest rocks which contain organic remains.
Hyp\u00e6thral: Exposed to the air; wanting a roof; -- applied to a building or part of a building.
Hiver: One who collects bees into a hive.
Horribleness: The state or quality of being horrible; dreadfulness; hideousness.
Hydriform: Having the form or structure of a hydra.
Hemorrhoidal: Of or pertaining to, or of the nature of, hemorrhoids.
Hinayana: a major school of Buddhism teaching personal salvation through one's own efforts.
Harvestry: The act of harvesting; also, that which is harvested.
hell-bent: recklessly determined; as, hell-bent on winning.
Hausse: A kind of graduated breech sight for a small arm, or a cannon.
Hindleys screw: A screw cut on a solid whose sides are arcs of the periphery of a wheel into the teeth of which the screw is intended to work. It is named from the person who first used the form.
Hoot down: To shout down; to cause (a speaker) to cease trying to speak by loud derisive shouts.
Hebdomad: A week; a period of seven days.
Have: To hold in possession or control; to own; as, he has a farm.
Hypercarbureted: Having an excessive proportion of carbonic acid; -- said of bicarbonates or acid carbonates.
Harpy: A fabulous winged monster, ravenous and filthy, having the face of a woman and the body of a vulture, with long claws, and the face pale with hunger.  Some writers mention two, others three.
Heath: A low shrub (Erica vulgaris or Calluna vulgaris), with minute evergreen leaves, and handsome clusters of pink flowers.  It is used in Great Britain for brooms, thatch, beds for the poor, and for heating ovens.  It is also called heather, and ling.
hyperspace: A mathematical space having more than three dimensions.  It is a mathematical construct and is not intended to represent the structure of the common physical space in which matter exists.
Hydracid: An acid containing hydrogen; -- sometimes applied to distinguish acids like hydrochloric, hydrofluoric, and the like, which contain no oxygen, from the oxygen acids or oxacids. See Acid.
H\u00e6cceity: Literally, this-ness.  A scholastic term to express individuality or singleness; as, this book.
&Verbar;Hamadryas: The sacred baboon of Egypt (Cynocephalus Hamadryas).
Hypallage: A figure consisting of a transference of attributes from their proper subjects to others. Thus Virgil says, “dare classibus austros,” to give the winds to the fleets, instead of dare classibus austris, to give the fleets to the winds.
Hepato-pancreas: A digestive gland in Crustacea, Mollusca, etc., usually called the liver, but different from the liver of vertebrates.
hook-and-ladder truck: A firefighting truck equipped with a ladder extendable to great length, for access to the upper stories of buildings; it also carries other firefighting equipment; called also ladder truck.
&Verbar;Herzog: A member of the highest rank of nobility in Germany and Austria, corresponding to the British duke.
Homotype: That which has the same fundamental type of structure with something else; thus, the right arm is the homotype of the right leg; one arm is the homotype of the other, etc.
Hamite: A descendant of Ham, Noah's second son. See Gen. x. 6-20.
Hyracotherium: An extinct horse genus, formerly called genus Eohippus.
hit on: To make sexual advances toward; -- usually of men making advances to women.
Hocco: The crested curassow; -- called also royal pheasant. See Curassow.
halfback: A person who plays the position of halfback{2} on a football team.
Homotypy: A term suggested by Haeckel to be instead of serial homology. See Homotype.
Herringbone: Pertaining to, or like, the spine of a herring; especially, characterized by an arrangement of work in rows of parallel lines, which in the alternate rows slope in different directions.
Ham: To act with exaggerated voice and gestures; to overact.
hipped: having hips; or, having hips of a specified type; -- used in combination; as, wide-hipped.
Hilt: A handle; especially, the handle of a sword, dagger, or the like.
Hag: A small wood, or part of a wood or copse, which is marked off or inclosed for felling, or which has been felled.
housecoat: a loose dressing gown for women.
Hay: To cut and cure grass for hay.
Heroism: The qualities characteristic of a hero, as courage, bravery, fortitude, unselfishness, etc.; the display of such qualities.
Hedysarum: A genus of herbs of Northern temperate regions.
Harmonize: To adjust in fit proportions; to cause to agree; to show the agreement of; to reconcile the apparent contradiction of.
horse-trade: to negotiate with much give and take.
Hat: A covering for the head; esp., one with a crown and brim, made of various materials, and worn by men or women for protecting the head from the sun or weather, or for ornament.
Haw: To cause to turn, as a team, to the near side, or toward the driver; as, to haw a team of oxen.
Hummer: One who, or that which, hums; one who applauds by humming.
Harbor master: An officer charged with the duty of executing the regulations respecting the use of a harbor.
Hydrofluoric: Pertaining to, or containing, hydrogen and fluorine; fluohydric; as, hydrofluoric acid.
Hypocritical: Of or pertaining to a hypocrite, or to hypocrisy; as, a hypocriticalperson; a hypocritical look; a hypocritical action.
Hammerable: Capable of being/formed or shapeo by a hammer.
&Verbar;Hippobosca: A genus of dipterous insects including the horsefly or horse tick.
Helicograph: An instrument for drawing spiral lines on a plane.
Homochromous: Having all the florets in the same flower head of the same color.
Halberd: An ancient long-handled weapon, of which the head had a point and several long, sharp edges, curved or straight, and sometimes additional points. The heads were sometimes of very elaborate form.
Heterocyst: A cell larger than the others, and of different appearance, occurring in certain algæ related to nostoc.
Hudge: An iron bucket for hoisting coal or ore.
Hummel: Having no awns or no horns; as, hummelcorn; a hummel cow.
hip: Aware of the latest ideas, trends, fashions, and developments in popular music and entertainment culture; not square; -- same as hep.
Hearth: The pavement or floor of brick, stone, or metal in a chimney, on which a fire is made; the floor of a fireplace; also, a corresponding part of a stove.
Heron: Any wading bird of the genus Ardea and allied genera, of the family Ardeidæ. The herons have a long, sharp bill, and long legs and toes, with the claw of the middle toe toothed. The common European heron (Ardea cinerea) is remarkable for its directly ascending flight, and was formerly hunted with the larger falcons.
Hesitant: Not prompt in deciding or acting; hesitating.
Hysteria: A nervous affection, occurring almost exclusively in women, in which the emotional and reflex excitability is exaggerated, and the will power correspondingly diminished, so that the patient loses control over the emotions, becomes the victim of imaginary sensations, and often falls into paroxism or fits.
Hickwall: The lesser spotted woodpecker (Dendrocopus minor) of Europe.
hand-to-hand: close to one's adversary; -- of combat; as, hand-to-hand fighting.
hoped-for: expected and desired.  Contrasted with unexpected.
Hemacite: A composition made from blood, mixed with mineral or vegetable substances, used for making buttons, door knobs, etc.
Hearty: Comrade; boon companion; good fellow; -- a term of familiar address and fellowship among sailors.
Haliotoid: Like or pertaining to the genus Haliotis; ear-shaped.
holograph: To produce a holographic image of, by holography.
hatemonger: one who arouses hatred for others by speech or writing.
Hopyard: A field where hops are raised.
Hayrake: A rake for collecting hay; especially, a large rake drawn by a horse or horses.
Haunt: A place to which one frequently resorts; as, drinking saloons are the haunts of tipplers; a den is the haunt of wild beasts.
houseful: as many as a house will accommodate; as, they entertained a houseful of guests.
Hele: To hide; to cover; to roof.
Hermaphroditism: The union of the two sexes in the same individual, or the combination of some of their characteristics or organs in one individual.
Hierologist: One versed in, or whostudies, hierology.
Helm: To cover or furnish with a helm or helmet.
Half-bound: Having only the back and corners in leather, as a book.
Haulabout: A bargelike vessel with steel hull, large hatchways, and coal transporters, for coaling war vessels from its own hold or from other colliers.
Haircloth: Stuff or cloth made wholly or in part of hair.
Hustings: A court formerly held in several cities of England; specif., a court held in London, before the lord mayor, recorder, and sheriffs, to determine certain classes of suits for the recovery of lands within the city. In the progress of law reform this court has become unimportant.
Herdswoman: A woman who tends a herd.
hen-of-the-woods: A large grayish-brown edible fungus (Polyporus frondosus) forming a mass of overlapping caps at the base of trees that somewhat resembles a hen.
Howsoever: In what manner soever; to whatever degree or extent; however.
Honewort: An umbelliferous plant of the genus Sison (Sison Amomum); -- so called because used to cure a swelling called a hone.
Hockday: A holiday commemorating the expulsion of the Danes, formerly observed on the second Tuesday after Easter; -- called also hocktide.
Holstein-Friesian: A breed of dairy cattle from North Holland and Friesland; they have a black and white color to their fur.
housekeep: to take care of all household-related business.
Hypophosphorous: Pertaining to, or containing, phosphorus in a lower state of oxidation than in phosphoric compounds; as, hypophosphorous acid.
Hydrated: Formed into a hydrate; combined with water.
heads-up: a warning to be prepared for an imminent event.
Heppelwhite: Designating a light and elegant style developed in England under George III., chiefly by Messrs. A. Heppelwhite & Co.
Hermitical: Pertaining to, or suited for, a hermit.
Heredity: Hereditary transmission of the physical and psychical qualities of parents to their offspring; the biological law by which living beings tend to repeat their characteristics in their descendants. See Pangenesis.
Hogging: Drooping at the ends; arching;-in distinction from sagging.
Hypnotize: To induce hypnotism in; to place in a state of hypnotism.
Hereditament: Any species of property that may be inherited; lands, tenements, anything corporeal or incorporeal, real, personal, or mixed, that may descend to an heir.
honour: Same as honor; -- chiefly British usage.
Huntsmanship: The art or practice of hunting, or the qualification of a hunter.
Helminth: An intestinal worm, or wormlike intestinal parasite; one of the Helminthes.
Hemstitched: Having a broad hem separated from the body of the article by a line of open work; as, a hemistitched handkerchief.
Hypocrite: One who plays a part; especially, one who, for the purpose of winning approbation of favor, puts on a fair outside seeming; one who feigns to be other and better than he is; a false pretender to virtue or piety; one who simulates virtue or piety.
Harder: A South African mullet, salted for food.
Hetero-: A combining form signifying other, other than usual, different; as, heteroclite, heterodox, heterogamous.
Harden: To become hard or harder; to acquire solidity, or more compactness; as, mortar hardens by drying.
Hematinic: Any substance, such as an iron salt or organic compound containing iron, which when ingested tends to increase the hemoglobin contents of the blood.
Honor: To regard or treat with honor, esteem, or respect; to revere; to treat with deference and submission; when used of the Supreme Being, to reverence; to adore; to worship.
H\u00e6matachometer: A form of apparatus (somewhat different from the hemadrometer) for measuring the velocity of the blood.
Harm: To hurt; to injure; to damage; to wrong.
Harl: A filamentous substance; especially, the filaments of flax or hemp.
Hare: To excite; to tease, harass, or worry; to harry.
Hard: A ford or passage across a river or swamp.
Hyaloid: Resembling glass; vitriform; transparent; hyaline; as, the hyaloid membrane, a very delicate membrane inclosing the vitreous humor of the eye.
Hexdecyl: The essential radical, C16H33, of hecdecane.
Humanify: To make human; to invest with a human personality; to incarnate.
Hary: To draw; to drag; to carry off by violence.
Hyoscyamine: An alkaloid found in henbane (Hyoscyamus niger), and regarded as its active principle. It is also found with other alkaloids in the thorn apple and deadly nightshade. It is extracted as a white crystalline substance, with a sharp, offensive taste. Hyoscyamine is isomeric with atropine, is very poisonous, and is used as a medicine for neuralgia, like belladonna. Called also hyoscyamia, duboisine, etc.
Hippocratism: The medical philosophy or system of Hippocrates.
Hart: A stag; the male of the red deer. See the Note under Buck.
Harp: To play on, as a harp; to play (a tune) on the harp; to develop or give expression to by skill and art; to sound forth as from a harp; to hit upon.
Hornwort: An aquatic plant (Ceratophyllum), with finely divided leaves.
Harlequin: To remove or conjure away, as by a harlequin's trick.
hackery: A cart with wooden wheels, drawn by bullocks.
High-proof: Highly rectified; very strongly alcoholic; as, high-proof spirits.
Hellish: Of or pertaining to hell; like hell; infernal; malignant; wicked; detestable; diabolical.
Housewifely: Pertaining or appropriate to a housewife; domestic; economical; prudent.
Hornwork: An outwork composed of two demibastions joined by a curtain. It is connected with the works in rear by long wings.
hovercraft: A vehicle that rides over water or land supported by the pressure of a stream of air generated by downward-thrusting fans, and is propelled forward by an air propeller; also called ACV and air-cushioned vehicle.
Hormone: A chemical substance formed in one organ and carried in the circulation to another organ on which it exerts a specific effect on cells at a distance from the producing cells; thus, pituitary hormones produced in the brain may have effects on cells in distant parts of the body..
Heavenly-minded: Having the thoughts and affections placed on, or suitable for, heaven and heavenly objects; devout; godly; pious.
Hydrocephalus: An accumulation of liquid within the cavity of the cranium, especially within the ventricles of the brain; dropsy of the brain. It is due usually to tubercular meningitis. When it occurs in infancy, it often enlarges the head enormously.
Householder: The master or head of a family; one who occupies a house with his family.
hitting: The act of striking one thing against another; as, repeated hitting raised a large bruise
Harvey process: A process of hardening the face of steel, as armor plates, invented by Hayward A. Harvey of New Jersey, consisting in the additional carburizing of the face of a piece of low carbon steel by subjecting it to the action of carbon under long-continued pressure at a very high heat, and then to a violent chilling, as by a spray of cold water. This process gives an armor plate a thick surface of extreme hardness supported by material gradually decreasing in hardness to the unaltered soft steel at the back.
Halter-sack: A term of reproach, implying that one is fit to be hanged.
hag-ridden: Ridden by a hag or witch;
Heliotrope: An instrument or machine for showing when the sun arrived at the tropics and equinoctial line.
handoff: A football play in which one player hands the ball to a teammate.
high-pitched: high in pitch or frequency; -- used of sounds and voices.  Opposite of low.
Homeopathic: Of or pertaining to homeopathy; according to the principles of homeopathy.
Hawk-eyed: Having very keen vision; sharp-sighted; discerning.
hit man: A professional murderer, esp. one working for a criminal organization; also called torpedo.
Hypsometry: That branch of the science of geodesy which has to do with the measurement of heights, either absolutely with reference to the sea level, or relatively.
Halcyon: Pertaining to, or resembling, the halcyon, which was anciently said to lay her eggs in nests on or near the sea during the calm weather about the winter solstice.
Hordeic: Pertaining to, or derived from, barley; as, hordeic acid, an acid identical or isomeric with lauric acid.
Hordein: A peculiar starchy matter contained in barley. It is a complex mixture.
Halacha: The general term for the Hebrew oral or traditional law; one of two branches of exposition in the Midrash.  See Midrash.
Head-cheese: A dish made of portions of the head, or head and feet, of swine, cut up fine, seasoned, and pressed into a cheeselike mass.
Heterosporic: Producing two kinds of spores unlike each other.
Horatian: Of or pertaining to Horace, the Latin poet, or resembling his style.
handline: a fishing line managed principally by hand.
Haiduck: Formerly, a mercenary foot soldier in Hungary, now, a halberdier of a Hungarian noble, or an attendant in German or Hungarian courts.
Herbless: Destitute of herbs or of vegetation.
Heretical: Containing heresy; of the nature of, or characterized by, heresy.
Hydrocarbonaceous: Of the nature, or containing, hydrocarbons.
Haminoea: A common genus of marine bubble shells of the Pacific coast of North America.
Hereof: Of this; concerning this; from this; hence.
Hobo: A professional tramp; one who spends his life traveling from place to place, esp. by stealing rides on trains, and begging for a living.
Haikwan tael: A Chinese weight (1/10 catty) equivalent to 11/3 oz. or 37.801 g.
Hokkaido: The northernmost of the main islands of Japan.  Together with the islands of Honshu, Kyushu and Shikoku it forms the bulk of the land area of Japan.
handbrake: a brake operated by hand, used to stop a vehicle or keep it stationary; it usually operates by a mechanical linkage.
Holluschickie: A young male fur seal, esp. one from three to six years old; -- called also bachelor, because prevented from breeding by the older full-grown males.
Home run: a complete circuit of the bases made by the batter without being put out and without an error on the play; also, the hit on which the batter makes such a circuit; a four-base hit.
Hot-brained: Ardent in temper; violent; rash; impetuous; as, hot-brained youth.
Horopter: The line or surface in which are situated all the points which are seen single while the point of sight, or the adjustment of the eyes, remains unchanged.
Habituation: The act of habituating, or accustoming; the state of being habituated.
Hydatid: A membranous sac or bladder filled with a pellucid fluid, found in various parts of the bodies of animals, but unconnected with the tissues. It is usually formed by parasitic worms, esp. by larval tapeworms, as Echinococcus and Cœnurus. See these words in the Vocabulary.
Hospitaler: One residing in a hospital, for the purpose of receiving the poor, the sick, and strangers.
Hubbub: A loud noise of many confused voices; a tumult; uproar.
Holly: A tree or shrub of the genus Ilex. The European species (Ilex Aquifolium) is best known, having glossy green leaves, with a spiny, waved edge, and bearing berries that turn red or yellow about Michaelmas.
Hummocking: The process of forming hummocks in the collision of Arctic ice.
Homopolic: In promorphology, pertaining to or exhibiting that kind of organic form, in which the stereometric ground form is a pyramid, with similar poles. See Promorphology.
Hypnogenic: Relating to the production of hypnotic sleep; as, the so-called hypnogenic pressure points, pressure upon which is said to cause an attack of hypnotic sleep.
Hepta: A combining form from Gr. "epta`, seven.
Healthless: Without health, whether of body or mind; infirm.
Houve: A head covering of various kinds; a hood; a coif; a cap.
&Verbar;Halteres: Balancers; the rudimentary hind wings of Diptera.
Hyper-: A prefix signifying over, above; as, hyperphysical, hyperthyrion; also, above measure, abnormally great, excessive; as, hyperæmia, hyperbola, hypercritical, hypersecretion.
Hard-featured: Having coarse, unattractive or stern features.
Hailshot: Small shot which scatter like hailstones.
humiliated: brought low in condition or status; reduced in dignity; humbled; mortified.
Headdress: A covering or ornament for the head; a headtire; as, chiefs among the plains Indians had elaborate long headdresses with many feathers.
higher: advanced in complexity or elaboration; as, higher mathematics.
&Verbar;Histolysis: The decay and dissolution of the organic tissues and of the blood.
&Verbar;Hexapoda: The true, or six-legged, insects; insects other than myriapods and arachnids.
Horehound: A plant of the genus Marrubium (Marrubium vulgare), which has a bitter taste, and is a weak tonic, used as a household remedy for colds, coughing, etc.
H\u00fcbner: A mineral of brownish black color, occurring in columnar or foliated masses. It is native manganese tungstate.
Hypo: Sodium hyposulphite, or thiosulphate, a solution of which is used as a bath to wash out the unchanged silver salts in a picture.
Hellhag: A hag of or fit for hell.
Horoscopy: The art or practice of casting horoscopes, or observing the disposition of the stars, with a view to prediction events.
Hydrofluosilicate: A salt of hydrofluosilic acid; a silicofluoride. See Silicofluoride.
Hexagon: A plane figure of six angles.
&Verbar;Hypotyposis: A vivid, picturesque description of scenes or events.
Hoggery: Hoggish character or manners; selfishness; greed; beastliness.
Hieratic: Consecrated to sacred uses; sacerdotal; pertaining to priests.
Hepatology: The science which treats of the liver; a treatise on the liver.
Heave offering: An offering or oblation heaved up or elevated before the altar, as the shoulder of the peace offering. See Wave offering.
Hesperidin: A glucoside found in ripe and unripe fruit (as the orange), and extracted as a white crystalline substance.
housebreak: to train a pet to live cleanly in a house, especially by training it to defecate and urinate in designated boxes.
half-baked: Insufficiently or poorly planned or thought out; impractical or unrealistic; as, a half-baked proposal; half-baked ideas; -- of plans, theories, proposals, etc.
hematolysis: The lysis of erythrocytes in the blood with the release of hemoglobin.
&Verbar;Holmos: A name given to a vase having a rounded body
Hoult: A piece of woodland; a small wood. [Obs.] See Holt.
Harpoon: To strike, catch, or kill with a harpoon.
Hydrosalt: A salt supposed to be formed by a hydracid and a base.
Hypothetist: One who proposes or supports an hypothesis.
Hackneyman: A man who lets horses and carriages for hire.
Honeydew: A sweet, saccharine substance, found on the leaves of trees and other plants in small drops, like dew. Two substances have been called by this name; one exuded from the plants, and the other secreted by certain insects, esp. aphids.
Hesitate: To utter with hesitation or to intimate by a reluctant manner.
Hoity-toity: Thoughtless; giddy; flighty; also, haughty; patronizing; as, to be in hoity-toity spirits, or to assume hoity-toity airs; used also as an exclamation, denoting surprise or disapprobation, with some degree of contempt.
Horribly: In a manner to excite horror; dreadfully; terribly.
Handmade: Manufactured by hand; as, handmade shoes.  Contrasted with machine-made.
Hemmel: A shed or hovel for cattle.
handbasket: a container that is usually woven and has handles.
Half-breed: A person who is half-blooded; the offspring of parents of different races, especially of the American Indian and the white race.
Histoid: Resembling the normal tissues; as, histoid tumors.
Heartener: One who, or that which, heartens, animates, or stirs up.
Horrible: Exciting, or tending to excite, horror or fear; dreadful; terrible; shocking; hideous; as, a horrible sight; a horrible story; a horrible murder.
hemolytic: of or pertaining to hemolysis; causing hemolysis.
Heeltap: To add a piece of leather to the heel of (a shoe, boot, etc.)
half-track: a half-tracked vehicle; -- used mostly of armored military vehicles.
Hideous: Frightful, shocking, or offensive to the eyes; dreadful to behold; as, a hideous monster; hideous looks.
Harvest-home: The gathering and bringing home of the harvest; the time of harvest.
Homonymy: Sameness of name or designation; identity in relations.
Harem: The apartments or portion of the house allotted to females in Mohammedan families.
Hobbly: Rough; uneven; causing one to hobble; as a hobbly road.
Hatchettine: Mineral tallow; a waxy or spermaceti-like substance, commonly of a greenish yellow color.
Half-moon: The moon at the quarters, when half its disk appears illuminated.
Hindu: Same as Hindoo.  This is now the more commonly used spelling.
Hobble: An unequal gait; a limp; a halt; as, he has a hobble in his gait.
Holograph: A document, as a letter, deed, or will, wholly in the handwriting of the person from whom it proceeds and whose act it purports to be.
Hummock: A rounded knoll or hillock; a rise of ground of no great extent, above a level surface.
Hurler: One who hurls, or plays at hurling.
&Verbar;Hyph\u00e6: The long, branching filaments of which the mycelium (and the greater part of the plant) of a fungus is formed.  They are also found enveloping the gonidia of lichens, making up a large part of their structure.
Hawk moth: Any moth of the family Sphingidæ, of which there are numerous genera and species.  They are large, handsome moths with long narrow forewings capable of powerful flight and hovering over flowers to feed.  They fly mostly at twilight and hover about flowers like a humming bird, sucking the honey by means of a long, slender proboscis.  The larvæ are large, hairless caterpillars ornamented with green and other bright colors, and often with a caudal spine. See Sphinx, also Tobacco worm, and Tomato worm.
Heterocarpism: The power of producing two kinds of reproductive bodies, as in Amphicarpæa, in which besides the usual pods, there are others underground.
Humming: A sound like that made by bees; a low, murmuring sound; a hum.
Herpetotomist: One who dissects, or studies the anatomy of, reptiles.
Hagberry: A plant of the genus Prunus (Prunus Padus); the bird cherry.
Homeopathist: A believer in, or practitioner of, homeopathy.
Hariali grass: The East Indian name of the Cynodon Dactylon; dog's-grass.
Hydrography: The art of measuring and describing the sea, lakes, rivers, and other waters, with their phenomena.
Homodynamous: Pertaining to, or involving, homodynamy; as, successive or homodynamous parts in plants and animals.
Hydro-electric: Pertaining to, employed in, or produced by, the evolution of electricity by means of a battery in which water or steam is used.
Hydrobiplane: A hydro-aëroplane having two supporting planes.
Huller: One who, or that which, hulls; especially, an agricultural machine for removing the hulls from grain; a hulling machine.
&Verbar;Honv\u00e9d: The Hungarian army in the revolutionary war of 1848-49.
H\u00e6matitic: Of a blood-red color; crimson; (Bot.) brownish red.
Highly: In a high manner, or to a high degree; very much; as, highly esteemed.
Hackmatack: The American larch (Larix Americana), a coniferous tree with slender deciduous leaves; also, its heavy, close-grained timber. Called also tamarack.
Hairbreadth: Having the breadth of a hair; very narrow; as, a hairbreadth escape.
Humeral: Of or pertaining to the humerus, or upper part of the arm; brachial.
Handball: A small ball, usually made of rubber, thrown or struck with the hand in various games.
Herpetology: The natural history of reptiles; that branch of zoölogy which relates to reptiles, including their structure, classification, and habits.
hoofing: a dance in which the steps are more important than gestures or postures.
&Verbar;Hydrobranchiata: An extensive artificial division of gastropod mollusks, including those that breathe by gills, as contrasted with the Pulmonifera.
Hectorism: The disposition or the practice of a hector; a bullying.
Hecatomb: A sacrifice of a hundred oxen or cattle at the same time; hence, the sacrifice or slaughter of any large number of victims.
Hurons: A powerful and warlike tribe of North American Indians of the Algonquin stock. They formerly occupied the country between Lakes Huron, Erie, and Ontario, but were nearly exterminated by the Five Nations about 1650.
Hydraulic: Of or pertaining to hydraulics, or to fluids in motion; conveying, or acting by, water; as, an hydraulic clock, crane, or dock.
Haversian: Pertaining to, or discovered by, Clopton Havers, an English physician of the seventeenth century.
Hammer lock: A hold in which an arm of one contestant is held twisted and bent behind his back by his opponent.
Hellenistically: According to the Hellenistic manner or dialect.
Hogback: An upward curve or very obtuse angle in the upper surface of any member, as of a timber laid horizontally; -- the opposite of camber.
Horsenail: A thin, pointed nail, with a heavy flaring head, for securing a horsehoe to the hoof; a horsehoe nail.
hardass: A person who strictly enforces rules and regulations.
Hemisphere: A half sphere; one half of a sphere or globe, when divided by a plane passing through its center.
housebound: confined to the home, usually due to illness.
Holder: One who, or that which, holds.
handbasin: A small basin used for washing thehands; as, `wash-hand basin' is a British term.
Historify: To record in or as history.
Herodian: One of a party among the Jews, composed of partisans of Herod of Galilee. They joined with the Pharisees against Christ.
Heptavalent: Having seven units of attractive force or affinity; -- said of heptad elements or radicals.
Hieromancy: Divination by observing the objects offered in sacrifice.
Hunker down: to crouch or squat; to sit on one's haunches.
Harebell: A small, slender, branching plant (Campanula rotundifolia), having blue bell-shaped flowers; also, Scilla nutans, which has similar flowers; -- called also bluebell.
Homeric: Of or pertaining to Homer, the most famous of Greek poets; resembling the poetry of Homer.
Hoddengray: Applied to coarse cloth made of undyed wool, formerly worn by Scotch peasants.
Heelpost: The post supporting the outer end of a propeller shaft.
Hypogene: Formed or crystallized at depths beneath the earth's surface; -- said of granite, gneiss, and other rocks, whose crystallization is believed of have taken place beneath a great thickness of overlying rocks. Opposed to epigene.
Heptarchy: A government by seven persons; also, a country under seven rulers.
Hello: An exclamation used as a greeting, to call attention, as an exclamation of surprise, or to encourage one.  This variant of Halloo and Holloo has become the dominant form.  In the United States, it is the most common greeting used in answering a telephone.
Hartwort: A coarse umbelliferous plant of Europe (Tordylium maximum).
&Verbar;Hymenoptera: An extensive order of insects, including the bees, ants, ichneumons, sawflies, etc.
Hypocist: An astringent inspissated juice obtained from the fruit of a plant (Cytinus hypocistis), growing from the roots of the Cistus, a small European shrub.
Herling: The young of the sea trout.
Haltingly: In a halting or limping manner.
Heptarchist: A ruler of one division of a heptarchy.
hari-kari: An incorrect but common spelling and pronunciation of hara-kiri.
High-spirited: Full of spirit or natural fire; haughty; courageous; impetuous; not brooking restraint or opposition.
Horsewood: A West Indian tree (Calliandra latifolia) with showy, crimson blossoms.
hired: performing work for pay; as, hired hands.
Hammer break: An interrupter in which contact is broken by the movement of an automatically vibrating hammer between a contact piece and an electromagnet, or of a rapidly moving piece mechanically driven.
Hoemother: The basking or liver shark; -- called also homer. See Liver shark, under Liver.
haplosporidian: A parasite in invertebrates and lower vertebrates of no known economic importance.
Holy cross: The cross as the symbol of Christ's crucifixion.
Heterographic: Employing the same letters to represent different sounds in different words or syllables; -- said of methods of spelling; as, the ordinary English orthography is heterographic.
Hogsty: A pen, house, or inclosure, for hogs.
Henfish: A marine fish; the sea bream.
Historize: To relate as history; to chronicle; to historicize.
&Verbar;Hemerocallis: A genus of plants, some species of which are cultivated for their beautiful flowers; day lily.
Helianthin: An artificial, orange dyestuff, analogous to tropaolin, and like it used as an indicator in alkalimetry; -- called also methyl orange.
Half-hourly: Done or happening at intervals of half an hour.
Heartstrike: To affect at heart; to shock.
Hierourgy: A sacred or holy work or worship.
Henhussy: A cotquean; a man who intermeddles with women's concerns.
Hermitage: The habitation of a hermit; a secluded residence.
&Verbar;Heterosomati: An order of fishes, comprising the flounders, halibut, sole, etc., having the body and head asymmetrical, with both eyes on one side. Called also Heterosomata, Heterosomi.
Hygienic: Of or pertaining to health or hygiene; sanitary.
&Verbar;Hematuria: Passage of urine mingled with blood; blood in the urine.
horsecloth: a cloth for the trapping of a horse.
Hailstorm: A storm accompanied with hail; a shower of hail.
Hull: To toss or drive on the water, like the hull of a ship without sails.
Hogskin: Leather tanned from a hog's skin. Also used adjectively.
Hazardize: A hazardous attempt or situation; hazard.
&Verbar;Hematophilia: Same as hemophilia; -- an obsolete term.
Hutchunsonian: A follower of John Hutchinson of Yorkshire, England, who believed that the Hebrew Scriptures contained a complete system of natural science and of theology.
Hendecasyllable: A metrical line of eleven syllables.
&Verbar;Hirudo: A genus of leeches, including the common medicinal leech. See Leech.
homestretch: the straight segment of a racetrack leading to the finish line.
Holocaust: A burnt sacrifice; an offering, the whole of which was consumed by fire, among the Jews and some pagan nations.
Huguenot: A French Protestant of the period of the religious wars in France in the 16th century.
Hedonics: That branch of moral philosophy which treats of the relation of duty to pleasure; the science of practical, positive enjoyment or pleasure.
Heelspur: A slender bony or cartilaginous process developed from the heel bone of bats. It helps to support the wing membranes. See Illust. of Cheiropter.
Hydroquinone: A white crystalline substance, C6H4(OH)2, obtained by the reduction of quinone. It is a diacid phenol, resembling, and metameric with, pyrocatechin and resorcin. Called also dihydroxy benzene.
Howl: The protracted, mournful cry of a dog or a wolf, or other like sound.
High-seasoned: Enriched with spice and condiments; hence, exciting; piquant.
&Verbar;Hydria: A water jar; esp., one with a large rounded body, a small neck, and three handles. Some of the most beautiful Greek vases are of this form.
Hewn: Felled, cut, or shaped as with an ax; roughly squared; as, a house built of hewn logs.
Hexicology: The science which treats of the complex relations of living creatures to other organisms, and to their surrounding conditions generally.
Hydromancy: Divination by means of water, -- practiced by the ancients.
Helena: See St. Elmo's fire, under Saint.
hard-surfaced: paved; -- of roads.  Opposite of  unpaved.
Hierology: A treatise on sacred things; especially, the science which treats of the ancient writings and inscriptions of the Egyptians, or a treatise on that science.
&Verbar;Helianthoidea: An order of Anthozoa; the Actinaria.
half-light: a grayish light (as at dawn or dusk or in dim interiors).
&Verbar;Holmium: A rare element of atomic number 67 said to be contained in gadolinite.  Chemical symbol Ho. Atomic weight 164.93.  Valence +3.  It was detected by spectral absorption bands in 1878 by the Delafontaine and Soret, who called it "Element X".  Later the Swedish chemist Cleve independently discovered it in erbia, and named it after his native city Stockholm.  The first preparation of pure Holmia, the yellow oxide, was not made until 1911.
Heartache: Sorrow; anguish of mind; mental pang.
high-speed: same as fast; as, fast film.  Opposite of slow.
Half-faced: Showing only part of the face; wretched looking; meager.
Half-wit: A foolish person; a dolt; a blockhead; a dunce.
