Hued: Having color; -- usually in composition; as, bright-hued; many-hued.
High-church: Of or pertaining to, or favoring, the party called the High Church, or their doctrines or policy. See High Church, under High, a.
Hebdomadal: Consisting of seven days, or occurring at intervals of seven days; weekly.
&Verbar;Heteromera: A division of Coleoptera, having heteromerous tarsi.
Hareld: The long-tailed duck.  See Old Squaw.
Healthward: In the direction of health; as, a healthward tendency.
Handicraftsman: A man skilled or employed in handcraft.
Heirdom: The state of an heir; succession by inheritance.
Heartiness: The quality of being hearty; as, the heartiness of a greeting.
Hexacapsular: Having six capsules or seed vessels.
Hypersthene: An orthorhombic mineral of the pyroxene group, of a grayish or greenish black color, often with a peculiar bronzelike luster (schiller) on the cleavage surface.
Handiness: The quality or state of being handy.
Hazel: Consisting of hazels, or of the wood of the hazel; pertaining to, or derived from, the hazel; as, a hazel wand.
hop, skip, and a jump: a short distance; as, it's just a hop, skip and a jump away.
Hangman: One who hangs another; esp., one who makes a business of hanging; a public executioner; -- sometimes used as a term of reproach, without reference to office.
Hundredweight: A denomination of weight, containing 100, 112, or 120 pounds avoirdupois, according to differing laws or customs. By the legal standard of England it is 112 pounds. In most of the United States, both in practice and by law, it is 100 pounds avoirdupois, the corresponding ton of 2,000 pounds, sometimes called the short ton, being the legal ton.
Homography: That method of spelling in which every sound is represented by a single character, which indicates that sound and no other.
Host plant: A plant which aids, shelters, or protects another plant in its growth, as those which are used for nurse crops.
Hydroxyl: A compound radical, or unsaturated group, HO, consisting of one atom of hydrogen and one of oxygen. It is a characteristic part of the hydrates, the alcohols, the oxygen acids, etc.
helping: a quantity of food served as part of a meal.
H\u00e6mapoietic: Blood-forming; as, the hæmapoietic function of the spleen.
Habergeon: Properly, a short hauberk, but often used loosely for the hauberk.
Hybridization: The act of hybridizing, or the state of being hybridized.
Huyghenian: Pertaining to, or invented by, Christian Huyghens, a Dutch astronomer of the seventeenth century; as, the Huyghenian telescope.
Hooky: A word used only in the expression to play hooky, to be truant, to run away; -- used mostly of youths absent from school without a valid reason and without the knowledge of their parents.  Also (figuratively and jocosely), to be absent from duty for frivolous reasons.
&Verbar;Hemiopia: A defect of vision in consequence of which a person sees but half of an object looked at.
Hard-shell: Unyielding; insensible to argument; uncompromising; strict.
Hoax: To deceive by a story or a trick, for sport or mischief; to impose upon sportively.
Harts-ear: An Asiatic species of Cacalia (Cacalia Kleinia), used medicinally in India.
hospitalisation: medical care in a hospital; also, the period during which one receives care in a hospital.
higher programming language: A computer programming language with an instruction set allowing one instruction to code for several assembly language instructions.
Histography: A description of, or treatise on, organic tissues.
Half-tongue: A jury, for the trial of a foreigner, composed equally of citizens and aliens.
Horological: Relating to a horologe, or to horology.
Hemihedral: Having half of the similar parts of a crystals, instead of all; consisting of half the planes which full symmetry would require, as when a cube has planes only on half of its eight solid angles, or one plane out of a pair on each of its edges; or as in the case of a tetrahedron, which is hemihedral to an octahedron, it being contained under four of the planes of an octahedron.
Hydrant: A discharge pipe with a valve and spout at which water may be drawn from the mains of waterworks; a water plug.
Harper: A player on the harp; a minstrel.
H\u00e6matogenesis: The origin and development of blood.
H\u00e6matology: The science which treats of the blood. Same as Hematology.
&Verbar;&Verbar;Holotricha: A group of ciliated Infusoria, having cilia all over the body.
Hanaper: A kind of basket, usually of wickerwork, and adapted for the packing and carrying of articles; a hamper.
Herbal: A book containing the names and descriptions of plants.
Honey-bag: The receptacle for honey in a honeybee.
holdout: a negotiator who hopes to gain concessions by refusing to come to terms after most other participants have signed an agreement; as, their star pitcher was a holdout for six weeks.
hand-loomed: Woven on a handloom; -- of fabrics, rugs, or carpets.
houhere: A small tree or shrub (Hoheria populnea) of New Zealand having a profusion of axillary clusters of honey-scented paper-white flowers and whose bark is used for cordage.
hatchet man: A person hired to murder or physically attack another; a hit man.
Heterogenist: One who believes in the theory of spontaneous generation, or heterogenesis.
hemosiderin: a granular yellowish-brown substance composed of protein and ferric oxide, resulting from the breakdown of hemoglobin; it has a higher iron content than ferritin, and its presence in body tissues or phagocytes can be a symptom of disturbed iron metabolism.
Half-brother: A brother by one parent, but not by both.
Hellgamite: The aquatic larva of a large American winged insect (Corydalus cornutus), much used a fish bait by anglers; the dobson. It belongs to the Neuroptera.
Hypoblast: The inner or lower layer of the blastoderm; -- called also endoderm, entoderm, and sometimes hypoderm. See Illust. of Blastoderm, Delamination, and Ectoderm.
Hom\u0153omerous: Having the main artery of the leg parallel with the sciatic nerve; -- said of certain birds.
Hypotrochoid: A curve, traced by a point in the radius, or radius produced, of a circle which rolls upon the concave side of a fixed circle. See Hypocycloid, Epicycloid, and Trochoid.
Hempen: Made of hemp; as, a hempen cord.
Healful: Tending or serving to heal; healing.
Hoodman-blind: An old term for blindman's buff.
Heritable: Capable of being inherited or of passing by inheritance; inheritable.
Hartshorn: The horn or antler of the hart, or male red deer.
Horripilation: A real or fancied bristling of the hair of the head or body, resulting from disease, terror, chilliness, etc.
Hom\u0153omeric: Pertaining to, or characterized by, sameness of parts; receiving or advocating the doctrine of homogeneity of elements or first principles.
Hunnemannia: A genus with only one species, the golden cup.
Hydramide: One of a group of crystalline bodies produced by the action of ammonia on certain aldehydes.
honeyflower: An erect bushy shrub (Lambertia formosa) of eastern Australia having terminal clusters of red flowers yielding much nectar.
housefly: common fly (Musca domestica) that frequents human habitations and spreads many diseases.
Hispanicize: To give a Spanish form or character to; as, to Hispanicize Latin words.
Holocrystalline: Completely crystalline; -- said of a rock like granite, all the constituents of which are crystalline.
Hamate: Hooked; bent at the end into a hook; hamous.
homogenize: To blend (a collection of unlike elements) together so as to make the whole uniform in character, composition, or function.
Hoodman: The person blindfolded in the game called hoodman-blind.
Hounding: The act of one who hounds.
hard-bitten: not given to sentimentality or gentleness; -- of people; as, a hard-bitten character.
&Verbar;Homotaxis: Similarly in arrangement of parts; -- the opposite of heterotaxy.
Hogreeve: A civil officer charged with the duty of impounding hogs running at large.
Hermaphrodite: Including, or being of, both sexes; as, an hermaphrodite animal or flower.
Heartburn: An uneasy, burning sensation in the stomach, often attended with an inclination to vomit.  It is sometimes idiopathic, but is often a symptom of other complaints.
&Verbar;Haik: A large piece of woolen or cotton cloth worn by Arabs as an outer garment.
Help: To lend aid or assistance; to contribute strength or means; to avail or be of use; to assist.
Honestation: The act of honesting; grace; adornment.
&Verbar;Hemicardia: A lateral half of the heart, either the right or left.
&Verbar;Haikal: The central chapel of the three forming the sanctuary of a Coptic church. It contains the high altar, and is usually closed by an embroidered curtain.
Holing: Undercutting in a bed of coal, in order to bring down the upper mass.
Helot: A slave in ancient Sparta; a Spartan serf; hence, a slave or serf.
Homonymously: In an homonymous manner; so as to have the same name or relation.
Hucksterage: The business of a huckster; small dealing; peddling.
Hap: To happen; to befall; to chance.
Haloxyline: An explosive mixture, consisting of sawdust, charcoal, niter, and ferrocyanide of potassium, used as a substitute for gunpowder.
&Verbar;Hydrotheca: One of the calicles which, in some Hydroidea (Thecaphora), protect the hydrants. See Illust. of Hydroidea, and Campanularian.
hominal: Of humankind as a species; as, the hominal kingdom.
Hammerer: One who works with a hammer.
hyperon: Any baryon that is not a nucleon; it is an unstable particle with a mass greater than that of a neutron.
Heteronymous: Having different names or designations; standing in opposite relations.
Hanoverian: A native or naturalized inhabitant of Hanover; one of the House of Hanover.
Heartlings: An exclamation used in addressing a familiar acquaintance.
Hangnest: A nest that hangs like a bag or pocket.
Huntsman: One who hunts, or who practices hunting.
Hemistich: Half a poetic verse or line, or a verse or line not completed.
Hernia: A protrusion, consisting of an organ or part which has escaped from its natural cavity, and projects through some natural or accidental opening in the walls of the latter; as, hernia of the brain, of the lung, or of the bowels. Hernia of the abdominal viscera in most common. Called also rupture.
Hornsnake: A harmless snake (Farancia abacura), found in the Southern United States. The color is bluish black above, red below.
Hemipeptone: A product of the gastric and pancreatic digestion of albuminous matter.
Hex-: A prefix or combining form, used to denote six, sixth, etc.; as, hexatomic, hexabasic.
Headily: In a heady or rash manner; hastily; rashly; obstinately.
Haulm: A part of a harness; a hame.
Hydromagnesite: A hydrous carbonate of magnesia occurring in white, earthy, amorphous masses.
Hepatocystic: Of or pertaining to the liver and gall bladder; as, the hepatocystic ducts.
highwater: the tide when the water is highest; high tide.
Hissing: The act of emitting a hiss or hisses.
Homocercal: Having the tail nearly or quite symmetrical, the vertebral column terminating near its base; -- opposed to heterocercal.
Hematic: A medicine designed to improve the condition of the blood.
Heatingly: In a heating manner; so as to make or become hot or heated.
&Verbar;Hypospadias: A deformity of the penis, in which the urethra opens upon its under surface.
Heresiarch: A leader in heresy; the chief of a sect of heretics.
&Verbar;Hagiographa: The last of the three Jewish divisions of the Old Testament, comprising Psalms, Proverbs, Job, Canticles, Ruth, Lamentations, Ecclesiastes, Esther, Daniel, Ezra, Nehemiah, and Chronicles, or that portion of the Old Testament not contained in the Law (Tora) and the Prophets (Nevi'im) -- it is also called in Hebrew the Ketuvim.  Together with the Tora and Nevi'im, it comprises the Hebrew Bible, which is called in Hebrew the Tanach, a vocalization of the first letters of its three parts.
Hardy: A blacksmith's fuller or chisel, having a square shank for insertion into a square hole in an anvil, called the hardy hole.
handsbreadth: any unit of length based on the breadth of the human hand.
Hards: The refuse or coarse part of flax; tow.
Hammer-less: Without a visible hammer; -- said of a gun having a cock or striker concealed from sight, and out of the way of an accidental touch.
Handicraft: A trade requiring skill of hand; manual occupation; handcraft.
halfpenny: An English coin of the value of half a penny, no longer minted; also, the value of half a penny.
Hymnic: Relating to hymns, or sacred lyrics.
Honey-mouthed: Soft to sweet in speech; persuasive.
Harmotome: A hydrous silicate of alumina and baryta, occurring usually in white cruciform crystals; cross-stone.
Heter\u0153cious: Passing through the different stages in its life history on an alternation of hosts, as the common wheat-rust fungus (Puccinia graminis), and certain other parasitic fungi; -- contrasted with autœcious.
Hindi: The name given by Europeans to that form of the Hindustani language which is chiefly spoken by native Hindus. In employs the Devanagari character, in which Sanskrit is written.
Haft: To set in, or furnish with, a haft; as, to haft a dagger.
Hove: To hover around; to loiter; to lurk.
Hyperdicrotic: Excessive dicrotic; as, a hyperdicrotic pulse.
&Verbar;Holothurioidea: One of the classes of echinoderms.
Hermit: A person who retires from society and lives in solitude; a recluse; an anchoret; especially, one who so lives from religious motives.
Hud: A huck or hull, as of a nut.
Heraldry: The art or office of a herald; the art, practice, or science of recording genealogies, and blazoning arms or ensigns armorial; also, of marshaling cavalcades, processions, and public ceremonies.
Hug: A close embrace or clasping with the arms, as in affection or in wrestling.
hippie: Someone who rejects the established culture, dresses casually, and advocates extreme liberalism in politics and lifestyle.  Used especially of those in the late 1960's, mostly in their late teens and early twenties, who conspicuously rejected traditional culture by dressing casually, if male wore their hair long, and wore folksy or used clothing adorned with beads, headbands, and often flowers; they emphasized the importance of love and direct personal relations rather than success-oriented businesslike behavior, strove for spontaneity, sometimes lived communally, and in some cases tried to expand their consciousness by various psychological techniques such as meditation, or through the use of consciousness-altering drugs such as marijuana or LSD.  By the end of the Vietnam war in the 1970's, the numbers of people living a visibly hippie lifestyle had dramatically decreased, though some people continue to develop similar views and live with the same outlook.
Hub: The central part, usually cylindrical, of a wheel; the nave. See Illust. of Axle box.
Hang-by: A dependent; a hanger-on; -- so called in contempt.
Hendiadys: A figure in which the idea is expressed by two nouns connected by and, instead of by a noun and limiting adjective; as, we drink from cups and gold, for golden cups.
Hut: A small house, hivel, or cabin; a mean lodge or dwelling; a slightly built or temporary structure.
Hamulate: Furnished with a small hook; hook-shaped.
Huckaback: A kind of linen cloth with raised figures, used for towelings.
Hornet: A large, strong wasp.  The European species (Vespa crabro) is of a dark brown and yellow color. It is very pugnacious, and its sting is very severe.  Its nest is constructed of a paperlike material, and the layers of comb are hung together by columns.  The American white-faced hornet (Vespa maculata) is larger and has similar habits.
Heterogenetic: Relating to heterogenesis; as, heterogenetic transformations.
Hegelianism: The system of logic and philosophy set forth by Hegel, a German writer (1770-1831).
Heretic: One who holds to a heresy; one who believes some doctrine contrary to the established faith or prevailing religion.
Hodgkins disease: A morbid condition characterized by progressive anæmia and enlargement of the lymphatic glands; -- first described by Dr. Hodgkin, an English physician.
Helminthic: Of or relating to worms, or Helminthes; expelling worms.
Homoplast: One of the plastids composing the idorgan of Haeckel; -- also called homoörgan.
&Verbar;Hemelytron: One of the partially thickened anterior wings of certain insects, as of many Hemiptera, the earwigs, etc.
Honest: To adorn; to grace; to honor; to make becoming, appropriate, or honorable.
&Verbar;Hypermyriorama: A show or exhibition having a great number of scenes or views.
Housebuilder: One whose business is to build houses; a housewright.
Huke: An outer garment worn in Europe in the Middle Ages.
Hortation: The act of exhorting, inciting, or giving advice; exhortation.
Hyssopus: A Eurasian genus of perennial herbs or subshrubs.
Hotchkiss gun: A built-up, rifled, rapid-fire gun of oil-tempered steel, having a rectangular breechblock which moves horizontally or vertically in a mortise cut completely through the jacket. It is made in France.
Hydrotelluric: Formed by hydrogen and tellurium; as, hydrotelluric acid, or hydrogen telluride.
Horserake: A rake drawn by a horse.
Habited: Clothed; arrayed; dressed; as, he was habited like a shepherd.
Hyomandibular: Pertaining both to the hyoidean arch and the mandible or lower jaw; as, the hyomandibular bone or cartilage, a segment of the hyoid arch which connects the lower jaw with the skull in fishes.
Hepatoscopy: Divination by inspecting the liver of animals.
Herbaceous: Of or pertaining to herbs; having the nature, texture, or characteristics, of an herb; as, herbaceous plants; an herbaceous stem.
Halberdier: One who is armed with a halberd.
Hemispheric: Containing, or pertaining to, a hemisphere; as, a hemispheric figure or form; a hemispherical body.
Hoosier State: Indiana; -- a nickname of obscure origin.
&Verbar;Haliotis: A genus of marine shells; the ear-shells. See Abalone.
&Verbar;Hypocleidium: A median process on the furculum, or merrythought, of many birds, where it is connected with the sternum.
Heptade: The sum or number of seven.
Homemade: Made at home; of domestic manufacture; made either in a private family or in one's own country.
Haggle: The act or process of haggling.
Hetman: A Cossack headman or general. The title of chief hetman is now held by the heir to the throne of Russia.
Heathen: Gentile; pagan; as, a heathen author.
homoiothermism: The process or state of being homoiothermal.
Hermitary: A cell annexed to an abbey, for the use of a hermit.
Heterocephalous: Bearing two kinds of heads or capitula; -- said of certain composite plants.
Hemimorphic: Having the two ends modified with unlike planes; -- said of a crystal.
Hackman: The driver of a hack or carriage for public hire.
hangar: a large building at an airport where aircraft can be stored and maintained.
Hoverer: A device in an incubator for protecting the young chickens and keeping them warm.
&Verbar;Hemian\u00e6sthesia: Anæsthesia upon one side of the body.
Hammer-dressed: Having the surface roughly shaped or faced with the stonecutter's hammer; -- said of building stone.
Heart-wounded: Wounded to the heart with love or grief.
handover: The act of relinquishing property or authority etc. to another; as, the handover of occupied territory to the original posssessors; the handover of power from the military back to the civilian authorities.
Higher National Diploma: A certificate awarded for completing a course of vocational education beyond secondary school, preparing the student for a career in business or certain practical arts.  It is a term used in the United Kingdom.
Hydrochloric: Pertaining to, or compounded of, chlorine and hydrogen gas; as, hydrochloric acid; chlorhydric.
Hyperaspist: One who holds a shield over another; hence, a defender.
Hairsplitting: Making excessively fine or trivial distinctions in reasoning; overly subtle.
Heterophemist: One liable to the fault of heterophemy.
humidifier: A device that increases the moisture content of the air; -- used to avoid excessive dryness in buildings, which can cause irritation to the throat.  Compare dehumidifier.
Hysterology: A figure by which the ordinary course of thought is inverted in expression, and the last put first; -- called also hysteron proteron.
Hystricine: Like or pertaining to the porcupines.
Hemisystole: Contraction of only one ventricle of the heart.
heckling: Shouting in order to interrupt a speech with which the shouter disagrees.
highly-sexed: having unusually intense sexual desire or appeal.
Hive: To take shelter or lodgings together; to reside in a collective body.
Hogshead: An English measure of capacity, containing 63 wine gallons, or about 521/2 imperial gallons; a half pipe.
Heartwood: The hard, central part of the trunk of a tree, consisting of the old and matured wood, and usually differing in color from the outer layers. It is technically known as duramen, and distinguished from the softer sapwood or alburnum.
Hylotheism: The doctrine of belief that matter is God, or that there is no God except matter and the universe; pantheism. See Materialism.
Hares-tail: A kind of grass (Eriophorum vaginatum). See Cotton grass, under Cotton.
Herpes simplex: either of two forms of herpesvirus infection, distinguished as being caused by herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), which causes mostly sores and eruptions around the mouth (cold sores and fever blisters) and at other points above the waist, and herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2), causing genital herpes.  HSV-1 is also known in some cases to cause genital herpes infections.
horsemeat: The flesh of horses used as food.
Hornpipe: An instrument of music formerly popular in Wales, consisting of a wooden pipe, with holes at intervals. It was so called because the bell at the open end was sometimes made of horn.
Houttuynia: A genus of plants having only one species; East Asian low-growing plant of wet places.
Homogenous: Having a resemblance in structure, due to descent from a common progenitor with subsequent modification; homogenetic; -- applied both to animals and plants. See Homoplastic.
Hindgut: The posterior part of the alimentary canal, including the rectum, and sometimes the large intestine also.
Heteromerous: Unrelated in chemical composition, though similar or indentical in certain other respects; as, borax and augite are homœmorphous, but heteromerous.
Hypermeter: A verse which has a redundant syllable or foot; a hypercatalectic verse.
Halsening: Sounding harshly in the throat; inharmonious; rough.
Homocerebrin: A body similar to, or identical with, cerebrin.
Hamstring: To lame or disable by cutting the tendons of the ham or knee; to hough; hence, to cripple; to incapacitate; to disable.
Heremitical: Of or pertaining to a hermit; solitary; secluded from society.
&Verbar;Hemapophysis: The second element in each half of a hemal arch, corresponding to the sternal part of a rib.
Hinderer: One who, or that which, hinders.
Hammer: To be busy forming anything; to labor hard as if shaping something with a hammer.
Hydracrylic: Pertaining to, or designating, an isomeric variety of lactic acid that breaks down into acrylic acid and water.
Hoppo: A collector of customs, as at Canton; an overseer of commerce.
Hooked: Having the form of a hook; curvated; as, the hooked bill of a bird.
Heimdal: god of dawn and light; guardian of Asgard.
Heteroplastic: Producing a different type of organism; developing into a different form of tissue, as cartilage which develops into bone.
Hatstand: A stand of wood or iron, with hooks or pegs upon which to hang hats, etc.
Hunks: A covetous, sordid man; a miser; a niggard.
Homaxonial: Relating to that kind of homology or symmetry, the mathematical conception of organic form, in which all axes are equal. See under Promorphology.
hodometer: A device for measuring the length of a path, consisting of a wheel of known circumference attached to a rod held in the hand, and pushed along a surface, which is usually the ground or a floor.  The number of times the wheel makes a complete circle multiplied by the circumference is a measure of the length of the path traversed.  It may be used to measure distances on curved as well as straight paths.  A variant which registers the miles and rods traversed is sometimes used by surveyors.
H\u00e6mol: A dark brown powder containing iron, prepared by the action of zinc dust as a reducing agent upon the coloring matter of the blood, used medicinally as a hematinic.
Hemispheroidal: Resembling, or approximating to, a hemisphere in form.
&Verbar;Hyoglossus: A flat muscle on either side of the tongue, connecting it with the hyoid bone.
Haver: To maunder; to talk foolishly; to chatter.
Hammerhead: A shark of the genus Sphyrna or Zygæna, having the eyes set on projections from the sides of the head, which gives it a hammer shape. The Sphyrna zygæna is found in the North Atlantic. Called also hammer fish, and balance fish.
Highbinder: A ruffian; one who hounds, or spies upon, another; app. esp. to the members of certain alleged societies among the Chinese.
High-mindedness: The quality of being highminded; nobleness; magnanimity.
Hydrobromide: A compound of hydrobromic acid with a base; -- distinguished from a bromide, in which only the bromine unites with the base.
hotei-chiku: A small bamboo (Phyllostachys aurea) of Southeast China having slender culms flexuous when young.
Him: The objective case of he. See He.
Hypothesis: A supposition; a proposition or principle which is supposed or taken for granted, in order to draw a conclusion or inference for proof of the point in question; something not proved, but assumed for the purpose of argument, or to account for a fact or an occurrence; as, the hypothesis that head winds detain an overdue steamer.
Hymenopteral: Like, or characteristic of, the Hymenoptera; pertaining to the Hymenoptera.
Hippuric: Obtained from the urine of horses; as, hippuric acid.
Helleborin: A poisonous glucoside found in several species of hellebore, and extracted as a white crystalline substance with a sharp tingling taste. It possesses the essential virtues of the plant; -- called also elleborin.
Haloed: Surrounded with a halo; invested with an ideal glory; glorified.
Hosta: A genus of robust East Asian clump-forming perennial herbs having racemose flowers: plantain lilies; sometimes placed in the family Hostaceae.
Harvester: One who harvests; a machine for cutting and gathering grain; a reaper.
Hebraize: To speak Hebrew, or to conform to the Hebrew idiom, or to Hebrew customs.
Hungry: Feeling hunger; having a keen appetite; feeling uneasiness or distress from want of food; hence, having an eager desire.
Homogony: The condition of having homogonous flowers.
hands: a person's power or discretionary action; as, my fate is in your hands.
Hoove: A disease in cattle consisting in inflammation of the stomach by gas, ordinarily caused by eating too much green food; tympany; bloating.
Hewhole: The European green woodpecker. See Yaffle.
housemaster: A teacher in charge of a school boardinghouse.
handleless: having no handle; as, sleek cabinets with apparently handleless doors.  Opposite of handled.
Halometer: An instrument for measuring the forms and angles of salts and crystals; a goniometer.
holocephalan: A member of the Holocephali, fish with high compressed heads and a bodies tapering off into a long tail.  See also Hoocephali.
Healall: A common herb of the Mint family (Brunella vulgaris), destitute of active properties, but anciently thought to be a panacea.
Hysterophyte: A plant, like the fungus, which lives on dead or living organic matter.
Homologinic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, homology; as, homologinic qualities, or differences.
Hexagonal: Having six sides and six angles; six-sided.
Hydropult: A machine for throwing water by hand power, as a garden engine, a fire extinguisher, etc.
hypernym: a word that is more generic or more abstract than a given word; a word designating a class of which the given word is a member.  Inverse of subtype and hyponym.
Huzza: To receive or attend with huzzas.
Hysterotomy: The act of cutting into the uterus, as in Cæsarean section. See under Cæsarean.
Hematitic: Of or pertaining to hematite, or resembling it.
Hystrix: A genus of rodents, including the porcupine.
Heelball: A composition of wax and lampblack, used by shoemakers for polishing, and by antiquaries in copying inscriptions.
Hunts-up: A tune played on the horn very early in the morning to call out the hunters; hence, any arousing sound or call.
Harmony: The just adaptation of parts to each other, in any system or combination of things, or in things intended to form a connected whole; such an agreement between the different parts of a design or composition as to produce unity of effect; as, the harmony of the universe.
&Verbar;Haustellum: The sucking proboscis of various insects. See Lepidoptera, and Diptera.
Highwayman: One who robs on the public road; a highway robber.
Hayward: An officer who is appointed to guard hedges, and to keep cattle from breaking or cropping them, and whose further duty it is to impound animals found running at large.
Hydrofluate: A supposed compound of hydrofluoris acid and a base; a fluoride.
Hyl\u00e6osaur: A large Wealden dinosaur from the Tilgate Forest, England. It was about twenty feet long, protected by bony plates in the skin, and armed with spines.
Highland: Elevated or mountainous land; (often in the pl.) an elevated region or country; as, the Highlands of Scotland.
Hippocampal: Of or pertaining to the hippocampus.
Haggishly: In the manner of a hag.
Hydriodide: A compound of hydriodic acid with a base; -- distinguished from an iodide, in which only the iodine combines with the base.
Heterostyled: Having styles of two or more distinct forms or lengths.
Hallucinatory: Partaking of, having the character of, or tending to produce, hallucinations; as, hallucinatory visions.
Hyosternal: Between the hyoid bone and the sternum, or pertaining to them; infrahyoid; as, the hyosternal region of the neck.
Hydrogenide: A binary compound containing hydrogen; a hydride. [R.] See Hydride.
hedged: qualified; limited or restricted; as, a hedged promise.
Harpist: A player on the harp; a harper.
&Verbar;Holocephali: An order of elasmobranch fishes, including, among living species, only the chimæras; -- called also Holocephala. See Chimæra; also Illustration in Appendix.
halobacter: Any halophilic bacterium of the archaebacteria group, expecially of the genera Halobacterium and Halococcus, which live in saline environments such as the Dead Sea or salt flats.
High priest: A chief priest; esp., the head of the Jewish priesthood.
Hieromartyr: A priest who becomes a martyr.
Hemothorax: An effusion of blood into the cavity of the pleura.
Histolytic: Of or pertaining to histolysis, or the degeneration of tissues.
Harmonious: Adapted to each other; having parts proportioned to each other; symmetrical.
Harvestless: Without harvest; lacking in crops; barren.
Hydrangeaceae: A natural family of plants including the hydrangeas, sometimes included in the family Saxifragaceae.
Heptad: An atom which has a valence of seven, and which can be theoretically combined with, substituted for, or replaced by, seven monad atoms or radicals; as, iodine is a heptad in iodic acid. Also used as an adjective.
Hydrostatic: Of or relating to hydrostatics; pertaining to, or in accordance with, the principles of the equilibrium of fluids.
Hydrophobia: An abnormal dread of water, said to be a symptom of canine madness; hence:
Homogeneousness: Sameness 9kind or nature; uniformity of structure or material.
Hierarchy: Dominion or authority in sacred things.
hyperinflation: an unusually rapid rate of monetary inflation, as when prices rise more than 100 per cent per year.
Half-caste: One born of a European parent on the one side, and of a Hindu or Mohammedan on the other. Also adjective; as, half-caste parents.
Hydrargyrism: A diseased condition produced by poisoning with hydrargyrum, or mercury; mercurialism.
Heteropathic: Of or pertaining to the method of heteropathy; allopathic.
Hanging: The act of suspending anything; the state of being suspended.
horsebrier: a very prickly woody vine (Smilax rotundifolia) of eastern U. S. growing in tangled masses having tough round stems with shiny leathery leaves and small greenish flowers followed by clusters of inedible shiny black berries.
Honeycomb: A mass of hexagonal waxen cells, formed by bees, and used by them to hold their honey and their eggs.
Heathenishness: The state or quality of being heathenish.
Henhouse: A house or shelter for fowls.
hadrosaur: Any member of the genus Hadrosaurus or family Hadrosauridae, an extinct family of heavy bipedal partly aquatic dinosaurs with duck-billed skull and webbed feet; of the Upper Cretaceous in North America.
Hypocrisy: The act or practice of a hypocrite; a feigning to be what one is not, or to feel what one does not feel; a dissimulation, or a concealment of one's real character, disposition, or motives; especially, the assuming of false appearance of virtue or religion; a simulation of goodness.
Heliotypy: A method of transferring pictures from photographic negatives to hardened gelatin plates from which impressions are produced on paper as by lithography.
Hollow-hearted: Insincere; deceitful; not sound and true; having a cavity or decayed spot within.
Heliotype: A picture obtained by the process of heliotypy.
Heterogeneity: The state of being heterogeneous; contrariety.
Harmonic: A musical note produced by a number of vibrations which is a multiple of the number producing some other; an overtone. See Harmonics.
Headed: Furnished with a head (commonly as denoting intellectual faculties); -- used in composition; as, clear-headed, long-headed, thick-headed; a many-headed monster.
Hindoo calendar: A lunisolar calendar of India, according to which the year is divided into twelve months, with an extra month inserted after every month in which two new moons occur (once in three years).
Handygripe: Seizure by, or grasp of, the hand; also, close quarters in fighting.
Hippocratic oath: An oath said to have been dictated by Hippocrates to his disciples.  Such an oath is still administered to candidates for graduation in medicine.
&Verbar;Herbivora: An extensive division of Mammalia. It formerly included the Proboscidea, Hyracoidea, Perissodactyla, and Artiodactyla, but by later writers it is generally restricted to the two latter groups (Ungulata). They feed almost exclusively upon vegetation.
Hippocrates: A famous Greek physician and medical writer, born in Cos, about 460 b. c.
Hectograph: A contrivance for multiple copying, by means of a surface of gelatin softened with glycerin.
&Verbar;Hibernaculum: A winter bud, in which the rudimentary foliage or flower, as of most trees and shrubs in the temperate zone, is protected by closely overlapping scales.
Hedonism: The doctrine of the Hedonic sect; the pursuit of pleasure as a matter of ethical principle.
Hawk: A small board, with a handle on the under side, to hold mortar.
Harshness: The quality or state of being harsh.
Hogget: A young boar of the second year.
Hard-handed: Having hard hands, as a manual laborer.
Henbit: A weed of the genus Lamium (Lamium amplexicaule) with deeply crenate leaves.
Hotshot: a successful, self-confident  person who is regarded by others as highly skilled; -- sometimes used ironically in reference to aggressive persons whose opinion of their own talents is considered exaggerated.
handwear: clothing for the hands, especially gloves.
highjacking: The seizure of control of a vehicle while it is in transit, either to rob it or divert it to an alternate destination.
&Verbar;Habitus: Habitude; mode of life; general appearance.
Haunch: The hip; the projecting region of the lateral parts of the pelvis and the hip joint; the hind part.
Hip lock: A lock in which a close grip is obtained and a fall attempted by a heave over the hip.
Hexateuch: The first six books of the Old Testament.
Hymenophore: That part of a fungus which is covered with the hymenium.
Hemachate: A species of agate, sprinkled with spots of red jasper.
Huttoning: Forcible manipulation of a dislocated, stiff, or painful joint.
&Verbar;Hypericum: A genus of plants, generally with dotted leaves and yellow flowers; -- called also St. John's-wort.
Heater: One who, or that which, heats.
Hercules-club: A densely spiny ornamental tree (Zanthoxylum clava-herculis) of the rue family, growing in southeast U. S. and West Indies.
Hanseatic: Pertaining to the Hanse towns, or to their confederacy.
Horsewhip: To flog or chastise with a horsewhip.
Homographic: Employing a single and separate character to represent each sound; -- said of certain methods of spelling words.
Hom\u0153ozoic: Pertaining to, or including, similar forms or kinds of life; as, homœozoic belts on the earth's surface.
Hydrothorax: An accumulation of serous fluid in the cavity of the chest.
Hodograph: A curve described by the moving extremity of a line the other end of which is fixed, this line being constantly parallel to the direction of motion of, and having its length constantly proportional to the velocity of, a point moving in any path; -used in investigations respecting central forces.
Hermaphroditic: Partaking of the characteristics of both sexes; having male and female reproductive organs in the same plant or animal; characterized by hermaphroditism.  Opposite of dioecious.
H-bomb: The hydrogen bomb, a thermonuclear weapon that releases atomic energy by union of hydrogen nuclei at high temperatures to form helium.  The force of its explosion may range from one to hundreds of megatons of TNT equivalent.
Hippolith: A concretion, or kind of bezoar, from the intestines of the horse.
Hellenist: One who affiliates with Greeks, or imitates Greek manners; esp., a person of Jewish extraction who used the Greek language as his mother tongue, as did the Jews of Asia Minor, Greece, Syria, and Egypt; distinguished from the Hebraists, or native Jews (Acts vi. 1).
Hypogynous: Inserted below the pistil or pistils; -- said of sepals, petals, and stamens; having the sepals, petals, and stamens inserted below the pistil; -- said of a flower or a plant.
Heliotypic: Relating to, or obtained by, heliotypy.
Hellenism: A phrase or form of speech in accordance with genius and construction or idioms of the Greek language; a Grecism.
Heteromorphic: Deviating from the normal, perfect, or mature form; having different forms at different stages of existence, or in different individuals of the same species; -- applied especially to insects in which there is a wide difference of form between the larva and the adult, and to plants having more than one form of flower.
&Verbar;Hyperthyrion: That part of the architrave which is over a door or window.
Hydrangea: A genus of shrubby plants bearing opposite leaves and large heads of showy flowers, white, or of various colors. Hydrangea hortensis, the common garden species, is a native of China or Japan.
Horneophyton: A genus of Devonian fossil plants considered one of the earliest forms of vascular land plants; it is similar to genus Rhynia but smaller.
hangover: An unpleasant feeling, such as a headache, occurring as an aftereffect from the use of drugs (especially alcohol).
Hobbism: The philosophical system of Thomas Hobbes, an English materialist (1588-1679); esp., his political theory that the most perfect form of civil government is an absolute monarchy with despotic control over everything relating to law, morals, and religion.
Hysterogenic: Producing hysteria; as, the hysterogenicpressure points on the surface of the body, pressure upon which is said both to produce and arrest an attack of hysteria.
Healing: Tending to cure; soothing; mollifying; as, the healing art; a healing salve; healing words.
Hobbist: One who accepts the doctrines of Thomas Hobbes.
Hairtail: Any species of marine fishes of the genus Trichiurus; esp., Trichiurus lepturus of Europe and America.  They are long and like a band, with a slender, pointed tail. Called also bladefish.
&Verbar;Homologoumena: Those books of the New Testament which were acknowledged as canonical by the early church; -- distinguished from antilegomena.
Homogangliate: Having the ganglia of the nervous system symmetrically arranged, as in certain invertebrates; -- opposed to heterogangliate.
Hyetograph: A chart or graphic representation of the average distribution of rain over the surface of the earth.
Humanistic: Of or pertaining to humanity; as, humanistic devotion.
&Verbar;Habitu\u00e9: One who habitually frequents a place; as, an habitué of a theater.
Hesychast: One of a mystical sect of the Greek Church in the fourteenth century; a quietist.
handbag: a small bag usually made of cloth, leather or a similar imitation material, and often having a strap to permit carrying it by slinging it over a shoulder, used by women to carry money and small personal items or accessories; as, she had to search under the cosmetics, hankies, and medicines in her handbag to find a comb.
&Verbar;Hyper\u00e6sthesia: A state of exalted or morbidly increased sensibility of the body, or of a part of it.
highschool: a public secondary school usually including grades 9 through 12; as, he goes to the neighborhood highschool.
&Verbar;Hysteron proteron: A figure in which the natural order of sense is reversed; hysterology; as, valet atque vivit, “he is well and lives.”
hyponymy: The state or quality of being a hyponym; as, hyponymy is symbolized by the tag “hypon”.
Hibernacle: That which serves for protection or shelter in winter; winter quarters; as, the hibernacle of an animal or a plant.
Heedful: Full of heed; regarding with care; cautious; circumspect; attentive; vigilant.
Helicoid: A warped surface which may be generated by a straight line moving in such a manner that every point of the line shall have a uniform motion in the direction of another fixed straight line, and at the same time a uniform angular motion about it.
Handkerchief: A piece of cloth, usually square and often fine and elegant, carried for wiping the face or hands.
Hippogriff: A fabulous winged animal, half horse and half griffin.
&Verbar;Hyalospongia: An order of vitreous sponges, having glassy six-rayed, siliceous spicules; -- called also Hexactinellinæ.
Hyponastic: Exhibiting a downward convexity caused by unequal growth.  Cf. Epinastic.
Hauberk: A coat of mail; especially, the long coat of mail of the European Middle Ages, as contrasted with the habergeon, which is shorter and sometimes sleeveless. By old writers it is often used synonymously with habergeon. See Habergeon.
Hyostylic: Having the mandible suspended by the hyomandibular, or upper part of the hyoid arch, as in fishes, instead of directly articulated with the skull as in mammals; -- said of the skull.
Hepatite: A variety of barite emitting a fetid odor when rubbed or heated.
Hydrotherapeutics: A system of treating disease by baths and mineral waters.
Husking: The act or process of stripping off husks, as from Indian corn.
Headstock: A part (usually separate from the bed or frame) for supporting some of the principal working parts of a machine
Hundredth: One of a hundred equal parts into which one whole is, or may be, divided; the quotient of a unit divided by a hundred.
Histonomy: The science which treats of the laws relating to organic tissues, their formation, development, functions, etc.
Higher criticism: Criticism which includes the study of the contents, literary character, date, authorship, etc., of any writing; as, the higher criticism of the Pentateuch. Called also historical criticism.
Hypocoristic: Endearing; diminutive; as, the hypocoristic form of a name.
Hydropneumatic: Pertaining to, or depending upon, both liquid and gaseous substances; as, hydropneumatic apparatus for collecting gases over water or other liquids.
hardcover: Same as hardback n. and a.
Hirsute: Rough with hair; set with bristles; shaggy.
Heteromorphism: The state or quality of being heteromorphic.
Hyperbaric: of, pertaining to, or using a pressure that is greater than normal atmospheric pressure; as, a hyperbaric chamber, where divers may decompress slowly to avoid the bends.
Herrenvolk: a race that considers itself superior to all others and fitted to rule the others; -- referred to especially in NAZI racial theories.
Hesitation: The act of hesitating; suspension of opinion or action; doubt; vacillation.
hierarchic: Of or pertaining to a hierarchy; ordered in a hierarchy.
Hotbed: A bed of earth heated by fermenting manure or other substances, and covered with glass, intended for raising early plants, or for nourishing exotics.
Hellenian: Of or pertaining to the Hellenes, or Greeks.
Heartstruck: Driven to the heart; infixed in the mind.
Head-lugged: Lugged or dragged by the head.
Hagioscope: An opening made in the interior walls of a cruciform church to afford a view of the altar to those in the transepts; -- called, in architecture, a squint.
Hydrostatically: According to hydrostatics, or to hydrostatic principles.
Homologous: Having the same relative position, proportion, value, or structure.
Hypostasis: That which forms the basis of anything; underlying principle; a concept or mental entity conceived or treated as an existing being or thing.
Hospitable: Receiving and entertaining strangers or guests with kindness and without reward; kind to strangers and guests; characterized by hospitality.
Huguenotism: The religion of the Huguenots in France.
heartshaped: Having the shape of a heart; cordate; -- of a leaf shape.
Hellbender: A large North American aquatic salamander (Protonopsis horrida or Menopoma Alleghaniensis). It is very voracious and very tenacious of life. Also called alligator, and water dog.
Handbreadth: A space equal to the breadth of the hand; a palm.
Hydraulicon: An ancient musical instrument played by the action of water; a water organ.
Hidage: A tax formerly paid to the kings of England for every hide of land.
Homish: Like a home or a home circle.
&Verbar;Hors de combat: Out of the combat; disabled from fighting; out of action.
Hardhead: Clash or collision of heads in contest.
hifi: An electronic device that plays phonograph records, reproducing the original sound with a high degree of fidelity.  It superseded the older phonographs, and itself is being displaced in popularity by CD players.
Humpy: Full of humps or bunches; covered with protuberances; humped.
Hogfish: A large West Indian and Florida food fish (Lachnolæmus).
Holethnic: Of or pertaining to a holethnos or parent race.
Holaspidean: Having a single series of large scutes on the posterior side of the tarsus; -- said of certain birds.
heatstroke: A physiological disturbance caused by exposure to excessive heat, resulting in rapid pulse, hot dry skin, and fever, leading to loss of consciousness.
Hydrachnid: An aquatic mite of the genus Hydrachna. The hydrachnids, while young, are parasitic on fresh-water mussels.
Hexane: Any one of five hydrocarbons, C6H14, of the paraffin series. They are colorless, volatile liquids, and are so called because the molecule has six carbon atoms.
House: To take shelter or lodging; to abide to dwell; to lodge.
Honorableness: The state of being honorable; eminence; distinction.
handstand: The gymnastic act of supporting oneself by one's hands alone in an upside down position; as, to do handstands for exercise.
Hamesecken: The felonious seeking and invasion of a person in his dwelling house.
Hypochondriasis: A mental disorder in which melancholy and gloomy views torment the affected person, particularly concerning his own health; a morbid and deluded belief that one is afflicted with disease.
hardwood: Made of the hard-to-cut wood of a broad-leaved tree, as e.g. oak; consisting of a hardwood; as, hardwood floors; -- of wood and wooden objects.
&Verbar;Hyperotreta: An order of marsipobranchs, including the Myxine or hagfish and the genus Bdellostoma. They have barbels around the mouth, one tooth on the palate, and a communication between the nasal aperture and the throat. See Hagfish.
Hemimetabolic: Having an incomplete metamorphosis, the larvæ differing from the adults chiefly in laking wings, as in the grasshoppers and cockroaches.
Handbook: A book of reference, to be carried in the hand; a manual; a guidebook.
Hyracoid: Of or pertaining to the Hyracoidea.
High-mettled: Having abundance of mettle; ardent; full of fire; as, a high-mettled steed.
Hurrah: To salute, or applaud, with hurrahs.
Hooker: One who, or that which, hooks.
Hostile: An enemy; esp., an American Indian in arms against the whites; -- commonly in the plural.
Hypersecretion: Morbid or excessive secretion, as in catarrh.
Homatropine: An alkaloid, prepared from atropine, and from other sources. It is chemically related to atropine, and is used for the same purpose.
hard-on: An erect penis; a penile erection.
Hawaiian: Belonging to Hawaii or the Sandwich Islands, or to the people of Hawaii.
Horoscope: The representation made of the aspect of the heavens at the moment of a person's birth, by which the astrologer professed to foretell the events of the person's life; especially, the sign of the zodiac rising above the horizon at such a moment.
Half-read: Informed by insufficient reading; superficial; shallow.
Hindoo: A native inhabitant of Hindostan. As an ethnical term it is confined to the Dravidian and Aryan races; as a religious name it is restricted to followers of the Veda.
&Verbar;Hamal: In Turkey and other Oriental countries, a porter or burden bearer; specif., in Western India, a palanquin bearer.
Hatter: One who makes or sells hats.
Hydrodynamics: That branch of the science of mechanics which relates to fluids, or, as usually limited, which treats of the laws of motion and action of nonelastic fluids, whether as investigated mathematically, or by observation and experiment; the principles of dynamics, as applied to water and other fluids.
&Verbar;Hyrax: Any animal of the genus Hyrax, of which about four species are known.  They constitute the order Hyracoidea.  The best known species are the daman (Hyrax Syriacus) of Palestine, and the klipdas (Hyrax capensis) of South Africa.  Other species are Hyrax arboreus and Hyrax Sylvestris, the former from Southern, and the latter from Western, Africa. See Daman.
H\u00e6macytometer: An apparatus for determining the number of corpuscles in a given quantity of blood.
Hamamelidanthum: A genus of fossil plants of the Oligocene having flowers resembling those of the witch hazel; found in Baltic region.
&Verbar;Holostei: An extensive division of ganoids, including the gar pike, bowfin, etc.; the bony ganoids. See Illustration in Appendix.
Huttonian: Relating to what is now called the Plutonic theory of the earth, first advanced by Dr. James Hutton.
Heptylic: Pertaining to, or derived from, heptyl or heptane; as, heptylic alcohol.  Cf. Œnanthylic.
Hobbyhorsical: Pertaining to, or having, a hobby or whim; eccentric; whimsical.
Hygrophanous: Having such a structure as to be diaphanous when moist, and opaque when dry.
haji: One who has made a journey to Mecca; Same as hadji.
Hindooism: The religious doctrines and rites of the Hindus; Brahmanism.
Hindermost: Furthest in or toward the rear; last.
Handspring: A somersault made with the assistance of the hands placed upon the ground.
Hanse: An association; a league or confederacy.
Homomorphy: Similarity of form; resemblance in external characters, while widely different in fundamental structure; resemblance in geometric ground form. See Homophyly, Promorphology.
Harquebus: A firearm with match holder, trigger, and tumbler, made in the second half of the 15th century.  The barrel was about forty inches long.  A form of the harquebus was subsequently called arquebus with matchlock.
Hercogamous: Not capable of self-fertilization; -- said of hermaphrodite flowers in which some structural obstacle forbids autogamy.
Huswifery: The business of a housewife; female domestic economy and skill.
Hemorrhoids: Livid and painful swellings formed by the dilation of the blood vessels around the margin of, or within, the anus, from which blood or mucus is occasionally discharged; piles; emerods.
Harten: To hearten; to encourage; to incite.
&Verbar;Hacienda: A large estate where work of any kind is done, as agriculture, manufacturing, mining, or raising of animals; a cultivated farm, with a good house, in distinction from a farming establishment with rude huts for herdsmen, etc.; -- a word used in Spanish-American regions.
Heliographic: Of or pertaining to a description of the sun.
Hectare: A measure of area, or superficies, containing a hundred ares, or 10,000 square meters, and equivalent to 2.471 acres.
High-colored: Having a strong, deep, or glaring color; flushed.
Hazarder: A player at the game of hazard; a gamester.
Hypobole: A figure in which several things are mentioned that seem to make against the argument, or in favor of the opposite side, each of them being refuted in order.
Hitch: A catch; anything that holds, as a hook; an impediment; an obstacle; an entanglement.
Houyhnhnm: One of the race of horses described by Swift in his imaginary travels of Lemuel Gulliver. The Houyhnhnms were endowed with reason and noble qualities; subject to them were Yahoos, a race of brutes having the form and all the worst vices of men.
Homilite: A borosilicate of iron and lime, near datolite in form and composition.
Homophyly: That form of homology due to common ancestry (phylogenetic homology), in opposition to homomorphy, to which genealogic basis is wanting.
highland: of, located in, or characteristic of high or hilly country.  Contrasted to lowland.
hungriness: The state of being hungry; a need for food.
Hibiscus: A genus of plants (herbs, shrubs, or trees), some species of which have large, showy flowers. Some species are cultivated in India for their fiber, which is used as a substitute for hemp. See Althea, Hollyhock, and Manoe.
&Verbar;Halma: The long jump, with weights in the hands, -- the most important of the exercises of the Pentathlon.
Heft: To heave up; to raise aloft.
H\u00e6matoxylin: The coloring principle of logwood. It is obtained as a yellow crystalline substance, C16H14O6, with a sweetish taste. Formerly called also hematin.
Hey: An exclamation of joy, surprise, or encouragement.
Holily: Piously; with sanctity; in a holy manner.
Halogen: An electro-negative element or radical, which, by combination with a metal, forms a haloid salt; especially, chlorine, fluorine, bromine, and iodine; sometimes, also cyanogen. See Chlorine family, under Chlorine.
Hem: To form a hem or border to; to fold and sew down the edge of.
Hen: The female of the domestic fowl; also, the female of grouse, pheasants, or any kind of birds; as, the heath hen; the gray hen.
Holiday: Of or pertaining to a festival; cheerful; joyous; gay.
Horntail: Any one of family (Uroceridæ) of large hymenopterous insects, allied to the sawflies. The larvæ bore in the wood of trees. So called from the long, stout ovipositors of the females.
Hairstreak: A butterfly of the genus Thecla; as, the green hairstreak (Thecla rubi).
Hepatorenal: Of or pertaining to the liver and kidneys; as, the hepatorenal ligament.
Hierogrammatist: A writer of hierograms; also, one skilled in hieroglyphics.
highball: An alcoholic beverage having a liquor such as whiskey mixed with water or a carbonated beverage, and usually served with ice in a tall glass.
Holo-: A combining form fr. Gr. "o`los whole.
Hoarse: Having a harsh, rough, grating voice or sound, as when affected with a cold; making a rough, harsh cry or sound; as, the hoarse raven.
Hand-winged: Having wings that are like hands in the structure and arrangement of their bones; -- said of bats. See Cheiroptera.
Harness cask: A tub lashed to a vessel's deck and containing salted provisions for daily use; -- called also harness tub.
Hayloft: A loft or scaffold for hay.
Humbug: To deceive; to impose; to cajole; to hoax.
Holographic: Of the nature of a holograph; pertaining to holographs.
Hemipteran: One of the Hemiptera; an hemipter.
H\u00e6matic: Of or pertaining to the blood; sanguine; brownish red.
Haymow: A mow or mass of hay laid up in a barn for preservation.
headlamp: A powerful light with a reflector, attached to the front of an automobile, locomotive, or other vehicle; called also headlight.
Halfness: The quality of being half; incompleteness.
Helter-skelter: In hurry and confusion; without definite purpose; irregularly.
hindquarters: the fleshy part of the human body at the back of the hip, on which a person sits; teh buttocks.
Herisson: A beam or bar armed with iron spikes, and turning on a pivot; -- used to block up a passage.
Heading: The act or state of one who, or that which, heads; formation of a head.
Hemiramphidae: A natural family of fish including the halfbeaks, marine and freshwater fishes closely related to the flying fishes but not able to glide.
Hommocky: Filled with hommocks; piled in the form of hommocks; -- said of ice.
Homefield: A field adjacent to its owner's home.
Heptarchic: Of or pertaining to a heptarchy; constituting or consisting of a heptarchy.
Halloween: The evening preceding Allhallows or All Saints' Day (November 1); also the entire day, October 31.  It is often marked by parties or celebrations, and sometimes by pranks played by young people.
Heedless: Without heed or care; inattentive; careless; thoughtless; unobservant.
hayrig: a frame attached to a wagon to increase the amount of hay it can carry.
Haven: To shelter, as in a haven.
Hederic: Pertaining to, or derived from, the ivy (Hedera); as, hederic acid, an acid of the acetylene series.
&Verbar;Hectocotylus: One of the arms of the male of most kinds of cephalopods, which is specially modified in various ways to effect the fertilization of the eggs. In a special sense, the greatly modified arm of Argonauta and allied genera, which, after receiving the spermatophores, becomes detached from the male, and attaches itself to the female for reproductive purposes.
Hardhack: A very astringent shrub (Spiræa tomentosa), common in pastures.  The Potentilla fruticosa is also called by this name.
hypertension: abnormally high blood pressure; especially, the chronic condition associated with persistent high blood pressure.
&Verbar;Hematocrya: The cold-blooded vertebrates, that is, all but the mammals and birds; -- the antithesis to Hematotherma.
horse-trading: negotiation accompanied by mutual concessions and shrewd bargaining.
Hanap: A rich goblet, esp. one used on state occasions.
hairpiece: a covering or bunch of human or artificial hair used for disguise or adornment; a toupee.
handcolor: to add color to (a black-and-white image) using an instrument held in the hand; as, Some old photographs are handcolored.
Heptamerous: Consisting of seven parts, or having the parts in sets of sevens.
Holocentrus: The type genus of the family Holocentridae, comprising some of the squirrelfishes.
Hade: To deviate from the vertical; -- said of a vein, fault, or lode.
&Verbar;Homoioptoton: A figure in which the several parts of a sentence end with the same case, or inflection generally.
Heterogamous: The condition of having two or more kinds of flowers which differ in regard to stamens and pistils, as in the aster.
Hystricomorphous: Like, or allied to, the porcupines; -- said of a group (Hystricomorpha) of rodents.
homeothermism: The process or state of being homoiothermal.
Hinduism: the dominant religion of India; characterized by a caste system anud belief in reincarnation.
Horseman: A rider on horseback; one skilled in the management of horses; a mounted man.
Hope: To desire with expectation or with belief in the possibility or prospect of obtaining; to look forward to as a thing desirable, with the expectation of obtaining it; to cherish hopes of.
Highness: The state of being high; elevation; loftiness.
Holystone: To scrub with a holystone, as the deck of a vessel.
Hilary term: Formerly, one of the four terms of the courts of common law in England, beginning on the eleventh of January and ending on the thirty-first of the same month, in each year; -- so called from the festival of St. Hilary, January 13th.
Hypnoscope: An instrument for ascertaining the susceptibility of a person to hypnotic influences.
Hopscotch: A child's game, in which a player, hopping on one foot, drives a stone from one compartment to another of a figure traced or scotched on the ground; -- called also hoppers.
Hunter: One who hunts wild animals either for sport or for food; a huntsman.
Homosystemic: Developing, in the case of multicellular organisms, from the same embryonic systems into which the secondary unit (gastrula or plant enbryo) differentiates.
Hearthstone: Stone forming the hearth; hence, the fireside; home.
Hagbutter: A soldier armed with a hagbut or arquebus.
Hyphen: To connect with, or separate by, a hyphen, as two words or the parts of a word.
Hydrogenize: To combine with hydrogen; to treat with, or subject to the action of, hydrogen; to reduce; -- contrasted with oxidize.
Huddle: A crowd; a number of persons or things crowded together in a confused manner; tumult; confusion.
Handling: A touching, controlling, managing, using, etc., with the hand or hands, or as with the hands. See Handle, v. t.
Helvetic: Of or pertaining to the Helvetii, the ancient inhabitant of the Alps, now Switzerland, or to the modern states and inhabitant of the Alpine regions; as, the Helvetic confederacy; Helvetic states.
&Verbar;Halichondri\u00e6: An order of sponges, having simple siliceous spicules and keratose fibers; -- called also Keratosilicoidea.
Hasty: Involving haste; done, made, etc., in haste; as, a hasty retreat; a hasty sketch.
Hearsecloth: A cloth for covering a coffin when on a bier; a pall.
Hydrobarometer: An instrument for determining the depth of the sea water by its pressure.
&Verbar;Hypogastrium: The lower part of the abdomen.
house-proud: proud of one's house or its furnishings or upkeep.
Howbeit: Be it as it may; nevertheless; notwithstanding; although; albeit; yet; but; however.
Homing: Home-returning; -- used specifically of carrier pigeons.
Humiliation: The act of humiliating or humbling; abasement of pride; mortification.
&Verbar;Hesperornis: A genus of large, extinct, wingless birds from the Cretaceous deposits of Kansas, belonging to the Odontornithes. They had teeth, and were essentially carnivorous swimming ostriches. Several species are known. See Illust. in Append.
Hard-favored: Hard-featured; ill-looking; as, Vulcan was hard-favored.
Hunch: To push or jostle with the elbow; to push or thrust suddenly.
hushed: having the sound level reduced; -- especially used of the noise of conversation; as, speaking in hushed tones.
&Verbar;Hemibranchi: An order of fishes having an incomplete or reduced branchial apparatus. It includes the sticklebacks, the flutemouths, and Fistularia.
&Verbar;Hepar: Liver of sulphur; a substance of a liver-brown color, sometimes used in medicine. It is formed by fusing sulphur with carbonates of the alkalies (esp. potassium), and consists essentially of alkaline sulphides. Called also hepar sulphuris (&unr_;).
Horoscoper: One versed in horoscopy; an astrologer.
Hollyhock: A species of Althæa (Althæa rosea), bearing flowers of various colors; -- called also rose mallow.
Harmoniphon: An obsolete wind instrument with a keyboard, in which the sound, which resembled the oboe, was produced by the vibration of thin metallic plates, acted upon by blowing through a tube.
Halidom: Holiness; sanctity; sacred oath; sacred things; sanctuary; -- used chiefly in oaths.
Heliacal: Emerging from the light of the sun, or passing into it; rising or setting at the same, or nearly the same, time as the sun.
Hartbeest: A large South African antelope (Alcelaphus caama), formerly much more abundant than it is now. The face and legs are marked with black, the rump with white.
Hassock: A rank tuft of bog grass; a tussock.
&Verbar;Hom\u0153omeria: The state or quality of being homogeneous in elements or first principles; likeness or identity of parts.
H\u00e6matoplastic: Blood formative; -- applied to a substance in early fetal life, which breaks up gradually into blood vessels.
Hamamelidoxylon: A genus of fossil plants having wood identical with or similar to that of the witch hazel.
Homocategoric: Belonging to the same category of individuality; -- a morphological term applied to organisms so related.
Hygeia: The goddess of health, daughter of Esculapius.
Harpsichord: A harp-shaped instrument of music set horizontally on legs, like the grand piano, with strings of wire, played by the fingers, by means of keys provided with quills, instead of hammers, for striking the strings. It is now superseded by the piano.
Haloscope: An instrument for exhibition or illustration of the phenomena of halos, parhelia, and the like.
hand-operated: requiring hand manipulation for operation; not automatic or machine-driven; as, a hand-operated winch.  Opposite of automatic or powered.
Healingly: So as to heal or cure.
Having become very popular or acclaimed; -- said of entertainment performances; as, a hit song, a hit movie.
Haje: The Egyptian asp or cobra (Naja haje.) It is related to the cobra of India, and like the latter has the power of inflating its neck into a hood. Its bite is very venomous. It is supposed to be the snake by means of whose bite Cleopatra committed suicide, and hence is sometimes called Cleopatra's snake or asp. See Asp.
Hemastatics: Laws relating to the equilibrium of the blood in the blood vessels.
Historionomer: One versed in the phenomena of history and the laws controlling them.
Hornstone: A siliceous stone, a variety of quartz, closely resembling flint, but more brittle; -- called also chert.
Hygrology: The science which treats of the fluids of the body.
Hydrolytic: Tending to remove or separate water; eliminating water.
Hilted: Having a hilt; -- used in composition; as, basket-hilted, cross-hilted.
Hennery: An inclosed place for keeping hens.
Heroic: Of or pertaining to, or like, a hero; of the nature of heroes; distinguished by the existence of heroes; as, the heroic age; an heroic people; heroic valor.
Hypognatous: Having the maxilla, or lower jaw, longer than the upper, as in the skimmer.
Hederaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, ivy.
hosepipe: A flexible pipe for conveying a liquid or gas.
handsewn: sewn by hand rather than machine.
Haziness: The quality or state of being hazy.
Hogringer: One who puts rings into the snouts of hogs.
Headless: Having no head; beheaded; as, a headless body, neck, or carcass.
historic: Of or pertaining to history, or the record of past events; as, an historical poem; the historic page.
Homaloid: Flat; even; -- a term applied to surfaces and to spaces, whether real or imagined, in which the definitions, axioms, and postulates of Euclid respecting parallel straight lines are assumed to hold true.
Handwriting: The cast or form of writing peculiar to each hand or person; chirography.
Hoecake: A cake of Indian meal, water, and salt, baked before the fire or in the ashes; -- so called because often cooked on a hoe.
Haymaking: The operation or work of cutting grass and curing it for hay.
H\u00e6macyanin: A substance found in the blood of the octopus, which gives to it its blue color.
Habilatory: Of or pertaining to clothing; wearing clothes.
Halfpace: A platform of a staircase where the stair turns back in exactly the reverse direction of the lower flight. See Quarterpace.
Habitual: Formed or acquired by habit or use.
Honey: To make agreeable; to cover or sweeten with, or as with, honey.
&Verbar;Huch: A large salmon (Salmo hucho or Salvelinus hucho) inhabiting the Danube; -- called also huso, and bull trout.
&Verbar;Hornito: A low, oven-shaped mound, common in volcanic regions, and emitting smoke and vapors from its sides and summit.
Habitable: Capable of being inhabited; that may be inhabited or dwelt in; as, the habitable world.
Hecatompedon: A name given to the old Parthenon at Athens, because measuring 100 Greek feet, probably in the width across the stylobate.
Humpback: A crooked back; a humped back.
Heriot: Formerly, a payment or tribute of arms or military accouterments, or the best beast, or chattel, due to the lord on the death of a tenant; in modern use, a customary tribute of goods or chattels to the lord of the fee, paid on the decease of a tenant.
Hydropneumatic gun carriage: A disappearing gun carriage in which the recoil is checked by cylinders containing liquid and air, the air when compressed furnishing the power for restoring the gun to the firing position. It is used with some English and European heavy guns.
&Verbar;Hysteresis: A lagging or retardation of the effect, when the forces acting upon a body are changed, as if from velocity or internal friction; a temporary resistance to change from a condition previously induced, observed in magnetism, thermoelectricity, etc., on reversal of polarity.
Half nelson: A hold in which one arm is thrust under the corresponding arm of the opponent, generally behind, and the hand placed upon the back of his neck. In the full nelson both hands are so placed.
Hyposulphite: A salt of what was formerly called hyposulphurous acid; a thiosulphate.
Heavy-armed: Wearing heavy or complete armor; carrying heavy arms.
Hypodermic needle: A small slender hollow metallic tube, sharp-pointed at one end and fitted at the other end with an adapter of larger internal diameter, designed for introduction of liquids directly into the bloodstream or other parts of the body of an animal.
Hemadrometer: An instrument for measuring the velocity with which the blood moves in the arteries.
hypersonic: Pertaining to or moving at a speed greatly in excess of the speed of sound, usually meaning greater than mach 5.  All speeds in excess of the speed of sound are supersonic, but to be hypersonic requires even higher speed.
Hobsons choice: A choice without an alternative; the thing offered or nothing.
Homelyn: The European sand ray (Raia maculata); -- called also home, mirror ray, and rough ray.
Hitherto: To this place; to a prescribed limit.
Harvesting: a. & n., from Harvest, v. t.
&Verbar;Hypotheca: An obligation by which property of a debtor was made over to his creditor in security of his debt.
Hemal: Relating to the blood or blood vessels; pertaining to, situated in the region of, or on the side with, the heart and great blood vessels; -- opposed to neural.
Humicubation: The act or practice of lying on the ground.
Hydrazine: Any one of a series of nitrogenous bases, resembling the amines and produced by the reduction of certain nitroso and diazo compounds; as, methyl hydrazine, phenyl hydrazine, etc.  They are derivatives of hydrazine proper, H2N.NH2, which is a doubled amido group, recently (1887) isolated as a stable, colorless gas, with a peculiar, irritating odor. As a base it forms distinct salts. Called also diamide, amidogen, (or more properly diamidogen), etc.
&Verbar;H\u00e6matophilina: A division of Chiroptera, including the bloodsucking bats. See Vampire.
harvest-lice: An erect perennial Old World herb (Agrimonia eupatoria) of dry grassy habitats.
However: Nevertheless; notwithstanding; yet; still; though; as, I shall not oppose your design; I can not, however, approve of it.
Horse-chestnut: The large nutlike seed of a species of Æsculus (Æsculus Hippocastanum), formerly ground, and fed to horses, whence the name.  The seed is not considered edible by humans.
Hamose: Having the end hooked or curved.
Horse-drench: A dose of physic for a horse.
Hypostrophe: The act of a patient turning himself.
Hymnographer: One who writes on the subject of hymns.
Hexahedral: In the form of a hexahedron; having six sides or faces.
High-churchism: The principles of the high-church party.
Housage: A fee for keeping goods in a house.
hometown: the town (or city) where a person was born or grew up or has his principal residence; as, he never went back to his hometown again.
Heaven: To place in happiness or bliss, as if in heaven; to beatify.
Hushing: The process of washing ore, or of uncovering mineral veins, by a heavy discharge of water from a reservoir; flushing; -- also called booming and hydraulic mining.
Hiccough: To have a hiccough or hiccoughs.
Horology: The science of measuring time, or the principles and art of constructing instruments for measuring and indicating portions of time, as clocks, watches, dials, etc.
Hackelia: A genus of plants with seeds that stick to clothing, including stickseed and some of the beggar's lice.
Heating: That heats or imparts heat; promoting warmth or heat; exciting action; stimulating; as, heating medicines or applications.
High-wrought: Wrought with fine art or skill; elaborate.
Heterology: The absence of correspondence, or relation, in type of structure; lack of analogy between parts, owing to their being composed of different elements, or of like elements in different proportions; variation in structure from the normal form; -- opposed to homology.
Hosanna: A Hebrew exclamation of praise to the Lord, or an invocation of blessings.
Heaves: A disease of horses, characterized by difficult breathing, with heaving of the flank, wheezing, flatulency, and a peculiar cough; broken wind.
Heaver: One who, or that which, heaves or lifts; a laborer employed on docks in handling freight; as, a coal heaver.
Hyena: Any carnivorous mammal of the family Hyænidæ, doglike nocturnal mammals of Africa and southern Asia, of which three living species are known. They are large and strong, but cowardly. They feed chiefly on carrion, and are nocturnal in their habits.
Heteroclite: A word which is irregular or anomalous either in declension or conjugation, or which deviates from ordinary forms of inflection in words of a like kind; especially, a noun which is irregular in declension.
Hodman: A man who carries a hod; a mason's tender.
Helicin: A glucoside obtained as a white crystalline substance by partial oxidation of salicin, from a willow (Salix Helix of Linnæus.)
Handiwork: Work done by the hands; hence, any work done personally.
Hogger-pump: The top pump in the pit.
Historicize: To record or narrate in the manner of a history; to chronicle.
Hammercloth: The cloth which covers a coach box.
&Verbar;Hydrorhiza: The rootstock or decumbent stem by which a hydroid is attached to other objects. See Illust. under Hydroidea.
Hydrometrograph: An instrument for determining and recording the quantity of water discharged from a pipe, orifice, etc., in a given time.
Homiletic: Of or pertaining to familiar intercourse; social; affable; conversable; companionable.
Herbalist: One skilled in the knowledge of plants; a collector of, or dealer in, herbs, especially medicinal herbs.
Hilal: Of or pertaining to a hilum.
hegari: Sudanese sorghums having white seeds; one variety is grown in Southwestern U.S.
hartebeest: large African antelope with lyre-shaped horns that curve backward.
Homological: Pertaining to homology; having a structural affinity proceeding from, or base upon, that kind of relation termed homology.
Hydra-tainted: Dipped in the gall of the fabulous hydra; poisonous; deadly.
Honeybee: Any bee of the genus Apis, which lives in communities and collects honey, esp. the common domesticated hive bee (Apis mellifica), the Italian bee (Apis ligustica), and the Arabiab bee (Apis fasciata).  The two latter are by many entomologists considered only varieties of the common hive bee. Each swarm of bees consists of a large number of workers (barren females), with, ordinarily, one queen or fertile female, but in the swarming season several young queens, and a number of males or drones, are produced.
&Verbar;Helichrysum: A genus of composite plants, with shining, commonly white or yellow, or sometimes reddish, radiated involucres, which are often called “everlasting flowers.”
homophonous: Of or pertaining to a homophone or homophony; as, homophonous words.
Hesperidene: An isomeric variety of terpene from orange oil.
Hurtle: To move with violence or impetuosity; to whirl; to brandish.
Hylic: Of or pertaining to matter; material; corporeal; as, hylic influences.
Heathenness: State of being heathen or like the heathen.
Histographer: One who describes organic tissues; an histologist.
Hobble skirt: A woman's skirt so scant at the bottom as to restrain freedom of movement after the fashion of a hobble.
Homocercy: The possession of a homocercal tail.
Hemialbumose: An albuminous substance formed in gastric digestion, and by the action of boiling dilute acids on albumin. It is readily convertible into hemipeptone. Called also hemialbumin.
Historiographer: An historian; a writer of history; especially, one appointed or designated to write a history; also, a title bestowed by some governments upon historians of distinction.
Hygrograph: An instrument for recording automatically the variations of the humidity of the atmosphere.
Hoosier: A nickname given to an inhabitant of the State of Indiana.
Hidrotic: A medicine that causes perspiration; a diaphoretic or a sudorific.
&Verbar;Hypermetropia: An abnormal condition of the eye in which, through shortness of the eyeball or fault of the refractive media, the rays of light come to a focus behind the retina, making vision for distant objects better than for near objects; farsightedness; -- now most commonly called hyperopia.  Cf. Emmetropia.
Homeward: Toward home; in the direction of one's house, town, or country.
hearing-impaired: having a hearing impairment making hearing difficult; having a defective but functioning sense of hearing.
Hayfork: A fork for pitching and tedding hay.
hearthrug: a rug spread out in front of a fireplace.
Herself: An emphasized form of the third person feminine pronoun; -- used as a subject with she; as, she herself will bear the blame; also used alone in the predicate, either in the nominative or objective case; as, it is herself; she blames herself.
Hemerobian: A neuropterous insect of the genus Hemerobius, and allied genera.
Hyopastron: The second lateral plate in the plastron of turtles; -- called also hyosternum.
Histrionic: Of or relating to the stage or a stageplayer; befitting a theatre; theatrical.
Homograph: One of two or more words identical in orthography, but having different derivations and meanings; as, fair, n., a market, and fair, a., beautiful.
harmonizable: capable of being made harmonious or consistent.
Hedgerow: A row of shrubs, or trees, planted for inclosure or separation of fields.
&Verbar;Humus: That portion of the soil formed by the decomposition of animal or vegetable matter. It is a valuable constituent of soils.
houseguest: a guest entertained and staying overnight in one's house for one or more nights.
Haybote: An allowance of wood to a tenant for repairing his hedges or fences; hedgebote. See Bote.
Hymen: A fabulous deity; according to some, the son of Apollo and Urania, according to others, of Bacchus and Venus. He was the god of marriage, and presided over nuptial solemnities.
Homesick: Pining for home; in a nostalgic condition.
handset: The mouthpiece and earpiece of a communications device mounted on a single handle; as, when the telephone rings, pick up the handset.
Hackster: A bully; a bravo; a ruffian; an assassin.
Hock: The state of having been pawned; usually preceded by in; as, all her jewelry is in hock.
Hugoesque: of, pertaining to, or in the style of Victor Hugo.
Hebdomadary: A member of a chapter or convent, whose week it is to officiate in the choir, and perform other services, which, on extraordinary occasions, are performed by the superiors.
Hemorrhagic: Pertaining or tending to a flux of blood; consisting in, or accompanied by, hemorrhage.
Hexine: A hydrocarbon, C6H10, of the acetylene series, obtained artificially as a colorless, volatile, pungent liquid; -- called also hexoylene.
hit it off: To get along well together; to be compatible; to work well together; -- of people in interactive situations; as, the new chemist hit it off immediately with his supervisor.
Hydruret: A binary compound of hydrogen; a hydride.
H\u00e6matoin: A substance formed from the hematin of blood, by removal of the iron through the action of concentrated sulphuric acid. Two like bodies, called respectively hæmatoporphyrin and hæmatolin, are formed in a similar manner.
Heretoch: The leader or commander of an army; also, a marshal.
Hipe: To throw by means of a hipe.
Haul: A pulling with force; a violent pull.
&Verbar;Harpa: A genus of marine univalve shells; the harp shells; -- so called from the form of the shells, and their ornamental ribs.
Heterologous: Characterized by heterology; consisting of different elements, or of like elements in different proportions; different; -- opposed to homologous; as, heterologous organs.
Honeysuckle: One of several species of flowering plants, much admired for their beauty, and some for their fragrance.
Horsehair: A hair of a horse, especially one from the mane or tail; the hairs of the mane or tail taken collectively;
Harmine: An alkaloid accompanying harmaline (in the Peganum harmala), and obtained from it by oxidation. It is a white crystalline substance.
Heteronomous: Subject to the law of another.
Hexastich: A poem consisting of six verses or lines.
hindshank: a cut of meat from the upper part of a rear leg.
Heed: Attention; notice; observation; regard; -- often with give or take.
Habenaria: A genus of chiefly terrestrial orchids with tubers or fleshy roots often having long slender spurs and petals and lip lobes; it includes species formerly placed in the genus Gymnadeniopsis.
Heel: To perform by the use of the heels, as in dancing, running, and the like.
&Verbar;Heterauxesis: Unequal growth of a cell, or of a part of a plant.
&Verbar;Hylodes: The piping frog (Hyla Pickeringii), a small American tree frog, which in early spring, while breeding in swamps and ditches, sings with high, shrill, but musical, notes.
Hexavalent: Having a valence of six; -- said of hexads.
Hemigamous: Having one of the two florets in the same spikelet neuter, and the other unisexual, whether male or female; -- said of grasses.
Heteroscian: One who lives either north or south of the tropics, as contrasted with one who lives on the other side of them; -- so called because at noon the shadows always fall in opposite directions (the one northward, the other southward).
Hygiene: That department of sanitary science which treats of the preservation of health, esp. of households and communities; a system of principles or rules designated for the promotion of health.
Hexeikosane: A hydrocarbon, C26H54, resembling paraffine; -- so called because each molecule has twenty-six atoms of carbon.
Horrify: To cause to feel horror; to strike or impress with horror; as, the sight horrified the beholders.
Healer: One who, or that which, heals.
Happen: To come by chance; to come without previous expectation; to fall out.
Havanese: Of or pertaining to Havana, in Cuba.
